PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 15 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Eligibility Guidelines: Disabled Persons
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That there is an urgent need to alleviate the severe hardship and emotional stress caused by the new guidelines used by the Department of Social Security and/or the Department of Health. These state that the availability of work for people with certain disabilities is 'irrelevant' in determining eligibility for pensions.
(1) That the present eligibility criteria be changed so that factors such as the availability of work are taken into account.
(2) That a quicker and more accessible system of appeals be set up which is independent of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Health.
(3) That the review mechanisms and administrative procedures be simplified and less confusing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for National Development and Energy read the internal research memorandum of the Economic and Policy Division of the Department of Trade and Resources entitled 'Resource investment in prospect and the balance of payments-some implications for the economy'? Has he noted the amount the memorandum estimates will actually be spent overseas on capital equipment for mining ventures in Australia? Does this 'leakage', as the memorandum refers to it, represent a reduction in the amount of money that will actually be invested in Australia on Australian projects? Does he accept the estimate by participants in the North West Shelf project that 50 per cent of the investment actually will be spent overseas? Does this mean that on this project alone only half the $4,000m supposedly to be invested in Australia will in fact come to this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —From recollection, I have not seen the document. If Senator Button has a copy perhaps he will let me have it and I will peruse it. I would be very grateful.
—We can do that for you.

—Thank you very much. I accept the invitation to peruse the document. I have noted that the newspapers reported that the Department of Trade and Resources had given particular figures. Estimates for the decades ahead show enormous increases in the number of ventures in Australia. As the Senate will know, the estimate from the Department of Industry and Commerce shows that something like $33 billion will be in the pipeline. I draw the attention of those who think that that may be an overestimate to the fact that a recent official publication by the New South Wales Government indicates an investment of $23 billion in that State alone. I say to those who said before that we had overestimated that the evidence is looking as though we have underestimated. Nevertheless, there will be some fallout.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that in order to establish the huge infrastructure that will be necessary a considerable quantity of imports of large and specialised capital equipment and goods must occur. Indeed, it is desirable that it should occur. One of the things that will happen is that the nature and character of Australian industry will expand through the need to service this new kind of capital equipment in future. That is acknowledged by Australian industry. The initial importation, apart from anything else, perhaps will ease the balance of trade and the hardening of the currency. Some will find comfort in that. It will not in any way prejudice the long term employment of Australians. A new kind of technological industry will be developed in Australia.

It is a matter for commercial judgment in the end whether these figures are right. I saw the figures for the North West Shelf. I imagine that a very considerable amount of equipment will come from overseas. We will try, wherever we can, to insist that Australian industry is favoured. We are enormously interested in creating more and more job opportunities in Australia. The very development of these industries will create permanent, new and expanded job opportunities. If I can add more once I have perused the document-I assume that the document is authentic and has been made available for public circulation-I will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said in his answer that the figures were a matter for commercial judgment. Are they not also a matter for political judgment? For example, prior to the last election, Sir Phillip Lynch came up with a figure of about $33 billion which would be invested in Australia. It is quite apparent from this document and from part of the Minister's answer that at least half that sum in many instances will not be invested in Australia but will be spent overseas.

—In my initial response I indicated two things: First of all, the amount of $33 billion is very conservative. The figure will be much higher. The total figure cannot be predicted at this moment. Certainly, I see a figure of $30-odd billion finding its investment residually in Australia overall. If Senator Button is asking whether a portion of any one investment figure will be taken up in imports, the answer is absolutely yes. That is to be acknowledged. Nevertheless, major and long term investment of at least that order will be generated in Australia because of the need for our own industries to expand to service the new industries. If Senator Button is seeking an offset for the initial imports, he should also put in a contra for the long term development of industry in Australia.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the latest findings by Australian Public Opinion Polls, concerning 2,031 people throughout Australia, that 57 per cent of Australians favour retention of the 40-hour working week? As the Government's responsible stand on this issue appears to have the endorsement of a majority of Australians, does the Government propose to yield to the demands of a vocal minority to halt its campaign of highlighting the economic dangers of the 35-hour week? Will the Government move to eliminate penalty rates for overtime so that those unions which obtain a 35-hour week under State awards are not able to use that 35-hour week as a means of outflanking wage guidelines?

—I did see a newspaper report of the survey mentioned by the honourable senator in his question and I noted with some satisfaction that 57 per cent of the people surveyed favour retention of the 40-hour week. That is, of course, a very encouraging level of support for the attitude of the Government that it is not in Australia's present interest to see a general reduction in working hours in this country.
—It never has been, according to your mob.

—I have little doubt that the people of Australia will not be shifted from that view by interjections of the sort that we have heard from the honourable senator opposite. I think that the public of Australia understands that, if labour costs go up, it is very likely that prices will go up and that Australia's position generally will deteriorate. Senator MacGibbon suggests in his question that the Government might move to remove the penalty rates which are payable for overtime as a means of offsetting the labour cost increases which would arise with a general reduction of working hours. I doubt whether that would be a practical course of action open to the Government, but I will refer the suggestion to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I think that the suggestion underlines the simple fact that a general reduction of working hours means an increase in costs to industry and, of necessity, a rise in the cost structure in Australia, including the cost of living of individual Australians. Indeed, this is a matter on which honourable senators will hear a statement later this morning. Perhaps I should not attempt to anticipate too much the contents of that statement.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that the Australian Society of Accountants pays a fee of $10,000 annually to the employer, the practice or the company of its president as a recognition that the position of president takes up a lot of time from employment and to compensate these firms for the considerable lost time in carrying out this important office? Has such a payment been made to the Department of Social Security in respect of this year's president, the Director-General of Social Services, Mr Lanigan? If it has not been paid to the Department of Social Security, to whom has it been paid? Has the Department been compensated in any way for the time Mr Lanigan has spent as president of the Australian Society of Accountants this year?

—I was not aware that the Australian Society of Accountants followed the practice indicated by the honourable senator in his question. I will make inquiries with respect to that part of the question which clearly falls within my area of responsibility, namely, the Department of Social Security, and I will ascertain whether any payment of the sort indicated by the honourable senator has been made to my Department. I will examine the other matters which he raised in his question and let him have a considered reply in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TOTALISATOR AGENCY BOARD

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory aware of complaints that the Canberra racecourse Totalisator Agency Board displayed incorrect information relating to the starting horses in interstate races on Saturday, 21 March, specifically that a horse which subsequently gained second place in its race was shown as scratched on lists displayed by the TAB? Does the Minister agree that punters justifiably would be very angry at being thus misled and the effect this incompetence had on their decisions as to on which horses they invested their money? Has the Minister ordered, or will he order, an investigation of who was responsible for this serious error in a matter on which the TAB should be scrupulously reliable? What recourse do Australian Capital Territory punters have against the TAB?

—Although I am not a great follower of races, particularly in the Australian Capital Territory, I have some information about this matter. I am aware of the complaints of particular punters. I imagine that if I were a punter of note I would be as upset as some of those of whom Senator Martin has spoken. I can confirm the fact that a horse was shown as scratched in the sixth race and that, in fact, that horse ran second. However, I am informed that the TAB has informed the Minister that the mistake was noted and corrected 25 minutes before the start of the race, and that a public announcement of the change was made. I am unable to confirm for Senator Martin whether that in fact occurred in all cases and in all offices. I may need to get some further information about that for her. I understand that those people who feel aggrieved in this matter can take their case to the TAB and have it considered. I understand that such cases will receive sympathetic consideration.

—Will the Attorney-General confirm recent reports that the Ministerial Review Committee, more familiarly known as the razor gang, has recommended the disbanding of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission and that the Commission's demise is, in fact, imminent? Is it true that under the proposed new arrangements the consultative functions of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission are to be taken over by a part time advisory council and that its funding functions-what is left of them-are to be taken over by the Attorney-General's Department? How can the Attorney-General reconcile these new arrangements with his speech of 18 February this year when he said, among other things, that it was wrong in principle for legal aid ever to be administered within the Attorney-General's Department? Finally, will he give a clear assurance or undertaking that the Commonwealth's funding of legal aid-in particular the funding of the State commissions-will not fall in real terms following this move?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has taken some decisions in principle in relation to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. I am not in a position to make any announcement in relation to these matters. We have entered into agreements in relation to legal aid matters with four States which have established legal aid commissions and it is necessary to consult with the States in relation to these questions. I am in the process of doing that at present. Any ultimate decisions that may be made will have to take account of the attitudes of the States with which agreements have been entered into.
—And the Parliament.

—Naturally, as Senator Missen quite rightly says, at this stage any changes in the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission will require the consent of the Parliament. As I have said, I cannot make any announcement of what the Government's decisions will be because they cannot be finalised until those consultations with the States with which there are agreements are concluded and the Government considers the views of those States. However, I want to make it quite clear that there is no intention on the part of the Government to reduce its commitments to the level of legal aid or the commitments it has made in agreements with the States to maintain the level of activity of legal aid. There are no renegotiations in that area whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: What I said in the speech which I made at a seminar on legal aid held in Melbourne some weeks ago and to which Senator Evans referred-I reiterate it here-was that I am concerned about the administrative costs of legal aid and I would like to see new arrangements, if possible, to reduce the administrative costs because the legal aid dollar is under a fair deal of strain. I want to see that money go as far as possible in giving direct assistance to people who need legal aid rather than it being spent on administration. That is the overriding principle on which I am approaching this problem and on which the Government is approaching this problem. Also, I believe that the Commonwealth has to maintain not only its major funding role, which will be maintained in this area, but also certain functions such as looking at legal aid on a national level, certain responsibilities on a national level, research into legal aid and so on. Obviously there are some continuing functions, none of which are under consideration to be cut out at the Commonwealth level. But certainly, as I said, none of the discussions that are taking place involve any reduction in the actual commitment of the Commonwealth Government to its existing responsibilities for funding legal aid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Attorney-General also reiterate what he said in that speech on 18 February, which was, in substance that he regards it as being wrong in principle for legal aid to be administered through his own Attorney-General's Department?

—In that part of the speech I was referring to the system of the Australian Legal Aid Office whereby the actual decisions on who will get legal aid are made by members of the Attorney-General's Department. I think that is wrong in principle. I certainly reiterate that. Of course, the decisions on what funds will be made available and the recommendations to this Parliament have to be made by the responsible Minister on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department. I want to make that distinction quite clear.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that a Mr Abraham Ordia, the Nigerian president of the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa, is in Australia at present as a paid guest of the Government? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that, before addressing the National Press Club in Canberra last week, Mr Ordia distributed copies of a printed extract from a speech made by John Vorster in the South African Parliament in April 1967 dealing with the South African Government's sports policies at that time? Will the Minister verify, firstly, that there is racial integration in South African sport at all levels-for example, South Africa's national soccer team consists of blacks and whites; secondly, that a non-white gentleman heads the South African cricket union; and, thirdly, that for more than 10 years athletics in South Africa have been racially integrated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of recent Press reports regarding the visit of Mr Ordia. As to the particular matters raised by Senator Jessop, I will need to seek advice from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I cannot add anything on the questions that were raised, but I am aware of the visit of the man concerned.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent collapse of two insurance broking firms, Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd and the One Stop Insurance Shop Pty Ltd, at a cost to their clients of millions of dollars? Does the Minister realise that these are only the latest of a series of failures by insurance brokers which have left hundreds of thousands of ordinary people without the insurance cover for which they paid? Does she also realise that some people with large claims against the failed brokers have been forced into bankruptcy? Why is the Government so reluctant to protect the Australian public by introducing legislation to regulate the insurance broking industry? Why is it still possible for an insurance broker to set himself up without training and experience, to operate without belonging to the partly self-regulatory brokers associations, and to set up a business in one State in Australia despite having left millions of dollars worth of debts in another State? Finally, why has no action been taken on the recommendation of the inquiry into insurance agents and brokers by the Law Reform Commission, despite Senator Carrick's undertaking in 1978 that the Government would make a rapid decision on broker regulation after the inquiry had submitted its report? Will the Government undertake to implement the Commission's draft legislation in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Treasurer's attention was drawn to the report referred to with regard to Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd. The Treasurer dealt with a question on this matter on 5 March of this year. With regard to the further questions raised by Senator Chipp relating to the Law Reform Commission's report, I am able to state that this report was tabled in Parliament on 16 September of last year by the Attorney-General. The matters referred to by Senator Chipp lead me to suspect that he understands the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission's report. The statement made at the time of the tabling of that report indicated that departmental officers were undertaking an assessment of the report. The views of the industry associations, the State governments and other interested parties were sought by the Government following the tabling of that report. To the date of the brief that I have on this matter, certain key industry bodies had not made any submissions on the matter and some of the State governments had not responded. I understand that the Western Australian Government intends to introduce legislation in this area shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the matters raised by Senator Chipp with regard to the Government's response to the report, I say on behalf of the Treasurer that the Government will consider the options on the matter as soon as practicable following receipt of the submissions sought on the recommendations. Views are held by some segments of the insurance industry to the effect that supervisory legislation would be welcomed and should be introduced. The Government regards the input from all interested bodies, such as the industry groups, as important and as an essential pre-requisite to the making of a sound assessment of the Commission's recommendations. In general terms, when all submissions are received they will be considered, and the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission will be considered by the Government at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen reports that production of the Nomad aircraft has been disrupted as a result of delays in Government authorisations? Is it correct that the Government Aircraft Factories will have to wait another 18 months for authorisation of further Nomad production, which already has put a stop to forward ordering of materials and components, making the aircraft more expensive and causing major delays? If so, will the Government take immediate steps to overcome this situation so that the excellent sales of the Nomad will not be jeopardised by a long delay in the supply of these aircraft?

—My most recent recollection of matters affecting the Nomad aircraft is that some time ago the Government authorised further financial support for the continued production of the aircraft. I am unable to say in response to a question without notice, however, just when that occurred and for what period it applied. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Industry and Commerce and seek an early reply for the honourable senator.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is in respect of restrictions recently imposed by the Government on travel by citizens of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in Australia which, of course, are not as severe as those restrictions placed by the Soviet authorities on Australian citizens visiting that country. Do these restrictions apply to Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians visiting this country? If they do apply to Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians visiting this country, why do they apply in view of the fact that the Australian Government has not recognised the incorporation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania into the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer that matter to the Minister and seek early information for Senator Harradine.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Will the Minister give consideration to ensuring that the language used in literature for migrants is far less sophisticated and simpler so that it can be easily understood by those people who have not yet become used to the English language?
—I will pass that suggestion to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who I am sure will be interested in it, and ask him to provide an early reply.

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be aware of newspaper reports on Monday noting that a team of eminent Australian scientists, led by Professor Charles Kerr of the Commonwealth Institute of Health, fears that hundreds of tonnes of a toxic chemical which makes up the defoliant agent orange were clandestinely imported and sold in Australia. Does the Minister agree that, if it is shown that such chemicals were imported into Australia, the validity of the Government's epidemiological study of veterans' illnesses will be severely undermined? When was the Minister first made aware of the fact that the inquiry under his jurisdiction was also being frustrated by the Bureau of Customs? The team of scientists referred to claimed that the Australian Bureau of Customs 'has declined to be of any assistance in determining the true nature or origins of the imports from Singapore'. When was the Minister first alerted to that possibility? What steps has he taken to ensure that the Bureau of Customs gives its fullest co-operation to the inquiry under his jurisdiction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter to which Senator Tate has referred is quite a complex one. If he will just bear with me for a moment, I will explain one or two things to him. Firstly, the material being discussed has a very long name-I will have to use the acronym KTCP-and is in fact a constituent in the manufacture of 2,4,5-T. It is not in itself a defoliant. I am advised that it does not contain any dioxin or poison of that kind. The situation is that there has been speculation that some of this material was brought into Australia in the early 1970s. No information is available to me yet as to how much came in in the early 1970s. I am investigating the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been in touch with Dr Peter Hall who is one of the people who brought the matter to the attention of the public by way of an article which appears in the April 1981 edition-I do not know quite how that could be since April has not arrived yet-of the journal Chemistry in Australia. The article made the point-I will obtain more specific information for Senator Tate on this so that he can see it clearly-that if this material was in fact present in Australia and was used in the manufacture of 2,4,5-T which was then spread throughout Australia, it may have had some impact upon the study which is being undertaken by my Department. But I must say that at this stage all this is speculation. There is no confirmation of any facts. I am sure that Dr Peter Hall will confirm that to Senator Tate if he cares to telephone him and discuss it with him. Nevertheless, the honourable senator asked whether I am aware of this; yes, I am. I am looking into the matter further and will obtain further reports on it. At this stage I am not at all clear as to how much material was used in Australia and, in fact, whether it was not destroyed in some way and did not get into the manufactured stage of 2,4,5-T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question because one section of my question was not answered by the Minister, probably inadvertently, given the technical material that he so masterfully put forward. The obscurity in obtaining the facts may be due, as the scientists allege, to the refusal of the Bureau of Customs to co-operate in detailing the origin and nature of certain suspected imports from Singapore. My question concerns whether the Minister has taken steps and, if so, what steps, to verify the complaint of the scientists in that regard? What steps has he taken to ensure the full co-operation of the Bureau in the future?

—So far I have had nothing but co-operation on the matter from the Bureau of Customs via the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. At this stage I am unable to say whether the material was imported and if so in what quantity. It is not clear from the records I have seen as to how much arrived. Indeed I am pursuing the matter with the Bureau of Customs. I will then see what the answer is. It may not necessarily be so important to know when the material came in or how much came in as to know what happened to it. It is that aspect which I am pursuing most vigorously at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Has the Minister noted an item in today's Sydney Morning Herald reporting that a Soviet satellite in orbit over Australia is being blamed for radio interference on radar screens at Sydney airport for the past few weeks? According to the report the signals block out part of the radar screens. Whilst they are not a danger to air traffic movements they are annoying to air traffic controllers who are subjected to intense pressure during peak hours. Will the Minister institute an inquiry into the possible effects of such interference if it becomes intensified and in particular into the fact that the satellite radio system, according to Transport Australia technicians, is being switched off and on, most likely from the ground?

—I am aware of the newspaper article which appeared today and I am aware that the article contains facts as set out by the honourable senator in his question. I think that all those who use Sydney airport and who depend upon the expertise of the air traffic controllers would have been interested in the article and would have wanted the kind of reassurance which it contained, that the air traffic controllers believe it does not in any way affect air safety. However, I am aware of the pressure under which air traffic controllers work. During my previous time in medical practice air traffic controllers quite often presented themselves with stress diseases. It is quite obvious that the occupation is one that imposes considerable stress upon them. The honourable senator asked particularly whether there is a possibility of establishing an inquiry to look at particular matters raised in the newspaper article. I think that such a decision would rest with the Minister whom I represent in this place. Accordingly I will pass on the honourable senator's request and seek the Minister's response.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. The Minister will recall his many statements to the effect that the Rundle shale oil project would be the answer to Australia's energy needs and that it would be producing 240,000 barrels of oil a day by 1988. I ask the Minister: Has there been a revision of his announced target date for commencement of production at Rundle? If so, what is the reason for the revision and what is the new target date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never stated or seen Rundle to be the answer to Australia's energy needs. I see the development of shale oil and coal liquefaction in the production of synthetic crudes as being a very significant contribution in the decades ahead to overcoming the decline. Rundle, in itself, is one of something like six or seven such projects that are shaping up in Australia. The early advice was that the gross output, that is, including the consumption of oil within the plant itself which would be considerable, would be of the order that Senator McLaren indicated. My understanding is that at the moment there are discussions between the partners regarding any necessity to revise their estimates as to the volume of product output and the time of such production. Such an announcement has not yet been made. It is inevitable that in the months of preparation in the drilling, in the determination of engineering problems and in the testing, there will be revisions. As soon as those revisions are made I imagine they will be made public.

ANSWER.PARA: I do want to say that the picture for Australia is that the import parity pricing is producing further encouraging discoveries of both oil and gas for Australia. This will mean that we will be able to flatten somewhat what had been a sharp fall away from Bass Strait production in the 1980s and therefore to put off perhaps for some years the major need which inevitably will come for significant reliance on synthetic crudes. As we develop more gas, as we develop more oil and as we find that we can use the Bass Strait wells more efficiently, we can extend the indigenous oil. That, of course, is good news for Australia because it means that we do not have to rely so early upon the huge capitalisation required for the synthetic crudes. But I do remind Senator McLaren that I have also announced from time to time the developments of coal liquefaction in the Latrobe Valley and, of course, such prospects, not yet taken further, as Millmerran in Queensland. They all ought to be put in their positions as being part of an orchestration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister responded to the recommendations of the New South Wales Committee of Inquiry into the Legal Provision of Heroin and Other Possible Methods of Diminishing Crime Associated with the Supply and Use of Heroin that the Federal Government should assist in exploring the possibility of monitoring large-scale cash transactions in order to identify those associated with organised drug trafficking? If he has not already responded, when is the Government likely to make that response? Does the Minister know how the New South Wales committee proposes to maintain confidentiality of legal transactions?

—The honourable senator has raised some very important issues concerning trafficking in heroin and the attempts which are being made to identify this through a variety of measures. But the questions asked essentially are questions of detail which will require a response from my colleague in the other place. I will undertake to get an answer for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACACIA RIDGE NORTH NON-OFFICIAL POST OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Have my representations both in this chamber and by letter in relation to the Acacia Ridge North non-official post office yet been considered? Have the express wishes of the 461 Acacia Ridge residents who signed a petition protesting against the proposed closure of this post office now been fully examined? If the Minister for Communications has made a decision on this matter, what is that decision? If the Minister has not made a decision, will he or his representative in this chamber accompany me to the area so that the needs of Acacia Ridge residents may be gauged personally rather than be obtained by way of Australian Postal Commission reports?

—I recall very well Senator Colston's raising in the adjournment debate one evening the question of the non-official post office at Acacia Ridge North and I recall that during my response to him on that occasion I was able to say again how pleased we were that there was to be the opening of a quite handsome new post office in Acacia Ridge in an area not very far from the facility about which he expresses his concern. His question today concerned the progress of the response he is seeking from the Minister and his wish that the Minister visit Acacia Ridge. The Minister will have to respond to both matters. I will obtain an early response for the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Recently the Minister for Health in the Northern Territory, Ian Tuxworth, approved the allocation of two positions in the Darwin school of nursing to two girls from the Philippines. These girls gained their nursing qualifications in Australia, as have some 90 other Filipino girls, and then returned to their villages in the mountains of the Philippines to practice amongst their own people, as present health facilities there are not adequate. Can the Minister advise whether the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has approved in principle the entry of these Filipino girls to Australia? If so, can he advise me of the correct procedures to be followed?
—I have no information that would enable me to answer the question asked by Senator Kilgariff on this matter. I will refer it to the Minister and ask him to give Senator Kilgariff an early reply.

—Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate noted that the former Queensland Minister for Mines, Energy and Police, Mr Camm, was hosted overseas by the BP company which is a member of the consortium which has been awarded the right to mine the Winchester South coal deposits? Has he also noted allegations that the BP-Thiess-Westfield consortium was invited to make a donation to the notorious Bjelke-Petersen Foundation? Finally, is he aware that the Queensland Government awarded the deposit to this consortium without examining the other 31 tenders? In view of this, will the Minister make representations to the Treasurer to ensure that the Foreign Investment Review Board refuses to give approval to this deal?

—I have read certain allegations in the newspapers. I have no knowledge at all of the truth or otherwise of any of them. Senator Primmer will understand that all these matters are clearly within the sovereignty and province of the Queensland Government and are appropriate matters to raise in the Queensland Parliament but are quite outside the jurisdiction of this Parliament. If Senator Primmer has any specific information on this matter, I will be happy to consider it. I am not aware whether any of the three matters raised are factual. The Foreign Investment Review Board would look at the matter through its own terms of reference. If Senator Primmer or any other honourable senator has any information that would come within the terms of reference of the FIRB, I invite him to give it to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The review of Australia's demographic trends conducted by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has been tabled by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). It is important that we look at this review and similar reviews which come before the Parliament at various times. This is a review of demographic trends and the implications of such trends for Australia in the next 20 years. As such, of course, it is important to the planning of many departmental processes and the planning of the industrial development of this country in the future.

Our population, as the document shows, has doubled since World War II and now we have a population of about 14.6 million people. We have the highest level of urban concentrations in the world apart from Hong Kong and Singapore. In recent years about two-thirds of this population increase has been brought about by natural increase and about one-third of it has been brought about by immigration increase. Despite this, our net reproduction rate is still declining basically, as the paper says, because women are making more choices for themselves about whether to work, whether to have families and when they will have families. The increase in the participation rate of women in the work force, of course, is well known.

Certain factors of the review are important and have important implications for planning in the future. The number of people over the age of 65 years is expected to increase by about two-thirds by the end of the century. The number of people over the age of 75 years is expected to double. On present trends, the proportion of people in the labour force will not decrease but it will mean that there will be an older labour force and, probably, a less flexible and a less mobile labour force. The implications of this for the products which will be demanded of our manufacturing industries and for the conditions of work which will be required for this future work force are serious.

The number of ex-nuptial births has increased. There has been a notable increase in the number of single parent families as a result both of choice and of what one might call mischance. This tendency for the reproduction rate to fall, for women to make more choices about what they will do outside the home, about working, and for the number of single parent families to increase is a social change which will not be changed by legislative processes in the area of social security or in related areas, as so many people in the Parliament and outside the Parliament would dearly like. It is the result of social change. It is a change which has occurred in all Western countries. It is a change which has occurred as a result of the higher status of women, the higher level of education of women, and is the choice of women themselves. In most cases it is not something which has been forced on them by any legislative process or by any economic process.

The key to solving the problems of the increasing aged population and the decreasing child population is to have a strong economic base so that we can support people who are forced outside the workforce by age, helplessness or other reasons. What it means is that we must develop our assets and our resources for the benefit of our people so that the wealth which is acquired from these resources can be used to benefit the people of this country who own those assets and resources. The profits of that exploitation should not be moved from this country, nor should they be outside the control of those who live in this country. There should be a conscious policy to concentrate on job opportunities for many disadvantaged groups in the community-single parents, the disabled and the presently unemployed. The implications of some of the answers which we received today and on other days in this place that the resources boom, and the resources boom alone, will solve the employment problems in this community have been quite clearly demonstrated to be false. As Senator Button demonstrated in a question today in giving the facts of the employment which is likely to come from resources development in this country, it is pointless to look to that area and to that area alone without careful planning and careful control of the development of those resources and at the same time protection of some manufacturing industry base in the community.

One of the problems which arise from projections of demographic trends such as this is that we get the very real predictions that in fact we will have an aging, less mobile and more dependent population and, as a result, it is seen that in the future the number of people who will need support by way of funds from the Government will in fact increase and that the proportion of people in employment who are taxed will decrease. This view is used to promote hysteria and the sorts of nonsense which we see in some of the newspapers in this country when mention is made of a welfare backlash. These people are seen by some not to be contributing to the work force and, therefore, are seen as a burden on the community. But we, as a civilised society, of course, should contribute to their welfare and should ensure that they have the same rights as other Australian citizens. Therefore, we should use demographic trends in a sen- sible way to plan for the future rather than throw up our hands or tear out our hair about what will possibly happen as a result of these changing demographic trends. Many problems will face us. The implications of the expenditure in the area of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), including expenditure on child care and age pensions, are difficult and obviously create problems, but we can solve those problems by carefully monitoring what is happening, by carefully planning and by not being inhibited by ideological hang-ups about whether we should have public intervention in areas which will clearly be important in the future. I believe the Senate should take note of this report and that we should have a debate on its implications. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was not going to make any comments on this document at this point. However, because of some of the remarks that Senator Grimes made, I feel obliged to do so. SPEECH.PARA: Through the 1970s, the net reproduction rate, the most common summary measure of population replacement (taking into account both fertility and mortality trends), has, however, continued to fall, from 1.39 to 0.92 by 1979. This is below the long-term level of replacement, 1.00.

I think this very important paper will affect policy decisions of the Government and of policy makers in Australia for some considerable time. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Opposition welcomes the appearance of the first report of the new National Companies and Securities Commission for the year ended 30 June 1980. But we do note that it has been quite a remarkably long time in its preparation and presentation for what essentially is such a slim volume. We hope that this will not be a forerunner of things to come when the Commission is in full operation and as a result its reports are more eagerly awaited. This report is a slim volume for the reason that it covers only the period from the inception of the Commission on 11 March last year, that is 1980, to 30 June in that year. During that time the Commission was simply being established, gearing up to the administrative arrangements and developing channels for consultation with the various relevant organisations around the country. It had then no substantive legislation to administer and the account given in the report of the activities of the Commission during that period is perfectly understandable and in fact informatively documented.

A more alarming consideration is that now, some nine months after the period to which this report refers, there is no substantive legislation for the Commission to be administering. Neither of the Bills which were passed last year and amended this year, namely the Securities Industry Act and the takeovers Act properly described as the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, although having been passed by this Parliament and having become Acts has yet been proclaimed into effect because the States still have not passed the necessary complementary legislation to apply the substance of those Acts in the State domain.

More importantly still, the Companies Bill which is intended to be the keystone of the whole regulatory arch in this area does not appear now to be any closer to fruition than it was at this time last year. The start-up date for the whole of the legislative scheme, we were told at this stage last year, was to be 1 January 1981. Now it is being said that the likely start-up date will be 1 January 1982. The day and the month stay the same; it is just the year that continues to change. There is no doubt that while the Ministerial Council and the States are fiddling in this way, Rome undoubtedly does continue to burn so far as companies and securities law is concerned. Scandals or what look likely to be scandals like the Negri River float for example, continue to erupt, takeovers or profitable non-takeovers continue to take place and in a highly unsatisfactory regulatory framework. There is still a diversity of obligations which ought to be imposed on directors in relation to their responsibilities not only to their shareholders but also to the community at large, which are insufficiently imposed by the present companies legislation and which must be the subject of urgent new national legislation. But still there is no sign of that legislation finally appearing and no sign of the National Companies and Securities Commission actually being given as a result some work to do.

What is happening now with the companies Bill itself has been a matter of considerable public speculation. My own understanding is that a gutting and filleting operation of fairly spectacular dimensions has been taking place in recent months and that the latest Bill which has been recently agreed upon by the Ministerial Council contains none of the even limited innovations and reforms which were contained in the original discussion draft, which was widely circulated over a year ago, and the Bill that was actually tabled last year. The new Bill, as I understand it, simply represents the lowest common denominator of existing State Companies Act provisions. It may be that it is being hoped that the innovatory process will commence once this new companies Bill is in fact on foot as a piece of legislation and the requirement of unanimity as to its terms is replaced by one of majority agreement only. But we in the Opposition cannot help but greet with profound scepticism the whole process which is now unfolding. We have always taken the view, and we take it again today, that effective far-reaching companies legislation will operate only when the Commonwealth abandons the impossible task of seeking concensus from the self-interested, chauvinist, parochially obsessed States in this country and unilaterally exercises its own undoubted Commonwealth powers.

We wish the new National Companies and Securities Commission well and we hope that it does in fact succeed in its urgently necessary task of exercising a supervisory role over the whole operation of company and security operations in this country. But on the evidence of the progress to date as revealed in this report and the non-developments since the middle of last year, we can have no cause for optimism whatever on this score.
