By a variety of delaying tactics the Government, the Liberal Party and some leading members of it in Western Australia in particular, were responsible by this long delay and by forcing a change of government for having the approach altered to one of co-operative federalism.

Senator Evans has pointed out that some of the States have not, as yet, passed the enabling or supporting legislation. It was pointed out by the Committee that that is exactly what would happen; that is, that one of the States would delay the implementation of legislation or would not carry out the necessary amendments to further legislation. The most effective way to control the securities industry is by national legislation and by a national approach because it is a national industry. This Commission ought to be looking at the Holmes a'Court operation. On three occasions Holmes a'Court has engaged in what I have heard described, for the first time, as a profitable non-takeover. It is a phrase which describes exactly what is going on. We learned of this practice in a smaller way. It was called the churning of shares. The values of shares were churned and the insiders knew exactly when the churning would peak, took their profit and moved out. Someone was left holding the baby, to use an old cliche.

That is exactly what is going on at present. South Australians, in loyalty to a company which they consider to be their own, raced in to protect that company and, of course, the price of the shares went up. At a particular point Holmes a'Court pulled out. Those people who were aware of what Holmes a'Court was doing, the insiders who knew the timing, were also able to take substantial profits. The Commission would investigate the means by which this was done. It would be able to look at this recurring practice and would be able to determine that it was a raid upon the securities industry and a raid upon the pockets of the investors. It would take a look at the situation in South Australia and find out just how many people were deprived of substanial sums of money by the Holmes a'Court operation. But nothing will be done because the Commission does not have the power to do it. It seems to me that the Senate will get very close to referring this type of takeover to one of its standing committees or to a select committee it sets up. This is roguery at its worst. It seems to me also that one could take it further and say that it was done in such a way that the public purse also will be at a disadvantage.

It has been implied in questions in the Senate that no tax will be paid on these transactions. If the figure of $16.5m is correct, a lot of money is being taken from a lot of people and finishing up in the pockets of one person. That is redistribution of wealth the other way round. This Commission is not in a position to carry out an investigation of the Holmes a'Court operation. I am told that he engaged in this practice in the United Kingdom in regard to the Rolls Royce company. He has done it in Australia on two previous occasions and he can do it on a third and fourth occasion because at present the Commission does not have the power or the legislation to take the necessary action to investigate and to close the loopholes he is using. If that is the case, and if this legislation is going to be delayed continually by the States, this Parliament will have to take the initiative and say: 'We have tried to do it by co-operative federalism and failed. We ought to revert to the Senate Select Committee's recommendation that there should be national legislation'. Failing that, I think it is the responsibility of the Senate, if it cannot refer it to a standing committee or if it is not pertinent to do so, to set up again the Senate Select Committee to investigate, in particular, the Holmes a'Court operations. We cannot allow this situation to go further. I welcome the fact that there is a Commission now. I will also welcome the day when the Commission has the legislation that is necessary to give it the power to deal with the roguery which I have just described. As no one else wishes to speak, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian economy is poised to enter a period of considerable growth. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has forecast that economic growth in Australia in 1981 will be the highest of all developed economies. The year 1981 represents the beginning of a period of expansion as resources development intensifies and economic growth is consolidated. I regret to state, however, that the benefits of much of this growth will be jeopardised if recent trends in earnings continue and if the union campaign for a 35-hour week is successful. The Government is aware that an estimated 36 per cent of all full time non-managerial employees are currently working less than 40 hours a week. It does not follow, however, that the economy can stand an across-the-board application of a 35-or even a 37 1/2-hour week to the total work force.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Australian economy has achieved some stability over the past six years, that stability would be seriously jeopardised if the shorter working hours campaign was achieved in the near future. It is worrying enough that claims that have a damaging economic impact are made, but this damage is compounded by the fact that trade unions are pursuing these claims by direct industrial action; action which is disruptive to the Australian community and robs the economy of its full potential. Over recent weeks the unions' shorter working hours campaign has received widespread attention. These claims are bound up with the more general issue of wage demands. It is crucial that restraint be exercised. Those engaged in the union campaign seem to ignore the fact that their campaign for reduced hours and their unremitting pressures for wage increases will seriously damage the Australian economy and undermine the benefits of the period of growth.

The Government is deeply concerned about this situation. It is necessary therefore to ensure that all Australians are aware of the threat posed if the current campaign continues and is successful. Reductions in hours of work prima facie lead to an increase in hourly wage costs. Wage costs are the most significant element in unit labour costs, and increases in unit labour costs are a significant element in price increases. I strongly emphasise the Government's concern about the possible growth of unit labour costs in the light of the recent trends in wages and earnings and in view of the number of current claims for shorter working hours.

The Government's primary economic objective is to promote a growth in the standard of living of every member of the Australian community. However, this can be achieved only if the problem of inflation is overcome. The consequences of sustained high rates of inflation are well known to honourable senators. It damages business confidence, curtails investment, reduces international competitiveness and weakens demand, economic activity and employment. Further high rates of inflation have a destablising impact on wage fixation and industrial relations. Wage restaint is crucial in meeting the primary anti-inflation objective. Developments on labour costs could have a significant influence on the course of inflation in the short and medium terms. If growth in money and real wages is not restrained and/or labour costs are added to by reductions in working hours, then clearly the battle against inflation will be made all the more difficult. Every worker knows from experience that a wage increase does mean a price increase. The higher the wage increase, the greater the consequent effect on prices and the living standards of people.

Since 1974-75 the rate of inflation has been reduced. This has been the result of and a vindication of the Government's policies. Whilst inflation in the year to the December quarter 1980 dropped to 9.3 per cent, this is regarded by the Government as too high. Unfortunately, and this must be understood, there is no prospect of the much needed further significant decline in inflation if the current surge in labour cost is not moderated. In the period since 1978 the acceleration in the rate of growth in award wages, combined with renewed over-award activity, has resulted in significant earnings growth. It is a matter of concern to the Government that there has been such an acceleration of wage movements since 1978. This reflects both increases through the indexation of award wages and increases gained outside national wage cases.

Award wage increases for work value adjustments began to occur in late 1978 and have gathered momentum so that a very large proportion of the work force has now participated in that work value 'round'. Wage increases of the order of $8 a week have been awarded across a wide range of industries. Additionally, the increasing importance of over-award payments has been reflected in the re-emergence of considerable earnings drift since late 1979. For example, the most recent statistics available indicate that, in the December quarter last year, the series for average weekly ordinary time earnings for full time non-managerial employees showed a 15.2 per cent increase over the corresponding quarter in the previous year. When this is compared with the 9.3 per cent increase in the consumer price index over that period it is quite apparent that employees have made significant real gains over the last 12 months. Clearly such rates of wage increase cannot be allowed to continue without adverse implications for the Australian economy.

The Government is concerned that these labour cost pressures are in the system. We are concerned that some union leaders apparently think there is some bottomless pit into which they can dig for wage increases without affecting the economy or the well-being and the employment prospects of their own members. The lessons of the 1970s have not been learnt well enough by some union officials. But that is not the end of it. Now, superimposed on these excessive wage pressures is the union campaign for a shorter working week. A campaign which, if successful, would lift unit labour costs in Australia by such magnitude as to erode significantly our advances in lowering inflation, erode seriously business profitability, confidence and international competitiveness, reduce employment and generally undermine the return to economic health which is under way.

Unions are increasingly pursuing their wage demands and their unrealistic demands for a 35-hour week with direct industrial action. This magnifies the economic consequences of the unions' demands. Industry, that is the livelihood of both employers and workers, faces increased costs due to the effects of industrial action and employers face greater uncertainty in planning decisions for the same reason. Their decision on whether to invest in new machinery and equipment, or in new building and construction works, or to expand employment and in-plant training schemes for workers, becomes far more difficult if they cannot make reasonable estimates of the degree to which such machinery, plant and workforce will be idle because of industrial disruption in their own or interdependent industries.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission does not share the view of some unions that the effects of industrial action are not significant and serious. In its national wage case decision of 14 July last, it discounted the increase awarded in specific recognition of the damage caused by the excessive levels of industrial disruption that prevailed. More recently, in its national wage case decision of 9 January of this year, the Commission identified the excessive levels of disputation as one of the factors which led to the suspension of wage indexation. In the latter decision the Commission said:

Costs to the economy arising from stoppages and bans threaten not only improvements in real wages and conditions but even the maintenance of existing standards. This is not a moral judgment but a matter of hard economic reality.

The effects, both direct and indirect, of the shorter hours campaign have now been felt in all States and many sectors of the economy. Some, and this is by no means a comprehensive list of the areas directly concerned include: The engineering and metals sector, shipbuilding and repair, mining equipment manufacturing, glass manufacturing, power generation, the brewing industry, and the Altona petro-chemical complex. In relation to the Altona petro-chemical settlement, the Minister for Industrial Relations has already said that it is disgraceful that the form of industrial pressure used by the unions concerned at the complex over such a long period has brought about a settlement so costly to the public interest. The Government intervened in this hearing and strongly argued against the settlement. It continues to oppose the productivity bargaining concept in its application to reduced working hours.

It is important to note that the Commission began consideration of this matter in September 1980 before the last national wage case began. It will be recalled that the Commission was strongly critical of this type of campaign by the unions in bringing down its decision in that case. When the Australian Council of Trade Unions took over the shorter working hours campaign last year it was claimed that direct industrial action would be minimised. It was stated that the ACTU was co-ordinating the campaign and the implication was that it would be less disruptive. Unfortunately for the community and the Australian economy this has not been the case. Take for example the situation in the metal industry. This is a major sector of Australian industry. It has thousands of employers who provide jobs for hundreds of thousands of Australians. It is an industry which in a very real way confronts competition from overseas. It has been disrupted by direct industrial action of some form or another for nearly 12 months now. If the unions think they have a justifiable claim, they should cease this harmful action and submit their claims to arbitration. They have not done so. They are resisting arbitration. That is not an attitude usually taken by groups who believe they have justifiable claims. It is an attitude of groups who recognise the unreasonableness of their position and have to resort to the weapon of duress to try to get their own way.

The economic consequences of reduced hours of work must be clearly understood. The implications of the campaign are enormous and the public should be made aware of the facts. The Government intends that this be done. The effect of reduced standard hours is best understood by thinking about the costs of producing a given level of output. Assuming that the given level of output requires the same total number of hours of labour input whether standard hours are 40 or 35-in other words that labour productivity is the same-an employer has to pay out more in wages to purchase the required labour input if standard hours are reduced. If a sector which currently works a standard 40-hour week were to move to 35-hours there are a number of courses of action open to an employer.

Firstly, he could seek to maintain his level of output by taking on more employees. If he were to do this, unit labour costs must increase. The weekly standard wage remains the same so that the hourly wage rate is higher. As well, an extra five hours labour has to be paid for at this higher hourly rate to maintain the level of output. In this case unit labour costs could increase by about 14 per cent. This is a clear disincentive to the employment of more people and, as I will explain later, gives the lie to arguments that shorter working hours would stimulate the overall level of employment. Secondly, an employer faced with a reduction of weekly standard hours from 40 to 35 could seek to maintain his level of output by having his existing work force work more overtime. This would compound the cost factor in the first example because if the difference is made up with additional overtime the penalty rates involved would cause an added burden on unit labour costs. As a result, they could increase by about 21 per cent. Finally, as an alternative to maintaining output, an employer confronted with such a labour cost rise could allow his output to fall. If he were to do this, no extra employees or overtime would be required but unit labour costs still increase since the same total is being paid in wages but output has fallen.

If the employer or industry concerned were to accept a reduction in output broadly in line with the reduction in hours worked, unit labour costs could increase by 12 1/2 per cent. Cost increases of this magnitude would clearly have a devastating effect on Australian industry. Now, employers facing an increase in unit labour costs of this order can be expected to increase their selling prices. They may or may not increase them in the same proportion as the increase in unit labour costs, but two things are clear: Firstly, the increase in costs resulting from a substantial reduction in the standard working week would be so large as to ensure some significant price response; and, secondly, if employers do not fully cover their increase in costs, their profits are eroded. This will inevitably reduce the level of economic activity and, consequently, the number of jobs available. The price response is, of course, just another expression for the effect on the rate of inflation.

I ask the Senate to contemplate the consequences for the CPI of a jump in the rate of increase of unit labour costs-currently in the order of 10 per cent-to something like 20 per cent or 25 per cent if there is a general move to a 35-hour week. The proper conclusion is inescapable to all except those who, for their own selfish purposes, will not admit it. We must consolidate the recent improvements in economic growth which have been reflected in the consistent growth in employment over the past year or so. A higher labour cost input would reduce business profitability and business confidence and undermine the competitiveness of Australian industry; it would inhibit any long term advantage in promoting employment. Inflationary expectations can themselves adversely affect the economy's performance. This is the situation that now confronts us. The realisation of those expectations would be disasterous. In this context, the shorter working hours campaign is particularly ominous.

Those advocating a reduction in standard hours argue that such a move would create additional employment opportunities and would thus assist the unemployed. Those arguments are simplistic and misleading, ignoring as they do changes which such labour cost increases will cause in the aggregate demand for labour. The avenues for adverse effects on the demand for labour-namely, the impact of the initial increase in unit labour costs on inflation, international competitiveness, profitability and the desire to substitute away from labour-are so pervasive as to ensure that the supposed employment gains will not be realised. It is ridiculous to suggest that a change that would have the effect of dampening aggregate demand, shifting demand away from Australian production, and of increasing the cost of employing labour would actually stimulate employment.

Those advocating a reduction in hours sometimes argue that the cost increase will not be significant because there could be productivity offsets. Given the magnitude of labour costs mentioned earlier, up to 21 per cent, such productivity growth would have to be extraordinary. Firstly, the rate of productivity growth would have to take a sudden leap to compensate for any significant reduction in working hours and, more importantly, it would have to be sustained at this new, higher level if the reduction were not to have adverse implications in the future. Because it is clear that unions also have expectations of wage increases based on annual productivity growth then any productivity growth to offset a reduction of working hours would need to be over and above the underlying rate of growth in the Australian economy. Clearly it is nonsense to suggest that this is attainable for any large segment of the work force. The flaw in the unions' argument is that on the one hand they say that productivity growth will cover the increased costs, and on the other hand they tell us that shorter working hours are necessary to provide additional employment opportunity. Clearly if productivity were to increase to the extent that there was no increase in unit labour costs, then there would be no need to increase employment. Output could be maintained at existing levels of employment. These unions cannot have it both ways.

There is one final point about labour costs that I wish to emphasise. It is the fact that labour costs play a very vital role in whether Australian industry is internationally competitive. Any increase in the Australian inflation rate now would be contrary to world trends. Any failure to match a declining trend in world inflation would have implications for Australia's international competitiveness. This proposition can be applied to the economy as a whole or any sector of it. The continued viability of many enterprises and the extent to which they can establish export markets, depends heavily on their competitive position. This applies whether they be large corporations or small businesses. Let there be no understatement of the potential magnitude of the impact of a five hour shortening of the standard working week. It could increase unit labour costs in the industries concerned by as much as 21 per cent. The inflationary consequences of this should be clear to all.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the points that I have made form the basis of the Government's concern. If a close check cannot be held on rising labour costs then Australia's economic prospects are lessened. Because of the high potential costs involved, this applies in particular to working hours claims. If unions believe that they have justifiable claims let them come forward and have them tested by arbitration. Let them come forward and allow both sides of the argument to be put and let the result rest on merit rather than industrial might. The Government expects employers to resist industrial pressures for increased wages and reduced hours. We intend to ask employers collectively and individually to resist such claims. The Minister for Industrial Relations has written this week to three firms which are reported to have conceded shorter working hours. He has asked for details of any concessions they may have made and will be making a report to the Government on appropriate responses.

The Government is heartened by employers' general attitude to date. The Government will be supporting them in their stance with all appropriate means. We intend to approach State governments and urge them to support a resistance to inflationary pressures. It must be recognised that all governments have a responsibility in this regard. We are inviting the ACTU to sit down and talk and we will explain in detail the reasons for our opposition to reduced working hours, higher wage demands and the economic consequences of such actions. We will be taking all appropriate opportunities before industrial tribunals to advocate the need for restraint in handling wages and shorter working hours claims because of the very real implications for the national economy.

As I indicated earlier the Government's approach to the unions' campaign is one which is strongly supportive of employers who stand up to the union pressure. This is the only responsible action for the Government to take. We intend to take a number of steps to lessen the burden that industrial action over the 35-hour week issue places on companies and firms. We will be requiring Federal Government departments and authorities to act flexibly and sympathetically in connection with businesses that have difficulty in meeting Government contractual obligations because of bans, strikes and other forms of industrial action as a part of the shorter working hours campaign. Pressure will not be exerted on firms in this situation. We will be asking State governments to do likewise. Naturally, we would expect that clients of firms under industrial pressures for reduced standard working hours will also exercise forbearance in calling for the execution of contracts.

As a Government we will not be pressing for the payment of bills by firms which have been singled out by the union campaign. Equally we will ensure that money owing to such firms by the Government and its agencies is paid promptly. We will be writing to all major Australian companies urging them not to switch orders away from firms faced with industrial difficulties as part of this general union campaign. Such a response plays into the hands of a union campaign of selective bans against some but not all companies in an industry. Clients of these firms must appreciate that a united stance is essential.

We are prepared to consider other measures to support employers' resistance to union claims for shorter hours. For example, we will consider measures such as the deferment of company taxation payments where companies are experiencing difficulties and other appropriate measures which might be indicated in individual circumstances. This is an indication of the Government's resolve. The Government will continue to ensure that its own authorities resist claims for shorter working hours. We will be asking State governments to adopt a similar approach. Under the Australian system of conciliation and arbitration, organisations, such as unions, gain registration. This confers on them a number of benefits but also involves responsibilities and obligations. The unions should discharge these obligations, cease their campaign of industrial action and work within the objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

Finally, as I indicated earlier, we will make a concerted effort to bring home to the Australian community, and that includes members of trade unions who are now engaged in industrial action in support of shorter working hours, the economic reality of the situation. The economic facts of life are simple: Australia cannot afford a reduction in working hours at this time. We will be informing the public in some detail of the reasons why. Current wage and hours demands by the trade union movement represent a very serious threat to the emerging economic recovery and lessen the potential advantages that the whole community can enjoy from the exciting projects which are ahead of us in the 1980s. The Government recognises the problem and is prepared to take all necessary steps to meet it. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has put down a lengthy statement in relation to the current issue of the 35-hour week, as it is described. I want to make some fairly brief comments about the statement and to try to express some of the attitudes of the Opposition towards this overall issue. I remind the Senate that the 40-hour week was established by a decision of the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, as it then was, in 1947. I want to refresh the memories of those honourable senators who have memories about the fact that, traditionally, hours of work in this country have been set by the arbitration tribunals. In 1947 when the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration gave its judgment in the standard hours case of that year, it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been the historic role of employers to oppose the workers' claims for increased leisure. They have, as is well known, opposed in Parliament and elsewhere, every step in this direction, and this case is no exception. The arguments have not much changed in 100 years. Employers have feared such changes as a threat to profits; an added obstacle to production; a limitation upon industrial expansion; and a threat to internal and international trade relations. Steadily, first in one country then in another, this opposition has been overcome, until great institutions like the International Labour Organization in the international arena, this Court in this country, and the legislatures both here and elsewhere, have declared for the desirability of added leisure.
And history has invariably proved the forebodings of employers to be unfounded.

I do not say that that statement in all its particularity is apposite to the statement that has been put down by the Government. But it is an important historical statement on the social and commercial factors involved in the argument about increased leisure for employees which still has a great deal of truth in it. Since 1947 when standard working hours were set by that judgment of the Court at 40 hours a week, working hours have, in fact, steadily been going down. As paragraph 3 of the ministerial statement acknowledges, the consequences of those average hours going down are apparent today. The statement reads:

The Government is aware that an estimated 36 per cent of all full-time non-managerial employees are currently working less than 40 hours a week. It does not follow, however, that the economy can stand an across the board application of a 35 or even a 37 1/2-hour week to the total work force.

I make it clear that the Opposition in this place, the Australian Labor Party, is not arguing for an across-the-board introduction of a 35-hour week at this stage. It is not arguing for that at all. The Opposition is arguing that there should be discussions where appropriate in connection with industry by industry arrangements to see where and how shorter working hours can be most profitably introduced for all concerned. As the Senate well knows, and as the statement acknowledges, those discussions have been taking place in various industries for some considerable period. For example, in today's Australian Financial Review there is a very good indication of that. The lead story on the front page is entitled: 'ICI in talks with unions: 35-hr Momentum Builds Up'. I shall read a little of that article which states:

Major chemical, fertiliser and fibre manufacturer, ICI Australia Ltd, has begun negotiations with the Chemical Workers' Union over the introduction of a shorter working week at the company's plants throughout Australia.
An ICI spokesman said yesterday the Federated Ironworkers' Association and its chemical workers' sub-branch had approached the company over recent weeks . . .
The ICI spokesman is then reported in the article as saying:
We have indicated we are prepared to discuss a gradual reduction in working hours so long as a number of conditions are met, including off-setting costs with productivity increases.

The article goes on to state how many workers would be affected by that decision of ICI if the discussions which the company projects it will have with the unions, in fact, result in a reduction in working hours. One matter about this Government which I have the greatest difficulty understanding is the commitment-I would say a blind ideological commitment in many areas-to what it calls market force arrangements except where, of course, market force arrangements do not suit for particular reasons. For example, in the famous speech of 5 December 1980 so eloquently read by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, in Adelaide, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:
I refer rather to a system-
He was talking about the private enterprise system-

which, while recognising the necessity for restraint and a degree of Government intervention, is premised on the belief that what produces the best economic and political results is an economy based on private property and income, in which normal economic activity consists of commercial transactions voluntarily entered into by individuals and groups.
I take it that the Government will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —God save us.
—I hope he will save you, Senator.
—What choice is there when you are losing $20m? Good heavens-market forces!

—Senator Walters began her lengthy interjection by asking God to save us. I hope he does that for her. I think Senator Walters should direct her request in a more specific way rather than trying to embrace the rest of us. The point I am making simply is that whatever Senator Walters has to reveal about the motivations behind the ICI decision-and I am sure she will have something very profound to reveal-the fact of the matter is that I just quoted from a statement made by a spokesman for that company on its view of the reduction of hours in its industry. Of course, it is not an isolated view because, as the Minister's statement points out in the paragraph to which I referred, that a very substantial portion of the Australian work force is now working 36 per cent hours less than 40 hours per week.

SPEECH.PARA: The ICI matter to which I refer does not have any sort of revolutionary component. It is just consistent with a process which has been happening for a long period. The Opposition sees the important question in this case as being one of determining how lower hours can be most profitably introduced for all concerned on an industry basis. There are two elements, of course, in all of this. The first element is whether the Government believes-as it continually says it believes-in the operation of market forces in these matters and in the rights of companies to determine their own positions about these matters. I suppose Senator Walters is going to tell us that ICI has been stood over by somebody or other.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I suppose she is going to tell us that. Perhaps Government members can tell us whether the Government was stood over when it reduced working hours in the Australian Public Service. It should not be reprehensible for ICI and not reprehensible for the Government, Senator Lewis. But, coming back to the statement, it points out that there has been a steady reduction in working hours in a substantial portion of industry.
—I like your market forces.

—The second point I make, which I have no doubt will appeal to Senator Walters, relates to the question of who will determine the matter of working hours and the reduction of working hours. At the end of the statement the Minister has brought down there is a very interesting passage to which I will refer. It relates to both the role of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the essential question of who determines what hours and working conditions should be. At page 15 of the Minister's statement, which he read a few minutes ago, the Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: If unions believe that they have justifiable claims let them come forward to have them tested by arbitration. Let them come forward and allow both sides of the argument to be put and let the result rest on merit rather than industrial might.

Of course, the whole burden of the Government's case rests on industrial might. Is the Government seriously saying that in relation to the Altona decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, this particular one.

—If Senator Hamer really believes that every time a consent award is obtained it is a result of the exercise of industrial might, he has a very dim view of employers in Australia which they do not share.
—I did not say that. I said: 'This particular one'.
—That is the implication of what he said.
—They said they would stop having demarcation disputes if they got this reduction. Isn't that blackmail?

—I should have thought that that was a normal commercial transaction, in Senator Lewis's terms. Let me proceed with the point of who determines the question. Referring to the quotation which I just made from the speech, it is said that these things should go to arbitration and be determined by arbitration and the merits of the dispute should be dealt with there and judged accordingly. Why did the Minister say that if what Senator Lewis is really saying by way of interjection is that the arbitration system is a farce?
—Not at all.

—Senator Lewis is saying that by way of interjection because, when I referred to a decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, he said: 'Ah ha, that is not a real one because the unions applied industrial muscle of some sort to obtain that decision'. That is what he is saying by way of interjection. On the one hand, the Government invites the unions to go to arbitration and then, on the other hand, when they go to arbitration, Senator Lewis says by way of interjection here, totally contrary to the Minister's statement: 'That is not a real thing to do because the arbitration decision is affected by industrial action'.
—That is not a determination.

—Of course it is a determination. It is an award and a decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Commission is in no way bound to certify consent agreements. What sticks in the Government's craw-it will not admit to this fact-is that 36 per cent of the Australian work force has it at the present time and there is nothing abnormal about the Altona people going to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and asking for a consent award because it has been happening for years. As usual, in regard to industrial relations, the Government thinks it can make a big political stick out of huffing and puffing about it and carrying on as though everybody said that there should be a 35-hour week for every worker in Australia tomorrow without any consideration of that question by the Commission and so on.
—What does Mr Dolan say?

—What Mr Dolan says, if Senator Walters reads what Mr Dolan says, is that the process of discussion with employers should continue to take place and that the matter should then go to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is all he said.

—What does the Australian Labor Party say about referring the matter to the tribunal? You have already said that in 1947 the 40-hour week was a determination of the tribunal. Why should not the 35-hour week be a determination of the tribunal?

—Because of very different factors which apply. It could not be said in the 40-hour week case of 1947 that a significant proportion of the Australian work force-namely, 36 per cent-already had the 40-hour week. It could not be said at all--
—What has that got to do with it?

—It has a lot to do with it in terms of equity. Senator Lewis, who makes more noise than anybody else and who works for about six hours a week, according to my observations, is in here complaining about a 35-hour week in particular industries determined by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is not an appropriate consideration. The point I was trying to make before I was interrupted by Senator Lewis and others is simply this: The Government invites unions to go to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
—And a very fair and proper approach that is, too.
—Then you will not accept the umpire's decision.

—My next point, if I may refer to it without the assistance of Senator McLaren, is that it was only yesterday in the Senate that the Government repudiated the invitation in today's statement to go to the umpire to get a decision. When the public servants went to the umpire and got the decision the Government rejected it.
—It is not a question of hours under the traditional system determined by the Tribunal.

—Senator Lewis may make all sorts of distinctions as much as he likes, but the fact of the matter is that the Prime Minister of this country has continually exhorted people to go to the arbitration system. The Minister, in reading this statement to the Senate today, again exhorted people to go to the arbitration system. I remind the Senate of the Prime Minister's invitation of 6 July 1979. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I again ask all working men and women to stand up for your own rights.
That is a good invitation. He continued:

You can support arbitration-that is your right. You and your workmates can see that the union also supports arbitration. There is no need to strike. No need to disrupt work. No need to damage yourselves, your industry or Australia. There is a better way-conciliation and arbitration-the way of the umpire. Australia needs your support.

That invitation is repeated, as I said, in Minister Peacock's statement in the House of Representatives today and in the statement made in the Senate-'go to arbitration about these things and you can get the umpire's decision'. The implication of it is that the Government will support them. It is now well established that if the decision does not suit the Government there will be no forthcoming support. What happens when the unions or the employers go to arbitration? The arbitration system hears from all parties. It heard from the Government in the Altona case and it heard from the unions and the employers. It made a decision which co-incided with the views of both the unions and the employers and it made a decision which in that case rejected the view of the Government. That is the thing, I suppose-if I may use the expression which I used before-which sticks in the craw.

What I say on behalf of the Opposition is that this matter of the reduction of working hours should be treated in Australia as it has traditionally been treated by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If the Government, being capable as it is of participating in the system of putting arguments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, reaches the point of agony where it can no longer abide by the decisions of that tribunal, it has to do something about it as a government. It has to take the matter right on board and decide what it will do as a government if it regards the arbitration system as a suitable scapegoat for all its inadequacies, which is what it has done for years. If it does not like the system that much, it is in its power to do something about it. But while we have the system and the umpire and while the Government talks about the virtues of the umpire and continually exhorts people to abide by the umpire's decision, so should the Government.

The question of working hours in this country has traditionally been determined in that way and it should continue to be determined in that way. In the Altona case the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission acknowledged that reduced working hours can improve productivity in industry. If the Government disagrees with that view it is capable enough, presumably, to argue it in the Commission. The Government's argument on the adverse economic impact of the 35-hour week is weakened if shorter working hours in fact are introduced where the adverse economic impact is least. Let me say-I express a totally private view about this; I am not speaking for my party, necessarily-the adverse economic impact of a shorter working week is certainly different in many small country towns from that in the major cities. That is my view. They are factors which I believe the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should take into account in determining the reduction of hours in particular industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for luncheon, we were debating the 35-hour week, as I recall. I was trying to make the point that the issue of hours in industry has traditionally been solved by arbitration tribunals and that what we are suggesting is that in this case, when the situation is that 36 per cent of the Australian work force already enjoys reduced hours, in respect of the balance it is essential that there be, if I can put it in these terms, attitudes of mutual respect and a willingness to listen, to understand, to reason and to discuss in an informed way. Those attitudes cannot be created by any party's industrial relations policy, as the present Prime Minister once put it. The question of hours should be determined, as has been suggested, by discussions about the way in which reduced hours could be implemented in particular industries, about the factors which militate against the economic desirability of reduced hours in particular industries, and so on. That seems to us to be the important point-that the Government should really make up its mind whether it accepts the arbitration system as the appropriate vehicle to deal with this or whether it is suggesting that there should be an alternative approach. In inviting the unions to go to arbitration, there is a recognition, one would hope, by the Government that, if that process happens, the Government would accept that decision.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the factors which has to be taken into account is the adverse economic impact which allegedly would follow from a reduction in working hours. That is a factor which has to be weighed in the balance. It is not possible for a government to determine in respect of every business and industry in this country whether shorter working hours will have an adverse economic impact. It is quite possible to say, as I believe the Government to be saying, that an across-the-board reduction in working hours would have an adverse economic impact, but it should be assessed in terms of merit in respect of each industry to see whether that adverse economic impact is likely to follow.

A number of things in the statement put down by the Minister call for particular comment. The statement really amounts to a sort of attack on any activity by trade unions-an attack induced by a degree of intoxication obtained from a recent opinion poll. I want to say a word or two about that opinion poll. If we look at a sample poll anywhere in Australia, I think we will see that it is a reality that many of those who pronounce on this question are in receipt of reduced working hours. The greatest opponents of reduced working hours are to be found amongst those who already enjoy them. Even amongst those who are not enjoying reduced working hours, there are many who would say: 'Yes, reduced working hours are appropriate for me but totally inappropriate for the fellow next door'. I think that is a reality of the formation of public opinion on such matters. The statement amounts in effect to something of a tirade, if I can use that expression in a not unkind way, against any improvement in working conditions and against union activity related to those conditions, which is quite a popular catch cry but which is an insufficient analysis of the relationship between a claim for reduced working hours and the alleged economic consequences.
One particular point in the statement to which I want to refer is the Government's commitment which is expressed in these terms:
The Government's primary economic objective is to promote a growth in the standard of living of every member of the Australian community.

I find that somewhat strange used in an argument relating to the discussion of working hours in the context of a situation in which a very substantial majority of people enjoy reduced working hours. If the Government has that commitment to promote a growth in the standards of living of every member of the Australian community, if I might say so again without unkindness, it is not doing very well because the standards of living of the community depend on a number of things which are in turn dependent on government activity. For example, they are determined by such questions as the provision of comprehensive and adequate health services. In the sense of the Australian work force they depend upon such questions as industrial safety, industrial health and relationships between employers and employees-all matters to which the Jackson report on manufacturing industry devoted a lot of attention five years ago now and, as a consequence of which, nothing has happened in terms of what this Government has done to improve standards of living, in the industrial sense, in the work place sense.

The standards of living of every member of the Australian community are dependent on housing, for example. This Government has an extraordinarily bad record in relation to housing, which is now developing as a crisis situation in Australia. The standards of living of the Australian community are dependent upon the disposable income available to families. Let me just say very briefly on that score that the average Australian family is statistically and undoubtedly in fact worse off as a result of this Government's policies than it was previously. It is at least $16 to $18 a week worse off-paying more in real terms in respect of taxation. For those on incomes over $700 a week income tax has fallen, but for all those below that income taxation has risen. The burden on pay-as-you-earn taxpayers has increased under the present Government. The Government has failed to index family allowances, which has resulted again in an erosion of family disposable incomes by $3.70 a week. The introduction of family allowances was a great achievement-the only one that comes to mind-of the Fraser Government. But in terms of living standards five years later, it has become something of a meaningless initiative.

The fact that the average family now has to pay $7 a week more in health insurance payments than in 1975 to get some level of cover again represents a substantial erosion of the standard of living of every Australian. There has been a cut in disposable income in terms of award wages for PAYE earners. The one income family with four dependent children, and a breadwinner bringing in $160 a week, is now about $25.40 a week below the poverty line. Some people talk of two million people in Australia living below the poverty line. I appreciate Senator Chaney's nod-we could have all sorts of arguments about that-but I do not think the general conclusion, which is supported by the figures on taxation, on health insurance costs, on the erosion of family living standards, and so on, is inconsistent with that figure to any extent. The position of people under the age of 18 on the unemployment benefit has been eroded considerably. There have been changes in the level of average weekly earnings.

Pensioners living in rental accommodation have suffered a deterioration in their economic situation as a result of the policies of this Government. One could go on and on about these sorts of things. As I understand it, the Australian Bureau of Statistics January income survey showed that in 1979 one million households-single income earners-had an income of less than $67 a week. That is about the equivalent of an overnight allowance of a member of this Parliament but it is the disposable income of some one million households or families in Australia. So when the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peacock) in this statement about the hours of work in the Australian community talks about the Government's objective of increasing living standards in Australia for every Australian and says that the 35-hour week proposition is an attack on the capacity to improve living standards, that may have a grain of truth in it but it is obfuscating the issue in terms of the changes in family living standards which have taken place in Australia in the last five years. So there are a number of rationalisations, as it were, of the Government's position in this statement which do not bear much examination.

The other thing which I find extraordinary about this statement is that not once in the whole statement is the question of technological change and its impact on the work force mentioned. I appreciate that there are all sorts of views about whether the provision of shorter working hours is the best and most appropriate solution to unemployment induced by technological change. There are all sorts of arguments about the question and I do not for one moment pretend to have all the answers, but let me say this: There is very widespread anticipation by the Australian community as to one of the solutions to the impact of technological change. Many solutions such as job sharing, part time employment, various forms of short shift work arrangements and so on are suggested in a society where the work force has technology impinging on its potential employment on a daily basis. One of the solutions to the problem of unemployment induced by technological change which is frequently suggested and widely discussed in the community is the question of shorter working hours. I find it quite extraordinary that a Minister for Industrial Relations can bring down a statement without any discussion of the arguments relating to that matter because the discussion within the community is very widespread.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a serious omission.

—It is a very serious omission; a thoughtless omission, Senator. As honourable senators who discuss these issues with people in the community will know, a lot of people are very anxious and concerned about the impact of technology on the work force and shorter working hours is one of the solutions which is frequently proffered. This is something which, if I may say so in political terms, the Government has running very strongly against it because in a quite sincere and anxious way people are looking for the solutions to unemployment induced by technology. That is, as I say, one of the solutions which is frequently popping up and the statement should have dealt with that argument. I do not know whether the argument that the ultimate consequence of reduced hours would be a greater sharing of jobs in the Australian community is right or wrong, but it is a matter which concerns people gravely and which should have been discussed by the Minister in what purports to be such an important statement.

SPEECH.PARA: In the statement there is a lot of talk about the adverse economic effects of an across-the-board introduction of the 35-hour week. These are matters which, as I have tried to indicate, in my view require some degree of expert determination rather than off-the-cuff, kerbside opinions. Of course some of the important questions are also associated with the method of introduction in terms of our society's being a predominantly urban society. I take the view that a reduction in daily working hours from eight to seven is not necessarily beneficial to either the employer, perhaps for economic reasons, or to the employee in terms of social reasons. For example, many people in most large urban conglomerates in Australia have to spend an hour and a half getting to work. It seems to me that work organisation could be far better arranged in the context of reduced working hours than by just reducing the daily hours from eight to seven; for example, by the introduction of a nine-day fortnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —A shorter working year.

—A shorter working year, or a shorter working life or a four-day-week, or something of that kind may be a more suitable way of providing for increased leisure in return for productivity increases in a particular industry. But none of these things can be determined by kerbside opinions about the issue. They are matters of assessment which ought to be made by a competent body which we suggest would be the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-the umpire in the Prime Minister's rhetoric. I know that the statement alleges that first of all the unions should go to the umpire on this issue and secondly, the umpire was not any good because he was stood over by union industrial action, but you cannot have it both ways. You have to decide whether you go to the umpire and accept his decision--
—Go to the umpire about a $20m loss.
—I do not know what the $20m loss is, Senator.
—That is Senator Walters' company losses.
—I was going to suggest that it was a private hospital or something like that. I do not know what Senator Walters is referring to.
—I did not think you would understand it.

—Thank you, Senator. Certainly the Minister's statement does not refer to any $20m loss. Maybe Senator Walters has some private information which she can give to the Senate as part of her civilising and informing mission which she carries out here from day to day. But I am unable to respond to her interjection because I think it falls very much in the realm of speculation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me reiterate one final important point: Insofar as the Opposition is concerned, we are not saying that there should be a blanket introduction of the 35-hour week immediately. What we are saying is consistent with the position adopted by the Australian Council of Trade Unions-that there should be continuing discussions about how shorter hours can be more profitably introduced for all concerned. We believe that the process of a shorter working week is irreversible; that it will take place; that it will provide some solution to some of the work force problems which we presently have in Australia and which the Government refuses to address its mind to; and that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is the appropriate body to deal with these claims because it does so on the basis of information before it rather than on the basis of, as I have said, kerbside opinions. The statement is deficient in that it fails to analyse in any way some of the wider issues which are concerning the community and causing a great deal of anxiety, particularly in relation to the implementation of technological change in Australia. The statement is highly deficient. It is strong on rhetoric and strong on arguments which it hopes will appeal to sections of the Australian community. Because of the operation of market forces in this country-an expression on which I think Senator Walters has some sort of copyright and does not like my using-and the operation of the industrial relations system as it has been established and applauded by this Government over many years there will, I think, be a gradual reduction of hours. The Opposition hopes that it will come about in a sensible way which is beneficial both to the employees in industry and to the industries themselves in terms of economic impact. That, of course, can be done only on the basis of informed discussion and inquiry. We commend that course to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in this discussion on the Government's statement made by Senator Chaney, the Minister for Social Security. Having listened to Senator Button for some time I see a real ray of hope. I believe that the approach that Senator Button has taken is basically responsible. It is certainly along those lines that the Government is projecting its views on industrial relations. Anyone knows that industrial relations are enormously important to this country. It is wholly appropriate that they should be approached and finally resolved through a proper legalistic institution such as the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It must be said, though, that the industrial legal body must not be approached as a result of massive industrial action and disruption. That sort of thing tends to destroy the real view of people and tends to destroy the accent on the real element concerned. That real element, I believe, was revealed when Senator Button referred to the judgment of 1947 when the 40-hour week became law in this country. He remarked that in this judgment there was reference to the need for more leisure.

SPEECH.PARA: On the surface and, indeed, in fact, no one would dispute that leisure is a very important part of the lifestyle of all Australians. The point that the Government would take would be that the economy's capacity to provide circumstances in which leisure can be increased would be significant. In 1947, apparently, the time had come when that was so. We believe that at this moment that time, in the main, has not arrived. We believe that this country is, for a whole host of reasons, facing a reasonably exciting future. We should be developing a determination and enthusiasm to exploit the circumstances that confront us. There is only one way that the people of this country can fail to enjoy the benefits of those circumstances, and that is if we fail to recognise the economic reaction to certain proposed happenings.

The introduction of the 35-hour week has been discussed over a long period. I believe the discussion dates back to about 1963. I do not think any Australian would deny that before the 35-hour week can be responsibly introduced in any industry, and certainly not across-the-board, the results of it on the community's capacity to establish and enjoy leisure have to be analysed very closely. I believe that this is the real value of the statement that is before us today. One of the advantages of a democracy surely is that people can freely analyse the facts and influence the course of events. The course at this stage, I believe, must be closely related to events. This statement give a background to and knowledge of facts, a reaction to facts and the results of facts which must be analysed by all Australians responsibly and sensibly if they are to come to a conclusion of what way they are to turn at least in the next decade.

It has been clearly indicated that Australia's opportunities in the next decade and beyond and her performance to this point are matters that should be developing enthusiasm and not despair. Despair can only come if we take an unrealistic approach to the facts around us. All we ask is that the facts around us in this economy should be properly analysed and that the appropriate authorities, in this instance the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, should be allowed to develop a view of their own that is relative to the economic capacity of this country to provide the sorts of things that Australians, whether union members or not, require and desire. We have every opportunity of achieving those things. I honestly believe that there is only one way in which we will not achieve them and that is if we continue to develop a form of confrontation. If we continue to see a circumstance in Australia whereby negotiation is the result of industrial disruption which has, in the case that has been discussed in this chamber today, resulted in a company or a number of companies losing about $20m there will be a reaction of despair. We cannot afford for that sort of thing to happen.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has an enormously important task to perform. Its industrial relations record is the envy of many countries. It is our duty to see that it performs its task relevant to the circumstances that surround it and is not impressed by pressures from one side or the other. My problem lies in the fact that some of its determinations and ratifications are due to a circumstance not of enthusiasm and determination but to a circumstance of despair. I believe we have to avoid that above all things.

In passing, I refer to Senator Button's comment which sometimes comes from certain areas of the community and of the political world, that Australia is in some significant poverty. He referred to the common figure, not classically identified, of some two million people being below the poverty line and so on. I want to make it clear that my experience and the experience of many Australians is that the tens of thousands of us, from the very young to the quite old, who travel to the four corners of the globe every year-many are on four weeks' leave or whatever-come back to this country convinced that Australia is certainly the best place in the world in which to live. I believe that we want to keep it that way. One of the significant ways we can do this is to maintain in our industrial relations, a sensible and constructive discussion before the appropriate bodies and to abide by their decisions.

Some comment has been made in this debate today on the fact that 36 per cent of the Australian work force is already working fewer than 40 hours a week. The assumption arising from that somewhat bland statement is, that therefore, 100 per cent of the work force could work less than 40 hours a week. I know from what Senator Button was saying that he does not believe that. He said quite distinctly that we are not talking about an across-the-board reduction to a 35-hour week. I was happy to hear him say that because it is an important basis in the discussion of the whole industrial relations situation.

Let us remember that a very significant part of that 36 per cent of the work force is working outside the controls, as it were, of the Federal Government. Some of those workers would come under the State awards. Indeed, in my State of New South Wales, the working week of power industry workers, and the working week of workers in other industries, has been reduced to 37 1/2 hours and then to 35 hours. The degree of productivity and the cost of power to the community are disastrous. We cannot afford to allow this situation to continue. This is the very sort of thing that, in the longer term, will increase the inflation rate which presently is running down and is one of the best in the Western world. Unemployment will be increased and productivity reduced. Of immense importance, it is the sort of thing that will destroy our competitiveness as a nation in the international scene.

Australia has one hope of real survival as a great and affluent community and that lies in its capacity to develop on the international scene. By the very nature of our production, techniques and skill and our geographical remoteness, we are dependent on our capacity to achieve, maintain and develop markets overseas. If our industrial circumstance is such that we tend to increase the cost of the labour unit and diminish our productivity per unit, which has to happen if we increase the labour unit cost in this case by either 15 or 21 per cent, our international competitiveness becomes a very great problem and the affluence of every Australian is in jeopardy. I believe that we must be aware of these perils and adjust our negotiations in the industrial relations field with a real reference to the capacity of this economy to afford the lifestyle and leisure which we ultimately aim to achieve. We know that at this time we have between 5 per cent and 6 per cent of the work force unemployed. Fortunately, the inflation rate has been reduced from 15 per cent or 16 per cent to 9 per cent plus. We are on the right economic track in terms of the Western developed world. We are one of the most successful countries in that area. We want to make sure that we keep it that way. Of all the things that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has said, I believe I need quote only one point which it made in the national wage case decision of 9 January this year. It stated:

Costs to the economy rising from stoppages and bans threaten not only improvements in real wages and conditions but even the maintenance of existing standards. This is not a moral judgment but a matter of hard economic reality.

I believe that those words are unquestionably true. If, indeed, they become the real and effective basis of negotiation between employers and employees through the process of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, we are not only on the right track but also we will remain on the right track.

I want to refer in some further detail to the fact that the Government is not opposed to a 35-hour week concept per se for ever and in all circumstances. We are immensely concerned to see that this great community does not dive into an economic circumstance which would ensure loss of productivity and increasing unemployment. We do not want to see ourselves dive into that circumstance by too rapidly or irresponsibly entering into a 35-hour week arrangement regardless of all those basic things that need to be considered. I hope and believe that the trade union movement will concur with this. Let us move into a discussion for a final evaluation of how we go, when and to what extent, through mutual consideration of those economic terms referable to the capacity of the economy to provide the sort of lifestyle that I am sure all of us want and, in some real measure, already have established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where has the Government indicated that it would sit down and talk with the unions? I agree with you.

—Certainly the Government, through the National Labour Consultative Council and other bodies, is determined and keen to talk. On some occasions it has been disappointed by the fact that the trade union movement has seen fit not to come to the Council. Of course, there has to be consultation between all the parties concerned. We would be the first to recognise that. There has never been any suggestion that it should be otherwise. We are concerned when decisions are the result of industrial pressure. For example, companies, out of sheer despair, may come to an arrangement with the trade union movement outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission area. The Government is concerned about that and I think that all genuine Australians would be concerned about that. The parties should talk to each other in the appropriate field and arrive at a sensible and responsible attitude. That is how things should be. The danger is that this sort of thing could happen as a result of disruption. Indeed, the Minister for Social Security has indicated to me that, on page 16 of the statement, the following interesting words, appear:

SPEECH.PARA: We are inviting the ACTU to sit down and talk and we will explain in detail the reasons for our opposition to reduced working hours, higher wage demands and the economic consequences of such actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a one way process.

—I think the honourable senator is reading that into it. It means exactly what it says, that is, that we are inviting the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as indeed has been the circumstance in the past through the National Labour Consultative Council, to talk and to look at the proposition and the matters that confront us. That is the very matter that identifies the Government's approach in this circumstance and that is the matter that identifies the value of this statement that we are discussing.
—Then you will agree that we should share productivity?

—Productivity is referable to the general affluence of the whole of the community. One of the problems of a widely distributed 35-hour working week in a sudden circumstance is that productivity would be at risk.
—Do you agree that when there is some productivity increase it should be shared by the labour force?

—If productivity increases only to the extent that costs increase it leaves one in the same position, so we have to examine these circumstances very carefully. Of course productivity is important. That brings me to a further matter to which Senator Button referred and which is equally important, that is, the advent of technology and the effect of these sorts of constant escalations in the wage system, the labour unit cost system, on technology. The effect is to bring technology into our community, into our industry and commerce, at a much greater rate than we are capable of absorbing it. We have to examine the consequences of that with very great care.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great challenge in this country to adjust our education system in such a way that we are producing people with the sorts of skills that are necessary to develop the sort of technological change that is inevitable. I believe that one of the problems of the past five, six or seven years has been that we have hastened into technological change basically, I believe, in part because of bad management and in part because of the enormous escalation of the costs of labour without any view being given to ultimate and real productivity. We are in the danger that we are in today partly because we rushed into it to that degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you use technology in a particular industry, obviously it will increase the rate of production and therefore reduce production unit costs. Should not the work force have some benefit from that?

—I do not have any doubt that Senator Gietzelt is asking a very sensible and appropriate question. I regret that I have not the time to reply to it in detail. I shall be glad to talk with him about that matter at any time in the future. I conclude my remarks by saying that I believe that this statement is one which evaluates the circumstance in Australia today. It is a valuable statement only if Australians examine the real consequences across-the-board of the advent of a 35-hour working week, whether it be today or in 10 or 15 years. It is not a question of being opposed to the concept of a 35-hour working week; it is a question of relating the capacity of this economy on both the management and labour sides, to be able to absorb a 35-hour working week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the views which have been expounded by my leader, Senator Button. We can see by looking at the statement of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that it is a sort of cross-fertilisation of industrial myths and economic faults. Senator Scott commented that Australians with an entitlement to four weeks leave could go overseas for a holiday and make comparisons with their homeland on their return. That is reasonable enough, but what he overlooked is that every time there is a substantial gain within the trade union movement it is regarded as an economic minus. Actually Senator Scott, in one of his utterances, referred to the tourist industry. When the trade union movement agitated for and gained long service leave provisions for workers it was actually regarded as a plus for that industry. If that theory is extended to apply to the granting of a shorter working week we will find that people will certainly be more active in their social life and will spend more, which of course would result in increased returns in the retail trade and the tourist industry. I make that point because the central theme of the argument of the Government seems to be that every gain within the trade union movement will diametrically affect the overall wellbeing of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may further illustrate my argument, anybody who read a recent issue of Newsweek would be aware of the dilemma of the motor vehicle industry in the European Economic Community in the face of competition from the Japanese. We have been told many times that if we were to emulate the policies of the EEC economically and, more so, if our trade unions were to adopt the responsible attitude of the EEC all would be well. I do not question the right of Japan to compete with the EEC and Australia. The point I am making is that whenever there is a gain for the workers the trade unions are said to be wrong and that is the end of it, but trade union demands are only a minor component of the overall economic picture. We all go to the trade fairs and get the trade journals, so we would know that some State workers got a 40-hour working week in 1947 whereas those who worked under Federal awards still had a 40-hour week in 1948. That was the position over 30 years ago and we would all know about the various labour saving devices and the better tools that are used. How can government blandly say after 30 years that industry cannot afford it?

Senator Button referred to the comments of the Minister on the first page of his statement in respect of 36 per cent of the work force already being on a 35-hour working week. Let us put that to one side for the moment and subtract the residue of the work force. I do not know who prepared the statement for the Minister but he should realise that a dramatic change to the standard working week would not be a major factor. As an example, I refer to the situation in the retail trade. Recently I was talking to an official of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association. I understand that in New South Wales 50 per cent of that union's members are part time workers. Most of them put in 20 or 30 hours a week between Thursday night shopping and lunch time on a Saturday. That slab of the work force is not caught up in this issue. Senator Scott represents the National Country Party. It is very significant that the pastoral industry achieved a comparable working week with the rest of the work force less than 3 1/2 years ago. As Senator Button has said, there will be fragile areas in which the unions probably will not fight very hard in relation to the gaining of a 35-hour working week. I emphasise again, and it cannot be stressed too often, that for the part time worker in industry a 35-hour or 40-hour working week is not a major factor.

If I may return to the 36 per cent of the work force who are already on a 35-hour working week or thereabouts, the plain fact of the matter is that in the power industry persons classified as turbine attendants, auxiliary plant operators and so on are able, with technological change, to be responsible for a greater number of job operations, so the numbers in the work force have been diminished. To take my point further, the computerisation of the New South Wales railways signals system and other changes will, according to the responsible union, mean that within the next seven years the number of members will be compressed from about 20,000 to 13,000. It is not on to say to people who perform manual work that the time is not opportune for these changes. In terms of the advances made through technological change, would anybody deny what the introduction of the forklift has meant to industry? As a result, fewer manual operatives are required, whether the forklift is used on the waterfront or in the wool stores.

I turn to another aspect of this matter. Some years ago a dispute occurred in Newcastle between the Federated Ironworkers Association and the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association about the introduction of a string crane, the operator of which is not immobilised in a cabin high above the job but works from the floor. The person performing that work is used by his boss on other duties when he is not needed to operate that crane. I have my own views as to how a person in that working situation has been abused by employers. I am giving honourable senators examples of the numerous changes that have occurred in the last 30 years.

Speaking in the context of what has happened in Sydney, I call to the minds of honourable senators the emergence of the one man bus concept in metropolitan transport systems. Would anybody deny the change to that system? Would anybody deny a reduction in working hours to people who must negotiate the hazardous traffic problems that are to be found in our massive metropolitan capital cities? When we are not here many of us probably drive, in Sydney or in Melbourne, to work in the morning and home in the afternoon. The people driving these buses on a shift of 7 hours 20 minutes or 8 hours are under pressure all the time. When I first entered this Senate, I pointed out that, if we were not careful, an insidious atmosphere could be created here. I appreciate that Senator Scott, for example, did his share of physical work on his own property and gained a great deal of satisfaction from it. But we are inclined when we are elected to this Parliament to get a little high and mighty, with our well padded buttocks on the soft seats, and to talk about 'them' and 'us'. I mean that remark to be taken seriously.

We have heard reference today to the problem that a shorter working week will create for the boss. But do we ever wonder about the other areas affected?
