People like Senator McIntosh know the industries in the various States. Let us forget about the major technical changes for the moment and consider the people about whom I am worried. Let us take the case of the woman who is a semi-skilled operator of a small guillotine and who is responsible for cutting up magazines to certain sizes, and so on. She would be a member of a printing union. The boss may say: 'Next week we have a contract to do Penthouse', or some magazine like that. I mention that I have no ulterior motive in taking that as an example. I know of specific cases in which that is what contracts provide. The boss has indicated that he wants to undercut a competitor and he wants the women to work a little bit faster. Many of the women concerned would be in the age group from 35 years to 45 years. Obviously the operation in performing that work involves stepping down, picking up material all the time and so on which requires a lot of extra effort each day.

What happens in such a situation? This matter was thrashed out when we were considering in an Estimates committee the appropriations for the Department of Health. The fact is that women are employed for some 8 or 9 months in such a job and, when that job cuts out, they will go back to the Printing and Kindred Industries Union to seek another job. The stage is reached with some of those employers that they might as well be picking cattle out of different pens. If they see that a woman has prominent varicose veins, they do not think that she will last the distance. These are matters that we must face up to. The rank and file members of the trade unions see it this way. A member will say: 'I am always going to be in this industry. I think that I am entitled at least to a little bit more leisure'. That is the atmosphere today, and we must face up to it. I repeat that the unions that have achieved shorter working hours already have members who work in heat and dust and under oppressive conditions.

Some honourable senators may say to me that industry perhaps in many ways is more safety conscious now than it was 20 years ago. If we go into an engineering establishment we may see someone, using a press, who is wearing mufflers to protect him from deafness caused by that industrial occupation. We think that that is a good thing. On the other hand, in his work he is experiencing a sort of cloistered existence. The more one can reduce the period that people spend in such an area in the course of an 8-hour day, the more can be laid at rest suggestions that employers are unscrupulous in what they require of employees.

I turn my attention to the rubber industry. Let it not be forgotten that the trade unions have never adopted a Luddite attitude in any respect in regard to the cases that I am mentioning. My colleague from South Australia, Senator Elstob, will tell honourable senators that Charlie Fitzgibbon, the National Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, had many package deals to ensure the quick turnaround of ships in some of the small ports. It is true that the agreement that was reached on the redundancy of certain waterside worker members was reasonable. The settlement of that matter in one financial year meant that the size of the work force was reduced and the operations became cheaper. That sort of thing is happening in so many areas.

Let me follow that line of thought a little further. We talk about our climate and, of course, in many ways it is a nice climate. But again I remind honourable senators of what I said about our talking about these matters as we sit here on our plush red seats. We know that, when one toils in the heat and sun, various industrial hazards are present and one is vulnerable if something goes wrong. The change that is being sought in hours of work after nearly 30 years of waiting is irresistible. If we look at discussions about apprentices and work in occupations where manual effort is involved, the whole idea promoted by the media is that ones son or daughter has to get into a nice air conditioned office. This is very laudable, but I have wondered about this view at times. I am sure that Senator McIntosh will agree with me that there are people who can get nice ice-cold water in their office; they certainly would not have to lose half a day to get it. Yet one can go to industrial establishments on construction sites where for the first month workers battle to get adequate toilet facilities, cold water and other such amenities. Sometimes a stoppage will occur for a few days because of this lack.

Let me now move away from that area of consideration. A dialogue occurred involving Senator Gietzelt, Senator Scott and Senator Chipp about the intention of the Government to get some sort of a deal. I invite honourable senators to read the submission by John Halfpenny, whose political views do not always coincide with mine, to the tribunal in Victoria inquiring into the media. In that submission, he spoke about the way in which the Press sensationalises disputes. Have honourable senators ever thought that, although a dispute makes the headlines when a stoppage occurs, on other days when the union organiser goes out to a job and achieves a settlement which is not news because it is not exciting. That is happening all the time. It is important that we should remember that that happens because the impression is being created that the unions are asking for more and getting what they want while the employer is being browbeaten.

As my next example, I refer to the tyre industry. Several years ago, the Dunlop organisation decided that its plant in Sydney should be dismantled as it would be far better and more economic to restructure the Sydney operations in Victoria where Dunlop's main operations were. I do not question that tyre manufacturers in Australia were experiencing extreme competition from South East Asia and Latin America. The unions involved agreed that the Sydney plant should be dismantled. There was no opposition from the various unions. Severance pay was paid to some of the workers. When we talk about severance pay, let us not forget that in some cases this would be the equivalent of about 3 months' wages-and that money soon goes. I had an intimate discussion on this matter with the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Ian Macphee, as he was then the Minister responsible for this area. The fact is that, at the end of that year, that rubber tyre manufacturer was in a better position as a result of going to Victoria and consolidating its activities there. That consolidation was achieved with the assistance of the gesture by the unions involved. Surely that organisation now can meet whatever is the impact of a shorter working week.

Another important point arises. We have often heard it said here-it is a constant bleat-that workers in Asian countries which are our competitors are underpaid. Whether we like it or not, that was the attitude that I and others had about Japan. Frankly, reasonable amenities are provided for their workers by Japanese manufacturers. Their attitude is different from ours. Some of these manufacturers believe that the employer should provide holiday camps for his workers while in Australia we prefer an adequate holiday loading to enable people to do their own thing. A campaign is being mounted claiming that Australia is headed for economic ruin. Whether an industry is buoyant or in difficulties, the picture that I am trying to paint is the need for an equality of sacrifice by all parties. Let me illustrate what I mean. My authority for my statement is the former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Bob Hawke, who is now the member for Wills in the other place.

I have said in this chamber on many occasions that, irrespective of whether an employee receives wage adjustments quarterly or half-yearly, a vital component in wage stability and employee satisfaction is the sudden and massive fluctuations in our rag bag national health system. Workers in Europe are provided with a far better health system than ours. It is true that it is paid for in some way by taxation. The introduction of a comparable scheme in Australia in the form of a levy on one's taxable income, similar to the concept of the Medibank levy, would mean that a process worker would not pay as much as a production manager. But such a system does not apply here with the result that the worker on low wages finds that he is slugged every couple of quarters for an adjustment in contributions to the Hospitals Contribution Fund, the Medical Benefits Fund or Medibank Private. The Government felt that in this matter it would be able to bargain one factor against another. In 1976, according to the then ACTU President, the trade union movement put that concept to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

I know the Government is in a bind. These wealthy private health funds are like an albatross around its neck. They want something and they drive the Government into the ground in order to get it. I have strong views on this matter. My colleague Senator Douglas McClelland and I-with one or two others-remember the big brawl when the Nimmo report was announced. That report on national health, to put it bluntly-I believed in the national Medibank scheme-could have taken the sting away if it had been introduced. I remember talking to the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Sir Kenneth Anderson. I asked him why he did not grasp the nettle. He said: 'We have to stay this one out. It would cause too much of an upheaval'. It would have caused an upheaval with the private health funds. But there are ways of bargaining. An arbitration judge named Gallagher was appointed to the Coal Industry Tribunal. This was at a time when the miners' union award was before court. The miners had a choice between a substantial wage increase or better long-service leave. Their log of claims involved a sizable wage increase. Justice Gallagher decided that rather than grant union members the full financial impact he would award them considerably better long-service leave conditions. Naturally everybody did not take the long-service leave at the one time. It was probably spread over a 10-year span.

In relation to the 35-hour week, some unions will get it fairly soon while others, for various reasons, will not get it. It is an academic question for members of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association, probably the theatrical employees organisation and unions like that with a high number of part-time employees. Many honourable senators have asked: 'What of the cost factor?' I return to the idea of plucking out figures and what it means. I had not been a member of the Senate for long when there was the disastrous Mt Isa mines dispute. I say 'disastrous' because the situation was that the lead bonus varied with the world price of copper. When the bonus reached a certain stage there was a ceiling. Of course it was expected that the world price of copper would go up. I know that at the time the Australian Workers Union had internal problems and that did not help. There was a devil's brew.

I remember Senator Branson. Day after day he got up and said: 'This strike is costing Australia $1m a day'. Six months after the dispute was settled an honourable senator from this side of the chamber rose to ask a question. Of course the price of copper was booming. It was a question on notice and the Government waited another six months. We did not have anyone with the tenacity of Senator McLaren to come back and back so that we would get an answer quickly. However, we did get an answer. We discovered that the mining companies in Mt Isa-the new honourable senator from Queensland will agree with me-did not go into liquidation. They became bigger and better and stronger. The purpose of that picture is to tell honourable senators that this report is a mish mash of half truths and economic nonsense. I will be quite frank about the matter.

I sympathise with the Government in relation to where it gets its economic know-how because we had the same problem when we were in government. A lot of economists would tell us what to do. One fellow, Professor Brian Brogan, had all the answers. I assure honourable senators that the trade unions did not believe him but some other people did, unfortunately. He went to New Guinea. I think the people there were much more aware of him than we were because they hoisted him out of New Guinea. The last I read about him, it was reported that he was writing another paper on tariffs. I suggest to the Government that it should send some of those economists to on-the-job meetings. If they worked on the workshop floor they would soon be told about some of their absurd economic theories.

In some ways I am pleased that the Government has given us a chance to get our teeth into the matter. I have had over 30 years' experience and nobody can tell me that massive technological changes can be resisted in our work pattern. I suppose it may be argued that some industries will lose. Let me turn to the statement that the unions win everything. I am looking for an honourable senator from Victoria to run-off on this point. There have been several disputes involving reinstatement and the Food Preservers Union of Australia. The union has not won all the disputes. Some of the disputes have got to a very delicate position, whether or not they are winnable. I will not name the newspaper in which I read of this. The point I am making is that somebody said that the unions are like a panzer division-they win all the disputes. I suppose I would insult the Air Pilots Guild if I said that all its members were dedicated to the Australian Labor Party and the ACTU. These people are middle-class militants. These are the people with whom we are dealing. Honourable senators can tell members of the storemen and packers organisation to be patient, but I wonder how they would get on telling that to the highly paid pilots who live on the North Shore, in the electorate of Bradfield and those areas. They do not return socialists to this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume lives in Bradfield. I don't.

—That is the point I am making. I have tried to inject a certain realism into this debate. Do honourable senators ever talk to these people and ask them about these matters? I can appreciate eloquence about Australia's economic stability. But this is all about equality of sacrifice and sharing of productivity. As a matter of fact the aspect of bad management came out a long while later. Whether it was the dockyards in Newcastle or Whyalla, management was pretty slow in endeavouring to retool. It is of no use blaming this matter on the work force. The fact of the matter is that the unions have to have a share in this. I repeat that honourable senators will not stop this tide. I offer this consolation to Senator Scott: The pastoral industry did not bear the full brunt of the 40-hour week and it probably will not on this occasion. I leave those thoughts of, I hope, wisdom with the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am looking forward to participating in this debate because it has been a very interesting one and classically throws up the philosophical difference in approach of the major political parties in this country. In this Senate I have not heard a debate for so long in which the lines are drawn so far apart, in which the remarks of speakers on the Government side of the chamber are 180 degrees in the opposite direction to those of speakers on this side of the chamber. I suppose the situation provides a classic definition of the Australian Democrats. I hope I can put that view in my speech. We would fall in the middle of both approaches which were put here today. I hope I do no injustice to colleagues on either side of the chamber, but it seems to me that Labor Party senators on this side of the chamber are saying: 'We will immediately support the trade union movement for 40 hours pay for 35 hours work'. I hope that I do not overstate the view but that seems to be the position. On the other hand, Liberal Party and National Country Party senators are saying: 'We will not budge one inch from 40 hours pay for 40 hours work'. I hope that I do not overstate their position. Senator Scott was gracious enough to say that a change in working hours must come, but he did not go on to say when or what sort of machinery would be adopted to bring in shorter working hours. I will say more about that later. I think the basis of all this is the iniquitious system.
—I think you should give your own position, not everyone else's.

—The honourable senator should save his interjection because I will have harsher things to say in a moment or two about the Labor Party. The method of funding political parties brings about this kind of stance and confrontation that we have in this Parliament. Is there any Labor Party senator here who feels totally free to attack some of the more extreme militant trade unions for their outrageous demands? I do not think so and I do not necessarily blame Labor Party senators because most of the funding of the Labor Party comes from trade unions. We know that it is very difficult for the Labor Party-God knows the Democrats can sympathise with it, we being short of funds-to turn around and abuse publicly or take the side against a trade union that is contributing funds for its political survival. It is human nature. I am not being critical; I am stating a fact. Here we have Government senators whose funds, which I estimate to be approximately $3m a year, come secretly, covertly from big business and private enterprise. What view could they support other than one that would maximise the profits of big business and private enterprise?

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I think the Labor Party in this debate is properly representing the views of most trade unionists, I wonder-this is rather ironic-whether the Liberal and National Country parties are properly representing the views of business. I have not yet spoken to a responsible business person-a leader in business-who does not say straight out that a 35-hour working week is absolutely inevitable and the more quickly and easily we get to it, the better. I wish this Government would wake up to itself and start meaningful negotiations so that we can move into that situation without disputation. I just wonder about the extent to which officers of Andrew Peacock's Department will go. My unbounded admiration for Andrew Peacock is no secret, but my appreciation of the department which he administers is also no secret. I believe it to be one of the most inefficient and uninformed of the whole 26 government departments. To that extent, I sympathise with Andrew Peacock. As an aside, I just hope that the advice that the Department has given my friend about taking on the Builders Labourers Federation is sound. I wish him luck, but I think it has dug a king-sized hole for him.

Having said that, I wish to register the astonishment, the incredulity, of the Australian Democrats that in a statement of 19 pages read to this chamber by the Minister for Social Security (Sentor Chaney)-a very important statement on the subject of a 35-hour working week or shorter working hours-the words 'automation' or 'microprocessing' do not appear once. Yet we are talking about something that will affect every human being in Australia within 10 years. Automation and microprocessing will devastate the work market. They will be catastrophic for the number of jobs offering to young people in this country. I am not stating some newly discovered fact. I would have thought that today every economic lecture delivered and every textbook produced was obsessed with the one big question the human race has to face in the next decade: How will we overcome this phenomenon and still have some form of equilibrium in our society?

Need I remind the Senate again that, among others, Lord Hershfield was in Australia last year specifically to study the effects of automation on the work force in Australia. Lord Hershfield is not a raving, rampant radical. I apologise for the alliteration, Mr Deputy President. In fact, he has been granted a life peerage by Mrs Thatcher for his outstanding work on automation and in particular its effects on the work force. About Australia he said that if within the next 10 years we persist with the present way of life in our industrial and social relations, namely, a 40-hour working week, penalty rates, the sacred cow of the eight-hour working day, casual work and those sort of things, by 1990 all the goods and services being produced today will be produced by 10 per cent of the work force. He is not a raving radical. He is a very conservative gentleman-a scientist, a person who has devoted his life to the effects of automation on the work force. What the hell does that statement mean if it does not mean that in nine years from now, 90 per cent of jobs existing in Australia on this day in March 1981 simply will not be there on 26 March 1990? They will have gone.

Clearly, Lord Hershfield saw that the existence of microprocesses will create other jobs, but not to the extent of the 90 per cent lost. His estimate is that by 1990 if the situation has not changed, if we preserve the status quo, we will have 40 per cent unemployment in Australia. In that situation-with six out of 10 people being haves and four out of 10 people being have-nots-we could not have stability. That is how serious this problem is. Yet there is not one word of it in this 19-page statement. Is it because Mr Peacock does not know that it exists? Did he have nothing to do with the writing of this statement? Did the Government drag up some moron from a back corner of his Department and tell him to put together 19 pages of words which do a little union bashing and which could be presented in Parliament? Is that how it happened? Does anybody who has read this statement really believe that it is a scientific, well considered and balanced document? Whoever is the author of this statement-I think Senator Mulvihill is as puzzled as I am as to where the authorship lies-ought to be ashamed of himelf.

On the question of automation, let me just say that obviously there must be some band-aid approaches in the short term. I am persuaded that no longer can Australia have the luxury of making it compulsory for people to wait until they are 65 years of age before they can get a pension. I am absolutely persuaded that we ought to reduce to 60 years, as quickly as possible, the age at which a person may voluntarily retire and receive a pension. It should not be compulsory. I am not suggesting for one moment that we tell everybody who is 60 years of age: 'Now that you are 60 you will have to retire and get a pension'. The figures that we have obtained indicate that that proposition would not cost Consolidated Revenue a penny. The extra pensions that would need to be paid would be more than compensated for by the amount we would save in dole payments and the extra taxation we would receive.

I wish to refer to something quite extraordinary. I do not do this to try to score a point against members of the Liberal Party; I just put it on the record to encourage them to think about what unemployment is costing Australia each year. An article in the Australian Economic Review shows the actual and full Budget positions in the third quarter of 1980-81. The actual Budget outcome is a deficit of roughly $1,500m. That is the actual deficit. But if there were full employment there would be a surplus of $5,800m. Clearly, unemployment is costing Australia $7,434m a year-this year. The cost of unemployment to the nation is $7 billion. Some band-aid measures should be introduced immediately. Every unemployed person is costing Consolidated Revenue dearly. We have to look at other matters.

We must try to persuade trade unions to look at their sacred cows. I believe that sensible members of the parliamentary Labor Party have a duty to say to their branches of the trade union movement: 'Okay, we have fought for an 8-hour working day, penal clauses and casual rates, but are these things not things that we could trade off, so doing better for ourselves in the area of shorter working hours or whatever?'

I know of the historical reasons for the battle for the eight-hour working day. It was a savage battle and was won totally on humaritarian grounds and for humanitarian reasons. But that was years ago. It is no longer-or it need not be-the sacred cow that it was. The whole thrust of my speech is to suggest to the Senate that this is a vexed problem. Everything that Labor senators are saying contains a great deal of sense. Similarly, what people like Senator Scott are saying contains a great deal of sense. The answer must lie somewhere in the middle. I have done a lot of work on this matter and have discussed it with many people. I will give honourable senators an example. There are several companies in Australia which are well known to me and whose executives are well and favourably known to me. They have enjoyed a magnificent relationship with their work force. They have, in fact, introduced four-day working weeks, which means working 9 1/3 hours a day. For their workers every weekend is a long weekend. The firms pay 40 hours pay for four days work at 9 1/3 hours a day. Someone better than I am at arithmetic can work that out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-seven and a third.

—Thank you. Every weekend is a long weekend for those workers. What has happened in those organisations has been quite dramatic, and they are sizable organisations. Production has increased because of the four-day working week. On the fifth day other workers clean out the factories and repair the machines. Time is saved on starting and stopping and absenteeism has disappeared. If a worker wants to go to the dentist, he does not take a sickie; he goes on the Friday. The morale on the shop floor has improved markedly. These organisations have palpable evidence that productivity and profits have increased and that absenteeism and sinking morale have diminished.

SPEECH.PARA: To my knowledge the three schemes that I know about operate no more. Why? Because the trade unions stepped in and said: 'You should not do this. You are working more than 8 hours a day. You have offended the sacred cow of the 8-hour day'. I say to members of the Labor Party that this acts against ordinary human beings. Of course, the trade unions concerned-I know members of the Labor Party are at a great disadvantage because I know they hold in contempt the politics of people such as John Halfpenny and Laurie Carmichael as much as I do-have decimated and destroyed those arrangements whereby everybody was happy. The boss and the worker were happy, more affluent and better off. Those arrangements have been destroyed by a militant trade union for reasons I could not begin to canvass. Some people in this place would put the view that those trade unionists want to destroy the whole society. Other people here would say that they are dedicated trade unionists who genuinely believe that it is the thin end of the wedge to give away an 8-hour day. I do not know the reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is accepted as a precedent and that you could have problems in other places. That is one cautious note.
—I accept that absolutely.
—The 8-hour day has been broken down by working 9 1/3 hours a day.

—I accept that, but if Senator Mulvihill and Senator McIntosh wish to tell me that the scheme I have just outlined and explained, which they know from their own experience happens, was not a good thing for workers, I would be pleased to hear from them. I know it is difficult but I am saying that the solution to this matter is not to be found in the area of disputation. There are other and better ways. The Democrats agree with Senator Scott. We cannot move forthwith from working 40 hours pay for 35 hours work. But the Democrats have a definite time schedule, whereas Senator Scott and the Liberal Party do not. We believe that there should be an immediate move to shorter working hours. What they should be, I cannot determine. I should have thought that 37 1/2 hours would be reasonable virtually forthwith with arrangements for a reduction in taxation to compensate employers for the additional cost.
—In some industries it has to be worked out over the working year.
—Agreed.
—Ha!
—Senator Walters laughs at the most extraordinary times.
—Because the Government has to make cuts to take in your taxation scheme.
—Perhaps I pay Senator Walters a disservice. I ought to say things to her three times. She may then have a chance of understanding.
—Slowly and in monosyllables.
—That is not gallant.
—She does not command gallantry.
—She does from me.

—Senator Baume has odd tastes in many things. For Senator Walters' benefit I will repeat what the Australian Economic Review estimates as the cost of unemployment. It estimates that at the moment the actual Budget outcome will be a deficit of $1,500m. If we had full employment it would be a surplus of $5,800m. If there were some arrangement between employers and employees the Government could well come in. If employment is to be increased by the introduction of a shorter working week, which it must be, we would reduce that deficit of $1,500m. The cost to the Australian taxpayer of unemployment in this country is now $7 billion. The Democrats believe we ought to be moving towards the introduction of a shorter working week but we believe we should be moving gradually and in a spirit of consultation. I have a great affection for Senator Scott and the gentle and generous way he puts arguments. He was prompted by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) when I interjected: Why does the Government not have consultation with the trade union movement? At Senator Chaney's instigation, Senator Scott quoted the paragraph appearing at the end of page 16 of the statement, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We are inviting the ACTU to sit down and talk--
That sounds good up to that point, but it goes on to state-
and we will explain in detail the reasons for our opposition to reduced working hours, higher wage demands and the economic consequences of such actions.

With great respect to Senator Scott, that is not consultation. That is like a teacher saying to a child: 'Come in here and we will talk. I will tell you why you have been a naughty child, how you can be a better child and how you have to behave in this way in the future'. That is certainly not consultation. Proper consultation is sadly lacking in any government initiatives. The Democrats say that the only possible solution to this problem, which is by far the biggest problem facing Australia today, is consultation and negotiation. I have wondered why the unions have gone for a 35-hour week. Why not go for 37 1/2 hours? Why not go for something less? I believe they have gone for 35 hours-in other words they have gone for a big grab-because--

TALK.START.PARA: —Five times seven is 35.

—Five hours out of 40 hours is a big grab. I think the honourable senator has to be honest and admit that. The trade unions know of everything that has happened in the past. There has been a war. There has been suffering and disputation. I believe the rationale of the trade union-Labor Party mind is: 'Let us go for a big one now because there is going to be a war. The forces of reaction will build a brick wall against us. We will have to suffer by industrial disputation. Therefore, let us do that exercise only once and let us go for something big'. If, however, the Government were less stubborn and showed some inclination to consult and discuss, I believe a responsible trade unionist could be persuaded to push for his claim on a policy of gradualism. In fact, the trade unionists with whom I have spoken have accepted that idea in a flash.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed on page 6 of the Minister's statement a remark with which I agree. The bottom of page 6 reads:
Their decision--
That is, the decision of the employers-

on whether to invest in new machinery and equipment, or in new building and construction works, or to expand employment and in-plant training schemes for workers becomes far more difficult if they cannot make reasonable estimates of the degree to which such machinery, plant and work force will be idle because of industrial disruption in their own or independent industries.

I agree with that. But does any industrialist or businessman in Australia today not believe that the trade union movement, backed by the Labor Party, is not fair dinkum about a shorter working week? I would have thought that that has been spelt out with crystal clarity for so long. Does the Government really believe that if it puts people such as Senator Walters in the Senate to give a hard-line speech and say that it will not budge under any circumstances it will make the trade union leaders flinch in terror, cower and back away from their bid for a 35-hour week? Does the Government really believe that? Does Mr Fraser really believe that by, wielding a big stick and by his threat of massive unemployment caused by automation he will force the trade unions to back off? I should think that that is naive thinking, but here it is. I agree with the Minister, employers want to know what is happening so that they can plan ahead.

I do not know whether the leaders of industry who are good enough to invite me to their luncheons now to discuss these things say different things to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and to Andrew Peacock from what they say to me. But they say to me: 'For God's sake, let us get some solution to this demand for 35 hours so that we can restore some sort of equilibrium to the economy'. They know that there will be blood on the floor, nationwide, if the Government continues to be intractable. For that reason, I believe that this debate today is an important one and I am appalled that the word 'automation' does not find its way into the Minister's speech at all. I wondered at the gall of the person who wrote this speech. Is this a way to start a public relations exercise on behalf of the Government to woo responsible trade unions? I will be interested to see what Senator Harradine, as a champion of the moderate trade unionists, says about the paragraph at the top of page 9. It states:
If the unions think they have a justifiable claim, they should cease this harmful action and submit their claims to arbitration. They have not done so. They are resisting arbitration.
Here is the classic of all classics, which states:
That is not an attitude usually taken by groups who believe they have justifiable claims.

Is there any person on the Government side who can hold his or her head up and say: 'We will stand beside that statement'. I will refresh honourable senators minds as to the continuation of the debate which we had here last night on the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act and the Government's action on Determination 503. The Public Service trade unions are objecting to certain aspects of this Act. The Prime Minister, in his own words, said: 'Go to the umpire. Go to arbitration'. They did and they got a decision, Determination No. 503. What happened? The Government now is changing the rules after the umpire has made his decision, and yet here another Minister in another area of industrial relations says: 'Go to the umpire'. In such a sensitive issue with the whole nation divided on whether there should be a shorter working week, we have statements like that. I am sure the author of this paper, whether it was Andrew Peacock, a member of his staff, or a member of his Department would not have had the gall to put that sentence in had he or she known the acrimony and the bad feeling which was engendered by the Government's reaction to Determination No. 503.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Walters wrote that paragraph.
—That is an allegation that I as a gentleman would not make even against Senator Walters.
—What makes you think you are a gentleman?

—Senator McIntosh suggested that you wrote that paragraph. I am sure not even you would have been capable of doing that. On the question of productivity, Senator Gietzelt and Senator McIntosh interjected on Senator Scott who is always generous in acknowledging interjections and asked him: 'What about productivity? Is the work force not entitled to share increases in productivity?' I did not disagree with the honest answer which Senator Scott gave. I do not think he disagreed with Senator McIntosh or with Senator Gietzelt. But this statement at the top of page 8 confounds me. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government intervened in this hearing . . .
That is the hearing with Altona-
and strongly argued against the settlement. It continues to oppose the productivity bargaining concept in its application to reduce working hours.

I would like explained to me what the Government really means by that. I cannot believe that the Government says: 'Okay, if, by the results of technology or by improved working techniques or by workers working harder or more efficiently, or whatever, we have a massive rise in productivity, the work force should not have at least an equal share in that increased productivity'. To take a literal meaning of that sentence, that is what it means to me. If the Government means that it is not amused by the kind of rubbish which some trade unions have been able to introduce into work practices, and if the Government means that it rejects those practices, I would be with the Government but it has not spelt that out. I shall quote an article by Michael Gordon entitled 'The end of one man, one switch', which was published in the Age this morning. The article states:

A tradesman has to flick the switch on a machine before an operator will use it. A pencil must be put into place by a fitter before another operator will use monitoring equipment. Bolts on another machine must be unscrewed by a fitter on penalty rates before an operator will clean the machine.

They are monstrous additions to cost which I do not support. I ask the question: Have the unions been able, by weak-gutted management, to introduce those sorts of irritations into work practices, unknown to or with the acquiescence of management, and then as part of the deal for shorter working hours say: 'Give us shorter working hours or something else and we will remove those work practices'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Amalgamation would help to deal with demarcation disputes, but it was opposed. Six times it was rejected in the Senate without good reason.

—I agree absolutely with what Senator McIntosh said. I am not sure, though, whether the article which I have just quoted relates to demarcation. If it does, I would agree with Senator McIntosh. The inference by the Government is that these sorts of practices have been wilfully inserted by mischievous trade unions and built up as a type of bank in the hope that one day they will be able to go to the employers and say that all these horrible practices will be removed if they are given a rise, or whatever. I do not know the answer but what I do know is that that statement, standing naked and unadorned, that the Government continues to oppose the productivity bargaining concept in its application to reduce working hours confounds my imagination. I cannot understand it because to me it flies in the face of everything which is basic in industrial relations and, in fact, in equity.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, the Australian Democrats believe that the only kind of solution that can exist is by consultation among the three parties. To illustrate my point I will use 38 hours because it is an easy figure. I am not saying that 38 hours should be our goal in the immediate future. But if there could be an arrangement between the trade unions and the employers by which a government could say to a representative of the trade unions 'What about working 38 hours and we will give you 39 hours pay. That is a good deal because you will work two hours less and will be paid for one hour in which you do not work. It is a good deal' a trade union leader would probably say: 'Yes, that is a good deal, but my take home pay is one hour less a week, and I cannot wear that'. The Government could well then say: 'We can compensate for that by making the reduced absolute money in your pay packet buy more by reducing sales taxes or by reducing income taxes, or whatever'. In that circumstance the worker will work two hours less a week and is in approxi- mately the same financial position. I think an arrangement like that could be well received.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or you catch up with indexation.

—Please. The employer would say: 'Just a minute; the worker is doing all right out of this deal. He is working two hours less and getting the same purchasing power. What about me? I have to pay him for one hour a week for which he does not work'. Again the Government could say: 'We could abolish Division 7 taxes, we could reduce double tax on dividends and we could reduce the neat rate of company tax. Therefore, you as an employer can be compensated to a large extent'. It would seem to me that that is a good proposition. We have calculated some rough figures on this. It is terribly difficult to come up with accurate figures, but we have found that Consolidated Revenue, under such an arrangement, would be about the same, that a reduction of two hours in the working week would be brought about, that profitability and productivity would be about the same, if not higher, and that opportunities for hundreds of thousands of new jobs would be created. I have oversimplified the scheme clearly because I did not answer Senator McIntosh's interjection about indexation, but that is the kind of formula the Democrats believe ought to be on the table around which unions, employers and government should be thrashing out this massive problem of future unemployment caused by automation with bona fides, with compassion, with honesty and with some genuine desire to solve something that I believe could well be catastrophic.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the alternative? The alternative is what we have seen here today-a view put by this side of the chamber and the trade union movement and an entirely opposite view put forward by the Liberal Party and the business world. There will be confrontation and there will be disputation. Who will suffer? The answer is: Everybody. To me that is the only other alternative. That is why we are pleading with both sides of the argument to come to the negotiating table and to realise that in confrontation there are only losers and no winners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agreed with one thing in Senator Chipp's speech; that is, he said he had great affection for Senator Scott and for the gentle way in which he put his argument. It is a pity that Senator Chipp does not emulate his friend. Senator Chipp seemed to be rather bright, in that he debated an honourable senator's speech in this place before it had been made. It is the first time that I have heard an honourable senator pick up and debate a point from the speech of an honourable senator who is following him in the debate. He assured the Senate that I would take a hard line in this debate. He must have tremendous insight! But it is a long time since he was on the Liberal back bench industrial relations committee and perhaps he is a little out of touch. Employers have not come to us and said: 'The sooner the 35-hour week is introduced the better'. As I said, I think Senator Chipp may be a bit out of touch. We are debating a ministerial statement made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). It follows the latest move by Mr Justice Williams to grant a 35-hour week to 840 workers at the Altona Petrochemical Co. Ltd. Mr Justice Williams, following his judgment, is reported in a newspaper to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: In considering whether we should give our approval we have taken into account all the terms of the agreement, including those portions designed to improve industrial relations.
I believe the crucial part of his statement is 'including that portion designed to improve industrial relations'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth having, isn't it?

—That is one of the cruxes of his decision; the whole decision hinges on it. It has been said many times that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission engages in conciliation and sometimes emphasises conciliation more than arbitration. It realises that unless it makes a decision that the unions will accept, the unions will just continue to strike; they will not accept the decision put down by the Commission. Therefore, the Commission bends over backwards and says: 'We will make a decision that the employees will accept'. Senator Button told us that his interpretation of market forces was the same as ours. I can assure the Senate that his interpretation of market forces emphasises the forces issue alone and leaves out any marketing. Over the 18 weeks of strike action Altona lost $20m. It then goes to arbitration and says: 'We need a decision'. Is it any wonder that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, bearing in mind Mr Justice Williams' comment that the Commission is looking at industrial relations, comes down with a conciliation decision that a 35-hour week should be granted to the 840 men? If I were ICI Australia Ltd, I would certainly be looking at that judgment and I would be looking at what the Altona company had just lost. I would be saying: 'If that is to be the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, for heaven's sake let us give in now. Let us not have a loss of $20m before we give in. Let us do it now'. That is the crux of what has occurred to date.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted in the Press today that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is divided on the productivity bargaining issue. I do not know whether that is true, but we tend to keep on taking notice of what the media says. I am not surprised about that report that there must be some division amongst the commissioners. Everybody must realise that the flow-on will occur, that productivity bargaining will soon be forgotten and that everybody will want the 35-hour week. Everybody believes that there will not be any pay back and that no one will say: 'We will improve our productivity and we will work hard so that we will achieve the same productivity when working the 35-hour week that we achieved when working the 40-hour week'. We are told Mr Dolan was delighted. He has said: 'Right, we are on our way. We will now get a 35-hour week across the board'. He recognises that the flow-on must occur.

I agree with Senator Scott. I believe eventually the 35-hour week will occur; it must occur. Technological change will give us increased productivity and we will be able to come to a 35-hour week eventually, but now is not the moment. At the moment we are competing with overseas markets and the workers in neighbouring countries are working a 50-hour week or a 45-hour week. How are we expected to compete with that? At the moment we have about 350,000 unemployed. I do not think anybody suggests that an increase in the hourly rate will not interfere with inflation. If workers earn the same amount for working 40 hours as they earned for working 35 hours, there will be a 14 per cent increase in the hourly wage. That must interfere with inflation. If that occurs we will have more unemployment. It is only in the last two years when our Government has been able to bring down inflation considerably-in December last year it was below 10 per cent-that we have seen unemployment decrease. We have found that employment has increased. Unemployment has gone down. Employment is higher than it was in January 1979. Some 279,200 more people are now employed than was the case in January 1979. Unemployment fell by 19,200 in February this year. Because we have been keeping down the inflation rate, we have been able to reduce unemployment. If inflation increases as a result of the 35-hour week campaign, unemployment will increase again.

The attitude adopted by people such as Mr Dolan seems tremendously irresponsible. He obviously is concerned only with his union membership. Mr Dolan wants his members' standard of living to increase. He does not care at all about the unemployed in this country; the unions never have. As a matter of fact, I know of a case involving a union member who had been made redundant and was unemployed for a certain time. Consequently, he did not pay his union dues. When he was re-employed in the same industry, the union demanded, before he was permitted to take the job, back payment of his union dues for the period he was unemployed. I am sure that Senator Mulvihill would agree that that is not the way unions should go about looking after their members. I believe the unions should be just as concerned about unemployed former union members as they are about working members who are paying their union dues. It concerns me that Mr Dolan is quoted as being delighted about the 35-hour week decision. I honestly think that this will lead to one of the worst situations that Australia has seen. The decision has come at a time when Australia cannot afford the introduction of the 35-hour week. We will only end up with greater numbers of unemployed. The Government is interested in the standard of living of all Australians and that is why it has been doing its utmost to keep down inflation. If inflation is kept down, employment will continue to increase.

The decision of the Court attacks the basis of business confidence. Business can cope with this decrease of working hours in only three ways. It can let its productivity rate drop and allow the business run down, which is absolutely disastrous for the economy of the country, employ more people or increase overtime. If more people are employed, wages increase by 14 per cent an hour. If overtime is worked at penalty rates, labour costs go up 21 per cent. What would honourable senators do in that situation? Could they, with a business that is just making ends meet, really cope with this additional inflation?

The 35-hour week is not an isolated issue. It has been associated with large wage demands over the last twelve months. I note that wages went up 15.2 per cent from the December quarter of 1979 to the December quarter of 1980 while the consumer price index rose by only 9.3 per cent. That sort of increase along with lower hours worked would upset the whole economy of any country. The world economy at the moment is in a far worse state than Australia's. The inflation rate is coming down throughout the world. Other countries are trying to get their inflation rates down to the rate in this country. If our inflation rate starts rising again, that benefit we now have will be destroyed.

Why will the ACTU not take the claim for the 35-hour week to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? If it did so without first taking any strike action the issue could be arbitrated instead of conciliated; and that, I believe, is the difference between the two sides. The Government is asking the ACTU to take its claim for a 35-hour week to the Commission without any duress being placed on employers. If the ACTU presented the issue to the Commission without the duress of strikes and without the knowledge that an industry had had to do without $20m and if the Commission could arbitrate on the matter instead of just conciliate on it, the Government would believe that the unions really felt that they were presenting a case which had to be answered. Because the unions refuse to do so, we believe that they feel they cannot present a reasonable case which has to be answered and that they can only bludgeon their way to achieving their end.

I believe that employers will have to unite on this issue. If they do not they will be picked off one by one. Each time one section of industry is attacked I believe other sections of the industry will have to close down until the dispute is settled. One industry cannot stay viable while a similar industry is being attacked. The unions concentrate on one company at a time and this, I believe, is the basis of the whole trouble. If the employers decided that when one of their colleagues was being attacked by a union over the 35-hour week issue, they would all close their doors until the dispute was settled, I believe this would rapidly settle the issue.

The Government has decided in its wisdom to assist the employers to withstand the unions' attacks. It has decided that it will not pressure firms which are being attacked to pay their bills or to fill contracts. I hope other companies will follow that decision. If a company, because it is under union pressure, cannot meet a contract with another firm, that firm should not switch its orders to a company that at the time is working. I also note that the Government has suggested that it may defer the payment of some company tax while an industry is withstanding the pressures of unions. I believe that the unions should take note of what has been going on in the public sphere over this issue. We have had many strikes recently. Members of the public have shown that they have had enough. For the first time we have witnessed large demonstrations throughout the whole country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Carefully orchestrated.

—Senator Sibraa said that the demonstrations were carefully orchestrated. I suppose he would consider that the demonstrations in New Zealand were carefully orchestrated. Nevertheless, even if, as Senator Sibraa says, they were carefully orchestrated, that is an awful lot of people to orchestrate. Australian people have marched in the streets and said that they have had enough. Yesterday's Australian Financial Review carried an article by Mike Taylor headed: 'Public backlash worries unions'. For the first time unions are admitting that they are concerned that the public is seeing them in a certain light. Some of the more conservative unions are backing off and saying that the backlash is of considerable concern to them. Mr Dolan attributes the criticism of his style and of the trade union leadership style just to the Fraser Government. But that is rather typical. He will not take any of the blame himself. He says that the Fraser Government is putting the blame on him and that it is not his fault. Mr Jim Baird, the research officer of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, is concerned about the matter. He says that it appears that conservatism is becoming rife in the work place and that this has led to isolated incidents of shop stewards being intimidated. In other words, the union members themselves are saying: 'We will no longer put up with this radical approach by the shop stewards and our executive'. The unionists are also reacting. The unionists also marched in the streets and said: 'We, too, have had enough'. The Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia found the task of recruiting membership on the shop floor was made very difficult by the backlash from the union members themselves against the radical executive. As I said, I believe that unions should take stock of what the public is saying to them.
—The vehicle builders union is a very moderate union.
—That is right, and that union had trouble recruiting membership on the shop floor. People do not want to belong to unions when they behave in such a radical way.
—They take everything the union gets for them. They never knock back a pay increase.
—That is right, they never knock back a pay increase, even if it is to the detriment of employment figures. There are 350,000 people unemployed.
—That has nothing to do with the unemployed.
—That is an incredibly stupid statement.
—Yours is the stupid one.

—Let me put to Senator McLaren the case of a corner shop employing three men. If wages go up suddenly, as they did in the era of the honourable senator's Labor Government, what happens? The honourable senator knows as well as I do what happened then. There was a tremendous increase in unemployment. The honourable senator knows full well that extra men were sacked. The owners of the corner stores said: 'We will manage with the family. We will manage without the extra staff. The wages have gone so high we cannot afford to employ them'. In 1973 one of the Labor Government's Ministers said very clearly: 'We have over-employment in this country'. Those were the words he used.
—Who said that?

—Mr Whitlam said that. 'Over-employment' was the expression he used. He fixed the situation in one fell swoop; he created unemployment at a level that this country had not seen for years. To say that this country can afford a 35-hour week at this stage is just to compound the problems caused by the Labor Government in this area. We cannot at this stage afford a 35-hour week. I appeal to the unions to take note of the public backlash that has started in this country. I appeal to the unionists themselves to vote out those radical executive members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — How this country approaches the issue of a 35-hour week will determine the work-style until after the beginning of the next century. The last time there was a reduction in standard hours-from 44 hours a week to 40 hours-was, of course, in 1947. That was 34 years ago. The next time there is an examination of working hours, assuming it bears the same relationship to last time, will be well into the next century. I do not believe that we should apply the criteria of the mechanical age of the 1940s to our consideration of the 35-hour week in the age of automation of the 1980s. I congratulate the Government for at least bringing down this ministerial statement for debate in the Parliament. I am afraid that this is as far as my congratulations go.

SPEECH.PARA: The ministerial statement is inadequate in a number of respects but it is inadequate in two major respects; that is, it makes no mention of the issue of automation or of the social aspects which contribute to the problem of unemployment in this day and age and, secondly, it assumes that all unions and, indeed, the Australian Labor Party want an immediate reduction in standard hours from 40 to 35. In dealing with the first inadequacy, I will quote from page 3 of the ministerial statement. It states:
The Government's primary economic objective is to promote a growth in the standard of living of every member of the Australian community.
That is a very worthy objective. However, the inadequacy is revealed in the next sentence, which states:
However, this can be achieved only if the problem of inflation is overcome.

I should have thought that the Government had well and truly jettisoned that single-minded and simple approach to the problems confronting this nation so far as unemployment and work are concerned. Obviously the problems of the 350,000 unemployed or, if one likes to take the Commonwealth Employment Service figures, the 482,000 unemployed cannot be overcome only if the problem of inflation is solved. I consider it necessary for me to spend a very short time on reminding the Senate of what I said concerning this aspect in a speech I made to the Senate in, I think, September of last year. I said:

The truth of the matter so far as employment and work is concerned in Australia is not being told. Simply stated, the problem is that there are more people in or seeking paid employment than there are jobs at the same time as new job creation continues to be slashed by technological change.

That is what I said then. Unless the Government and the people as a whole realise that the problem has a social as well as an economic aspect Australia will have an unemployment rate of over one million people by the mid-1980s. The current preoccupation with economic solutions alone will not overcome the problem. That is why I say that the sentence in this statement which says that the living standards of every member of the Australian community can be achieved only if the problem of inflation is overcome is totally inadequate. It is clear that, unless we face up to its inadequacies, we will see what George Polites, the director of the National Employers Consultative Council, forecast two years ago when in referring to youth unemployment he said:

If this situation is allowed to continue for any extended period, the economic costs will pale into insignificance compared to the price we will eventually pay in terms of social, economic and political disruption and dislocation.

As I have repeated time and time again, it is just crazy to allow jobs to be destroyed by the wholesale application of automation and technological change and to force to stay in the paid work force people who have better reasons to be out of the very jobs which could be taken by the unemployed. That has been the burden of my argument, apart from the question of justice, when it comes to support for the family so that mothers who have been forced into the paid work force through economic circumstances can have the true freedom of choice to opt out of the paid work force and make way for others to enter. That is why in the context of this debate it is important to understand that perhaps there are other means of rearranging the work system which will enable persons now in the paid work force in the older age groups to phase themselves out of the paid work force so as to enable the young people to come in at the other end.

As I mentioned, the second major inadequacy of a number of inadequacies in this statement is that it assumes all unions and the Labor Party want an immediate reduction in standard working hours from 40 to 35. The Labor Party can speak for itself but the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, is on record as saying last year that such an overall immediate reduction would lead to unemployment. Indeed, the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations and former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Hawke, is not in favour of an immediate reduction in the standard hours from 40 to 35. This push was commenced in the mid-1960s. Its purpose at that time seemed to be that a period had elapsed since the last reduction in standard weekly working hours. In about 1970 the reason tended to be that a reduction would assist in overcoming the growing unemployment problem and would ensure that advances in technology would be shared amongst the work force. The validity of those reasons is open to question by various people. For example, in 1970 the number in the paid work force totalled 5,395,600 and of that number 569,000 were part time workers. In 1980 the number of people in the paid work force was 6,246,700 and of that number 1,022,000 were part time workers. An immediate reduction in the standard weekly working hours from 40 to 35 hours, if we are looking at the question of equity, would not reduce the working hours of those part-timers, whose numbers have increased 79 per cent since 1970, but would mean increased pay. So in the sense it would not significantly assist in relieving the problem of unemployment.

In considering the question of the disbursement of profits arising out of automation, it is my belief that we should not establish a privileged autocracy of the post-industrial society, as Paul Johnson described it. These benefits should be shared broadly throughout the community. In other words, why should it be that, just because a fitter works for an oil company, he should enjoy the benefit of a 35-hour week and a fitter who works for a small engineering shop is still required and bound to work a 40-hour week? It does appear to me that the attitude that there should be an overall immediate reduction in the standard working week from 40 to 35 hours is not achievable and, if it is to apply only to certain privileged sections of the work force, it is inequitable.

It is appreciated that already some 36 per cent of persons are working less than 40 standard hours. If we are looking at this question of hours, why not look at other possibilities? In this sense it is important for the Government not to assume that all unions and the Opposition are for an immediate reduction in the standard working hours per week. Let us assume that with the development since 1947 to the present date there should be a capacity for us again to have a look at the question of working hours. Under those circumstances if it is assumed that the reduction in working hours is equivalent to that of 40 to 35, namely one-eighth, then if one works that over a life span it is possible to have a retiring age of 59. This is assuming that, in general, people start their working life at 17 and conclude their working life at 65; that is a total of 48 years. Because the reduction of standard hours from 40 to 35 hours is an eighth, then an eighth of 48 years represents six years. One could have a look at that option.

It is not beyond the collective wisdom of the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Opposition and others to see whether the remainder of the work force who are now not benefiting from shorter working weekly hours can in some way benefit in the long term, for example, by this availability of earlier retirement if that is their choice. The method of funding that sort of proposal it appears to me-it is not my proposal, I am just throwing it in and virtually thinking aloud at the present moment-could be achieved in a similar way to the funding of the casual long service leave proposals in, say, the building industry. These are the suggestions which are floating around at present.

I make it perfectly clear that those suggestions ought to be examined in detail and other suggestions, which I do not have the time to make at the present moment, ought to be dealt with. This requires an understanding by the Government that it should not believe that, just because a few people down at Altona Petrochemical Co. Ltd. got a 35-hour week, this means a boots-and-all approach into everybody and when one sees a head, kick it. I believe it is necessary for the Government to establish some sort of inquiry into this question of working hours, whether it be weekly working hours or working hours over a lifetime. As I said in the beginning of my address, what we do about this subject now will determine the working patterns for the whole of the community until well into the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Lewis for being given 10 minutes to speak on this matter before the debate is adjourned. I appreciate that. What I desire to say will have to be cut short for that very reason. I thought it necessary to enter the debate because of what Senator Walters said. I thought she conveyed the impression that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was somewhat influenced or coerced by the action of the unions in that particular dispute. Let me say in justification of Mr Justice Williams, who was a Deputy President of the Commission on that occasion, that I have had a long association with him. I was operating in the Industrial Court in South Australia when he came there as a young lad representing the employers. I recall the occasion when he was eleced as Deputy President of the Industrial Court in South Australia. He said it was the first time I had met him and that I could wish him success in his occupation. He replied that he was appreciative of the fact that he had always represented the employers, but he could assure me and the trade union movement that he would be just and fair in every deliberation. I do not think he has departed from that line. He has been promoted to Deputy President of the Commission. I do not think a threat of union organisation would have deterred Mr Justice Williams from doing what he thought was right and correct and in the best interests of the industry. On that particular occasion he ratified the agreement. His duties involve settling and preventing industrial disputes. That is his job. He can do that only if he is cognisant of the proper working of industry. He cannot give an award under coercion if it is going to bankrupt the employers. He pointed out that an agreement was reached. Senator Walters read from the decision relating to the bringing about of better industrial relationships. Of course the Commission was formed for the very purpose of bringing about better industrial relationships. He stated that better industrial relationships would result in improved productivity. So the loss was not unbearable to the employer. Senator Walters told us they lost $20m. Now she is suggesting that the judge should have refused to ratify the agreement, causing them to lose another $20m rather than progressing and making a profit in their future operations. This is her concern with the employers of the industry. Mr Justice Williams in all his wisdom accepted the position that his duty was for industrial harmony. He was doing that and it was in the interests of industry to see that it progressed. We get an invitation today to carry on this struggle of dislocating industry until such time that conditions get so chaotic that employers cannot afford to resist and before the Commission makes the award. This idea is not new. I direct the attention of all honourable senators to an article in this morning's Age by Michele Nayman entitled: 'The 35-hour war is 60 years old'. This is not new. It never happened with Fraser. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: This year is the 125th anniversary of Labor Day, the granting of an eight-hour day to building trades workers. The 48-hour, six-day working week granted in 1856 was a world first.
It was a world record and Australia led the way by reducing working hours from 60 a week to 48 a week. The article continues:
The reduction of the building trades working week from 60 to 48 hours was the beginning of a long campaign . . .
That union campaign went on for some time. The article also points out:
The first 35-hour week was awarded in Broken Hill in 1921 when underground miners won their claim after an 18-month strike.
It was the forerunner of what we are now experiencing. The article continues:
All other Broken Hill mining employees continued to work a 44-hour week. One of the conditions of the agreement was that the employers could re-open the case whenever they wanted. They never did.

The Broken Hill companies have not gone bankrupt by introducing the 35-hour week 60 years ago. I will not quote what Bob Hawke, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peacock) or even what Senator Walters have said on this matter. I will refer to a lesser identity and quote what Mr Justice Beeby said. The article continued:

Six years later, in 1927, Mr Justice Beeby gave judgment in a case where the metal trades were seeking a reduction of their working week from 48 hours to 44. In support of that claim, Justice Beeby referred to the case in Broken Hill and said that it had been 'conclusively proved that the underground men on the average produced substantially more ore in 35 hours than in 44'.
Where is the loss of productivity? It took 18 months to win the right to reduced working hours and still produce more ore for the company. This happened 60 years ago? Mr Justice Beeby also said:

. . . One important feature of economic history is that improvements of conditions of employment and standards of living have rarely been the result of concerted concessions by employers. All epochal improvements of the past, the justice of which is not now disputed, have been the result of organised force or of legislation, not of voluntary concession.

We are experiencing a repetition of this situation. If the Government had any principles at all, it would take note of the statistics-not interrupt the Commission-and not stop what history has told us is inevitable. The article continues:

The big breakthrough occurred in September 1947 when the Federal Arbitration Court awarded a 40-hour week to all industries. It was the first (and last) time working hours had been altered across the board.
In all previous cases, the reduced working week had been granted to individual industries. On this occasion, in summing up the opinions, the judges said:

. . . It has been the historic role of employers to oppose the workers' claims for increased leisure. They have, as is well known, opposed in Parliament and elsewhere every step in this direction, and this case is no exception. The arguments have not changed much in 100 years.
They still have not changed. The judges continued:
Employers have feared such changes as a threat to profits; an added obstacle to production; a limitation upon industrial expansion; and a threat to internal and international trade relations.
Surely we are hearing that argument today. The article continues to quote the judges:

Steadily, first in one country, then in another, this opposition has been overcome until great institutions like the International Labor Organisation in the international arena, this court in this country, and the legislatures both here and elsewhere have declared for the desirability of added leisure. And history has invariably proved the forebodings of employers to be unfounded.

Now we have reached the stage at which unions are invited to fight until they can force the Commission, which has the responsibility to settle industrial disputes, to grant their claims. It is inevitable that this situation has come about. This Government wants that confrontation, wants to dislocate industry and wants to impoverish employers rather than give anything to the workers. That is not what I say, it is what is stated in every considered judgment of the Commisssion. The arguments used today have been used years and years ago and are repeated on every occasion that this subject is discussed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that, by an arrangement, I could enable Senator Cavanagh to speak on this matter because, as usual, he had a contribution to make which was worth listening to. I think he has exposed the travesty of what happens in industrial relations when we get to the stage where unions blackmail industry into achieving a particular result.
—It always has been.

—Yes, the honourable senator says again that it always has been. We set up the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to try to prevent that sort of industrial blackmail. What happened at Altona was that as a result of the many demarcation disputes, the companies got to the stage where they were losing so much money that they were prepared to give in. Senator Cavanagh mentioned that many years ago Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd gave in and that it did not become bankrupt. Of course, BHP did not become bankrupt. But what has been the cost to the Australian community of BHP giving into industrial disputation, instead of making arrangements to arbitrate matters properly in order to achieve a particular result? What would have been the cost to this nation of that 18-month strike that Senator Cavanagh referred to? What would have been the additional cost to the community, over the 60 years, for the steel which is produced in Australia? Nothing is free! If only members of the Australian Labor Party would realise that nothing in this community is free. If we have a 35-hour week, something has to give somewhere. What will be given? We know what will be given because we saw what happened in 1973.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1973 the Labor Party took it upon itself to introduce two changes. They were introduced without debate in either chamber and by ministerial decree. I agree that the two matters certainly should have been introduced but they should have been introduced carefully over a period. Firstly, I refer to the 25 per cent across-the-board cut in tariffs and, secondly, equal pay for women. I do not want to argue that those are not matters which ought to have been introduced over a period, but in 1973 both of them were introduced in two blows. There is not the slightest doubt that as a result of both those matters being introduced, unemployment rose 140 per cent in a 12-month period. In other words, the quid pro quo for those two changes was massive unemployment throughout Australia-unemployment that after a period of over 7 years we still have not been able to control. There is not the slightest doubt that if we mark up the cost of real wages in the community by 21 per cent-this will be the cost to employers if this change is introduced- there has to be a quid pro quo somewhere and clearly that quid pro quo will be unemployment.

Senator Button smiles at me when I make that statement as if it is not true, but he admitted it. He said that he could appreciate that the 35-hour week would be very harsh on employers in country towns. But if the 35-hour week will be harsh on employers in country towns that means that there will be unemployment in country towns and if there is unemployment in country towns there will be unemployment in smaller industries in urban areas because they will suffer the same penalty. But the Labor Party can see only the big company which discloses so many millions in profits and says that there will not be any effect on the big company. Without the slightest doubt the Labor Party is displaying the same mentality, the same philosophy, the same approach to this debate that it displayed in 1973: Let us kick these big companies which make these massive profits. But what happened in 1973 was that the companies did not suffer. They managed to pass on the cost to the taxpayers of Australia who ended up either being unemployed or paying higher prices for the products. That is what the consequence of a 35-hour week will be-either the companies will end up with fewer employees or the price of their products will rise. We are part of the world economy and we are faced with competition which is very strong from the Asian areas. Let me remind honourable senators of what the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment had to say in its report in 1979. It said:

Developing countries of the Asian region will be increasingly able to offer a greater variety of light manufactured goods in competition with Australian industries. Over the next decade many other industries including engineering, metal working and furniture manufacturing industries in Australia are likely to face an intense competitive challenge from Asia.

Can anyone really believe that those industries in Australia will be able to meet an increase in labour costs of around 21 per cent? It is clearly madness to push a labour cost increase of 21 per cent on to those people and expect them to continue to compete with Asian imports. Somehow or other we would have to try to give them massive protection; for example, by way of tariffs or some other system of quotas to try to keep those industries alive. As I say, we have the perfect example of this. Fortunately, the Labor Party was silly enough in 1973 to introduce these things wham, wham, and we are able to see what the consequence of such a stupid move was. If we were to increase unemployment in this community by another 20 per cent, imagine how many people would be unemployed. The figure would be almost unbelievable. Senator Chipp, with his heart on his sleeve as it always is, comes along and tells us--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you have to cheapen yourself every time you speak?
