—But, Senator, you do this all the time. Senator Chipp always comes along and claims to be one of the people. He wants to talk about unemployment as if he has the answer to it. But I say to Senator Chipp: You do not think your arguments through. If only you would do some research instead of standing up and telling the media what they want to hear and repeating the headlines for them. But then I acknowledge that he has not enough staff. I do appreciate that as the leader of a third party he perhaps needs more staff but he should do his research. He says silly things like: 'Well, if we cut down to 35 hours a week that will give us an opportunity to create greater employment. There will be more jobs available'. That is an absolute nonsense. Industry cannot afford the cost of an extra 21 per cent on its labour costs so how will that create more jobs? Senator Chipp has come into the Senate and told us: 'If only we could reduce the retiring age by a couple of years that would create more jobs'. Anyone-even the fellows of the ALP who have done their research on that factor-will tell him that that is a nonsense. Senator Button knows that is a nonsense. He has done the research. It just does not happen that you cut off some section of the work force and thereby create jobs for other people. The thing that will create jobs in this country will be productivity growth. What we have to be able to do is to expand our profits and to get more people anxious to make profits, to get more people interested in developing new businesses and to get more people setting up companies-to create more jobs. That is what has been happening.
—It is fantastic what you have done in the last five years, doing just that.
—Senator, you can call that out to me as long as you like. If you look at the number of jobs created--
—Be a man and answer it.

—I am trying to answer it. If Senator Chipp looks at the number of jobs created in the last 12 months he will see that the figure is in excess of 180,000. Senator Button tried to tell us last year that under the Labor Party's election proposals it would create 50,000 or 60,000 new jobs with some sort of government arrangement similar to its scheme which failed in 1975. But we created 180,000 new jobs and no one in the media has the courage to stand up and say that is what we created. They never look at the figures.
—Full time jobs, Senator?

—Yes, 180,000 jobs and it is well worth having a look at, Senator. The way to create jobs in this community is to create development, to have massive development in this community. Certainly there is no way in which any government organisation can create jobs. The Labor Party proved that in the period 1973-75 with its Regional Employment Development Scheme which even it abandoned. There is not the slightest doubt that it is the free enterprise system which will create more jobs in this community. That is what it is all about. To reduce the number of hours that people have to work in order to earn the same amount of wages would put an overwhelming burden on the free enterprise system. Anyone who analyses the period 1973 to 1975 will see that the industry was staggering so much by 1975 that it just could not continue to employ people. The way to create jobs for people is to give back to people the profit motive. If I can come back to the subject under debate--
—About time.

—Yes, I would like to come back to it, Senator Button. Let me talk about what the Government's approach to this matter is. In the first place, and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peacock) spells this out quite clearly in his statement, the Government's primary economic objective is to promote a growth in the standard of living of every member of the Australian community, not just those who happen to be working for some strong union that is able to force itself upon the people.
—You have been successful there too?

—We are doing very well with it. Yes, certainly the Government is doing very well in its object. That is shown by the actual rise in real wages in the last quarter. The rise in real wages for the last quarter of December 1980 was 15.2 per cent compared with an inflation rate of 9.3 per cent. That means that there was a real rise in wages and that means that people had more money in their pockets.
—You try to tell that to the working class.

—The working class certainly recognised that fact, Senator McLaren, because they spent very heavily during December and business was extremely buoyant right throughout Australia during December. But, as the Government says, apparently some union leaders think there is a bottomless pit into which they can dig for wage increases. Of course the ultimate result of all their digging will be further unemployment which will be to the detriment of the community. But they do not care about that. They do not care about small businessmen who will go out of business because they are unable to cope with the expenses. They do not care about the small country towns which are dependent upon small businesses to keep them alive. Of course they do not care.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government points out in its statement that a five-hour shortening of the standard working week will increase by as much as 21 per cent the unit labour costs in the industries concerned. I have made some calculations based on that 21 per cent or five-hour shortening. That is equal to an additional six weeks' annual leave. All honourable senators present must be able to remember the cost to the community of the additional one week's annual leave when annual leave was increased from three weeks to four weeks. To add another six weeks' annual leave would be an unbearable cost. That is another example of the sort of cost that would be brought about by the proposal being put forward by the unions. But the significant point is that the Government, in its statement, has said:

If unions believe that they have justifiable claims let them come forward to have them tested by arbitration. Let them come forward and allow both sides of the argument to be put and let the result rest on merit rather than industrial might.

I was fascinated to hear both Senator Chipp and Senator Harradine say that there ought to be an inquiry. What need is there for an inquiry when we have an arbitration tribunal? We have asked the unions to come before the arbitration tribunal to put these propositions but, of course, they will not. It is fascinating that Senator Button pointed out in his opening remarks that the 40-hour working week was established by the Court of Conciliation and Arbitration in 1947. He stated that traditionally hours of work have been set by the tribunal. Having said, in effect, that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should be the body which determines whether workers should have a 35-hour week, he turned away and somehow or other by a convoluted argument ended up by saying that the unions ought to be able to negotiate outside the Arbitration Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to see the Arbitration Commission as part of the inquiry as well.

—I thank Senator Harradine. He suggests that the Arbitration Commission should be part of the inquiry. I have suggested that the Arbitration Commission should be the body to conduct the inquiry. That is what the Government seems to me to be saying.
—No, it is a different thing. It says that the unions should take cases to it, and that only creates an aristocracy.

—I will let Senator Harradine have those words recorded in Hansard. Senator Button went on to say that the Australian Labor Party is not saying that there should be an across-the-board cut in working hours. If he acknowledges that there should not be an across-the-board cut in working hours, surely he is admitting that some industries cannot afford it. If he admits that in relation to some industries, let him come forward and tell us what those industries are. Let the ALP come forward and tell us which industries cannot afford a 35-hour working week. We could then have some discussion about the matter. Senator Button said that there should be discussions where appropriate and negotiations in order to introduce reduced hours where appropriate. Of course there should be discussions, but why not have those discussions before the tribunal?

SPEECH.PARA: It seems quite clear to me that the Government's request in this matter is very reasonable and moderate. If the unions have justifiable claims, let them come forward and prove them before the arbitration tribunal. It is quite clear that the unions will not come before the tribunal because they know that they can carry on the tactics of blackmail suggested by Senator Cavanagh, which have been carried out for 60 to 100 years by industrial unions. There is continual blackmail of the company concerned, the economy and the taxpayers of Australia until ultimately the company caves in and the people of Australia have to suffer because of it. I believe that the Government's view on this matter is well taken by the Minister. I congratulate him for his statement. I move:
That the debate be now adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion for the first reading of six protection of the sea Bills. The moving of such a motion enables honourable senators to speak on any topic they desire. This afternoon I wish to speak on two matters, both of which are of great importance to South Australia. One relates to the problem being experienced by the residents of Coober Pedy and the other relates to the River Murray. I received a letter dated 18 March from Mr Nick King, who is the Chairman of the Mining Committee at Coober Pedy. I am quite sure that all South Australian senators have received a similar letter. Mr King wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,
This is a submission prepared by the Mining Committee of the Coober Pedy Progress and Miners Association. We wish to bring to your attention the serious situation affecting opal miners.
Your urgent consideration and response to the matters raised will be appreciated.

It was my intention to raise this matter on Tuesday in the debate on the first reading of these Bills, but that opportunity did not arise. Again yesterday, because of the consideration of other business, I did not get the opportunity. That is why I am making these remarks now rather than doing so in the adjournment debate. I shall read into Hansard the enclosed submission from Mr King so that the Government may read it and, I hope, take some notice of the plea that is being made not only by the miners at Coober Pedy but also by the other residents and business people who live in that far flung place in South Australia, which we all know is an opal mining town. The submission reads:

Coober Pedy is facing a crisis. The opal industry is in decline. The high costs of diesel fuel and explosives have made opal mining an extremely expensive enterprise. Many miners are being forced out of the industry because their expenses are too high and not commensurate with their efforts and present prices of opal.

Because of the exorbitant prices, demand for both diesoline and explosives has fallen in the past year. Mining equipment, bulldozers, blowers, tunnelling machines et cetera are lying idle throughout the town and fields. Urgent action is needed!
Two areas are of utmost concern.

Those of us who have often visited Coober Pedy know what the miners are talking about when they refer to bulldozers, blowers, tunnelling machines, et cetera. Under the heading 'Fuel Prices', the submission stated:

The Federal Governments fuel Parity Policy is the single most important reason we are paying such exorbitant prices for our dieseline. We request the Government to urgently review the parity policy with reference to the opal industry. And then reduce fuel prices by means of subsidy.
The rise in the price per litre of diesel sold in Coober Pedy is illustrated by the following table.

The submission then sets out that, in June 1973, the price of diesel was 5c a litre with road tax exempt. In September 1974, the price rose to 6c a litre or $11 for a 44-gallon drum or a 200-litre drum, depending on whether one likes to talk in the old imperial measures or the metric measures. In September 1976, the price rose to 12c a litre. In May 1977, the price rose to 13c a litre. In May 1978, the price rose to 15c a litre or $29.50 for a 44-gallon drum. In May 1979 the price rose to 16c a litre. In December last year, the price increased enormously to 30c a litre or $60 a drum. From those figures we can see that in the space of seven years the price of diesel has risen from 5c a litre to 30c a litre or from $11 to $60 for a 44-gallon drum. That is an enormous increase. The letter went on to state:
The opal industry, structured as it is, with no control over its international markets cannot absorb such increases.
The local Caltex supplier, who in 1979 was the largest distributor of diesel in the State, reports a 45% drop in sales betweeen March-November 1979 and March-November 1980.
That is a period of just 12 months. The submission continued:

The Golden Fleece agent reports a 33% drop in sales between 1979 and 1980. The figures for 1981-so far show a further 30% drop from the equivalent period in 1980. The drop in sales is indicative of the effect that fuel price increases have had on mining activity in Coober Pedy.
Under the heading 'Explosives', the submission stated:
The retail price of explosives has risen dramatically in the last few years. This, too, has had an adverse effect on many opal miners.
The following figures show the price increases that have occurred.

I have not shown this document to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who is sitting at the table but no doubt he has seen a copy of this letter. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table in the submission showing the price of explosives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The submission goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The figures for fuel and explosive prices show that it costs almost twice as much to mine in Coober Pedy as it did two years ago. The price for opal has not risen since 1974 yet the value of production has increased many times.
Opal mining has been an efficient industry.
We would like the Government to look into the high cost of explosives with a view to granting subsidies, or take action to reduce these costs.

The submission goes on to give some detail from report book No. 79/111 of the opal industry in South Australia. This survey was carried out by the South Australian Department of Mines. The submission quotes the conclusion appearing in the report at page 28. It states:

In recent years, opal mining has become a major industry in South Australia, employing over 1,200 full time, and many part time miners. In 1978, an estimated $41.75m worth of precious opal was produced, approximately 80 per cent of the total Australian output and 25 per cent of total mineral production in South Australia.
Coober Pedy continues to be the major source of precious opal with Mintabie, for the first time in 1978, replacing Andamooka as the second largest producer.
Report Book 80/50 gives these figures on Data and Production in 1979.

It goes on to set out the places and the figures. At Coober Pedy there were 1,000 miners with operating costs of $3.65m and capital investment of $18.46m. The value of production was $32.67m. At Mintabie there were 150 miners with operating costs of $760,000 and capital investment of $6.11m. The value of production was $6.10m. At Andamooka there were 125 miners with operating costs of $60,000 and capital investment of $3.71m. The value of production was $4.52m. The total figures for the three places were: 1,275 miners with operating costs of $5.01m and capital investment of $28.28m. The total value of production was $43.29m. The submission goes on to state:

The above data gives an indication of the importance of the opal mining industry to the Australian economy. Apart from the overseas revenue earned from the export of opal and the employment of some 1,300 full time miners, very important consideration must be given to the amount miners have reinvested in the industry.

The Government should institute an impact study of the parity pricing policy and its effects on this industry. Primarily because of increases in prospecting and mining expenses the existence of Coober Pedy, a town of some 5,000 people, is in the balance.
The Mining Committee of the Coober Pedy Progress and Miners Association extends an open invitation to you to visit Coober Pedy at your earliest convenience to see and discuss the situation.
Yours faithfully, Nick King Chairman, Mining Committee

I have been to Coober Pedy on quite a few occasions. My colleague who represents that area, Mr Laurie Wallis, the member for Grey in the other place, goes into the townships of Coober Pedy, Andamooka and Mintabie on very many occasions to look after the interests of his constituents. He is very concerned about what is taking place now at Coober Pedy. Like me, he is making a plea to the Government to give some relief to the people who live in that town by helping them with the prices they pay for their fuel, explosives-and the price of everything that goes with the use of explosives such as cordtex-and all the other things that go into operating the opal mining industry.

This matter goes further than the mining association writing to members of Parliament. These people have also received a fair amount of publicity in the Press in South Australia and in the national Press in the last few days. They have gone to the extent of trying to draw the Government's attention to their plight by setting up a blockade of the Stuart Highway. An article appearing in the Adelaide Advertiser of Tuesday 24 March, stated:
A meeting of about 120 residents of the remote Mid-North opal mining town-
That is, Coober Pedy-
decided on the blockade on Saturday in an attempt to force the State and Federal governments to either subsidise or strictly control the price of gelenite and diesel fuel.
Mr James is reported in the article as saying:
. . . another meeting would be held at 6 p.m. today to decide the final details of the blockade, including the period of the protest.
I shall not quote all of that article. Another Press statement appearing in the Advertiser of the next day, 25 March, written by Mike Ekin Smyth, stated:
A rowdy and enthusiastic meeting of about 400 opal miners and townspeople at the Coober Pedy Community Hall agreed to the blockade to focus Federal Government attention on the town's problems.
The Press statement goes on:
Mr James said the miners were making a last-ditch stand to maintain Coober Pedy as a viable mining centre.
The town already had lost about 1000 residents in the past year. Many of the remaining 3500 would leave if they could sell their equipment and property.
Mr James is reported further as saying:
. . . the progress association had tried to have talks with the Federal Government, but with little success.
That is the reason these people are now taking the action that they are.

In today's Australian there appeared an article headed 'Blockade a dig at opal mine costs'. The article is written by the correspondent Peter Blunden. I will not quote from that article because I think I have put the proposition to the Senate and alerted the Senate to the fact-and I hope the Government takes some notice of it-that Coober Pedy is facing a crisis at present. Also, an interview took place on AM on 24 March with a Mr John Thrower whom I know and who has been an opal miner at Coober Pedy for many years. He was interviewed by Mr Peter Rapp. I think that many people who listened to AM that morning would be acquainted with the problem faced by the residents of Coober Pedy. I hope that by the publicity which the residents of Coober Pedy have received in the last week, because the matter has been raised in the Parliament by me today-if my colleague, Mr Wallis, can get the opportunity to speak in the other place he will raise it also-and because the residents have written to every honourable senator, I think, as well as to South Australian members of the House of Representatives, acquainting them with the problem, both the State and Federal governments will see fit to take some quick remedial action to assist those people who live in that outlying area of South Australia. As they have pointed out in the correspondence which I have read out, it is a very valuable industry to the people who live there and it is a valuable means of raising revenue for the State and Federal governments.

Following on from that, on Tuesday 24 March a letter was written to the Editor of the Adelaide Advertiser by Mr Weiss of Blair Athol complaining about the price of petrol in South Australia. In his letter to the editor he pointed out something which those of us who live in South Australia know already, and that is that South Australia has the dearest petrol of any State in Australia. Last week, as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, we met to inquire into the aluminium industry. I had visited Darwin and I found that petrol there was about 5c a litre cheaper than it is in Adelaide. At Gladstone in Queensland there is a similar difference in the price of petrol and again a similar difference in Tasmania. On my way back from Tasmania I did not have the opportunity to go to Melbourne to have a look there, but I understand that petrol is cheaper there too. So we find that South Australia has the highest petrol prices. Of course, this has been brought about by the mismanagement of the present Tonkin Liberal Government and its monkeying about with petrol prices. The residents of South Australia are paying the penalty.

There is another matter which I wish to bring before the Senate. It is something which has been given a lot of publicity in the last month or so, and that is the quality of the River Murray water. As I have said in this chamber, and I will refer to it again before I sit down, I am very disturbed at the way in which the South Australian Premier and the South Australian Minister of Water Resources are playing foolish politics by shouting from the house tops and trying to lay the blame on the New South Wales Government for the quality of water coming to South Australia. I wish to say at the outset that the Labor Party always has been concerned about the River Murray. The documents which I shall quote from date back to 1973. All honourable senators will recall that it was in 1972 that a Federal Labor Government came into office after the country had been ruled by a Liberal-Country Party coalition for approximately 23 years. It had done nothing about setting up an inquiry into the quality of the River Murray Water. We find that shortly after the Federal Government's election to office we then had a Labor Government in South Australia. I wish to quote from the River Murray Working Party interim report which was set down in the Parliament in September 1973. If honourable senators look at page 3 of that report, under the heading: 'Terms of Reference and Membership of the Working Party', they will see that clause 11 states:
On March 2 1973-
That is just four months after the election of the Labor Government-

at the request of the Premier of South Australia, a meeting was held between the Prime Minister and the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia on the River Murray, the powers of the River Murray Commission and problems of water quality in the River Murray. The meeting agreed to establish a working party of senior officials of the Australian and State Governments concerned with the following Terms of Reference.

I will not quote them because I have already read them into Hansard on a previous occasion. It can be seen that shortly after the election of the Federal Labor Government we showed our concern by setting up a River Murray Working Party to look at the problems of the River Murray. On 10 October a document was tabled in the Parliament entitled: 'A National Approach to Water Resources Management. A Statement of Australian Government Policy by the Minister for the Environment and Conservation, The Hon. Moss Cass, M.P.' That document was dated 10 October 1973. If people read those documents they will see that we have always been concerned with the quality of the water of the River Murray. We set up the Working Party to try to reach some agreement between the three States and the Federal Government to bring about proper control of the River Murray.

Then, of course, the final report to the Steering Committee of Ministers was tabled in this Parliament in, I think, 1976, but it is dated 1975. Something which I want to read from this report is of great interest and I hope that the people of South Australia will get hold of this report, look at it and will stop blaming the Labor Government of New South Wales for not doing anything about the River Murray. I shall quote from page 9/11 of this report. Honourable senators should bear in mind that when this River Murray Working Party was doing its work we had a Liberal Government in New South Wales. I think Mr Askin was the Premier. Under the heading 'New South Wales Government Representatives' the report states:

The New South Wales Government representatives consider that the water quality management of the Murray River catchment area can be carried out most effectively by the responsible State authorities for the water within each State.
At the conclusion of that paragraph it states:
The New South Wales representatives see no need to expand the powers of the River Murray Commission in respect to water pollution control in New South Wales.

That is what the Liberal Government said at that time. Yet we find the Wran Government being vilified from pillar to post by Mr Arnold and by Mr Tonkin. I will quote some of the things they say. As I have said in the Parliament on many occasions, the only thing they can achieve by what they are doing is perhaps gain a little bit of political support in South Australia. They will not achieve any better quality water by the way they are carrying on. People ought to take the time to read these documents and see the attitude of previous Liberal governments and what they did. The paragraph headed 'Victorian, South Australian and Australian Government Representatives' states:

It is not considered desirable to have two bodies concerned with aspects of management of the River Murray. It is considered that the interests of all parties would be best served if the institutional mechanism was embodied in the River Murray Commission.

In March 1978 the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Bill was introduced into the Parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —What they are now saying is that something should be done by New South Wales and no one else.

That has been spelt out not only by Senator Carrick but also in the report of the Committee of which I am a member and of which Senator Thomas is chairman. SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we know that $200m was set aside to be made available to the States on an equitable basis over five years. DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDING COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This afternoon in another place my colleague the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Viner) tabled the Commonwealth Government response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs report-Aboriginal Legal Aid. I now wish to table the same report in the Senate, together with the detailed responses of the Government to each of the recommendations contained in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

In moving that motion I would like to make some comments on behalf of the Opposition on the Commonwealth Government response to the report on Aboriginal legal aid which has just been tabled by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume). First of all, I would like to congratulate the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs on its report. I think it was a very comprehensive investigation into what has now come to be recognised as an essential service for Aboriginal people. It is a very basic service which is essential to giving Aboriginal people what we regard as a fundamental right in our society-the right to be equal before the law.

Of course, that right has not yet been achieved by Aboriginal people. We are constantly reminded of that. We were very recently reminded of the unequal position of Aboriginal people in this country before the law in a paper delivered by Mr William Clifford of the Australian Institute of Criminology who pointed out that between 500 and 1,000 Aborigines per 100,000 people were in gaol, whereas the general imprisonment rate for Australia was 67 per 100,000 people. He claimed that Australian Aborigines probably have the highest rate of imprisonment in the world. He pointed out that Aborigines represent only one per cent of the Australian population but 30 per cent of the numbers in prison. Of course, those figures do not reflect a drastically higher propensity to criminal activity by Aboriginal Australians. What they reflect are the appalling circumstances of poverty and disadvantage in which most Aboriginal Australians live and the difficulties of discrimination that they experience under our legal system. I think there can be no debate about the essential nature of Aboriginal legal services, and I am pleased to see that there is a bipartisan position on that.

However, the overwhelming impression I have from this report is that the present level of resources being made available by the Federal Government to the Aboriginal legal services is quite inadequate. Although the absolute amount has increased since the Aboriginal legal services were begun a few years ago, the funding has not kept up with inflation. Indeed, in 1980 funding was 8 per cent to 10 per cent less in real value than in the year before. Not only have the funds not kept up with inflation in terms of the amount being given, but also the Aboriginal legal services are almost open-ended services. As the services develop and as Aboriginal people come to have confidence in them, so the demand increases all the time and the funding by the Federal Government has simply gone nowhere near reflecting that demand. That is our major criticism of the Government's handling of the Aboriginal legal services to date.

I would like to make some specific comments about matters raised in the report and the Government's response to it. In doing so, I acknowledge the fact that the Government has made detailed responses to each of the recommendations. This kind of government response to parliamentary reports is a welcome improvement on the situation that prevailed previously when reports were left unattended, sometimes for years. As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs knows, there was a dissent to one aspect of the report by the Labor Representatives on the Committee. It related to the recommendation in the report to charge fees, on a means tested basis, for Aboriginal people seeking the services of the Aboriginal legal services. I simply confirm that the Australian Labor Party opposes the charging of means tested fees mainly because the knowledge that fees were to be charged would discourage Aboriginal people in need from approaching the services. We also recognise and believe that the Government should also recognise that the overwhelming majority of cases dealt with by Aboriginal legal services involve Aboriginal people living well below the poverty line. The introduction of the means test would mean that the number of people actually rendered eligible to pay would be miniscule. One has to consider the machinery needed and the cost involved in imposing, testing for and collecting a fee. We believe the attempts to collect a fee and administer a means test would create an administrative nightmare for the Aboriginal legal services, which, under-resourced as it is, would hamper their efficiency and effectiveness and perhaps erode the confidence of the Aboriginal people in them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you think of the specific response on that point?
—The response was to investigate the legality of charging fees.
—And then to encourage, which is a very different thing from instructing.

—It is a modified response, as the Minister has pointed out, but it seemed to my colleagues on the Committee that the circumstances of people using Aboriginal legal services is such that it would not be worth the effort to collect the fees. I presume that that is what the Government would discover. I have made the point that as the reputation of the legal services improves the demand for services grows. I also point out that the Aboriginal legal services receive claims other than just from people seeking legal representation and they have to meet these claims out of a very small budget. For example, I understand that the Minister wrote recently to the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service refusing to provide funds for an appeal in the Huckitta case and suggesting that the funds allocated for the establishment of a legal aid office in Tennant Creek might be diverted to that purpose. That is an example of how, from time to time, claims will be made on the Aboriginal legal services in special cases of this kind. It ought not to be that the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service has to choose between pursuing an appeal which, after all, is just a further attempt to get legal justice for Aboriginal people, and establishing a regional office in Tennant Creek the need for which is recognised by all.

SPEECH.PARA: Another drain on the resources of the Aboriginal legal services, I understand, is connected with the work of the Australian Law Reform Commission, which is currently seeking the views of Aboriginal communities on its report on customary law. We endorse what the Commission is doing, but when I was in Central Australia recently I was told that the Aboriginal legal service there was required to translate the Commission's report into various tribal languages. The translations were put onto cassettes. The service was required to participate in the inquiry with no extra funds being allocated for the purpose. It seems to me that the Government ought not to make these additional demands on Aboriginal legal services without recognising that additional funds will be needed.

I refer now to training and staff development. The report recommended that additional funds be made available to Aboriginal legal services to enable Aboriginal field officers to participate in training and that educational institutions develop suitable formal diploma or certificate courses. The Government endorses these recommendations, as does the Opposition, but makes no mention of additional funds. I will ask one question of the Minister now. He can reply to me at his convenience. Does the Government intend that when the field officers go off on these training courses they will be replaced? Just this week I visited the Aboriginal legal service in Redfern. Officers there expressed to me concern that the field officers would go to the training courses, which of course we all want to happen, but no new officers would be provided to replace them. In such a case, of course, the work of the service would be seriously undermined. Along with that anxiety there is the anxiety that the training allowances for field officers will not be high enough to recognise the fact that many of them are mature people with family responsibilities. I have raised this problem of training allowances for people with family responsibilities in other contexts. The Minister knows of my concern. I think it is important, if the training is to be provided, that financial support be provided also, otherwise the best people will not gain the advantage of the training. It would be apparent to the Minister that the people who are best suited for the fairly demanding and sensitive work of an Aboriginal field officer in the legal services would generally be mature people with spouses, children and so forth. I also draw attention to the fact that only 12 Aboriginal lawyers are currently in training. Again I say that this is obviously inadequate. The Government, I believe, ought to respond more positively to the problem of such a small number of Aboriginal people undertaking legal training.

I notice the specific response of the Government to the recommendation concerning the training and employment of Aboriginal legal staff. The Government says that the employment of Aboriginal law graduates by the Aboriginal legal services is a matter for the Aboriginal legal services to determine. That is all very well. As a philosophy of autonomy for the Aboriginal legal services, I would not argue with it, but while ever there is such a small number of trained Aboriginal legal practitioners it is not really very helpful for the Government simply to say that the Aboriginal legal services can decide whether they want to employ Aboriginal lawyers. If there are no Aboriginal lawyers the decision, of course, is entirely spurious. I would like to see a more affirmative statement by the Government on the need to train Aboriginals as professionals in this crucial field.

Similarly the report recommended the development of opportunities for training Aboriginals, particularly those from the Aboriginal legal services, in management and administration in consultation with the National Aboriginal Conference. We know that in the past there have been administrative and management problems in the development of Aboriginal legal services. I imagine that this recommendation was a response to that. The report recommend that the Government consult the Aboriginal Training and Cultural Foundation and the Institute of Aboriginal Development on the development of suitable management training. I support these recommendations. I have had some contact with both training organisations. They seem to me to be very well suited to undertake this course.

On the question of community education the report recommends that the Government provide financial support to the Aboriginal legal services which take initiatives to develop community legal education materials. The Government's response is that it will consider the matter having regard to overall budgetary priorities. This is the kind of response which appears to many of the recommendations throughout the report. I simply say that I hope that when the Government is working out its overall budgetary priorities it will give a very high priority to this whole area of developing, within the Aboriginal communities, services, trained personnel and an understanding by the community of legal rights. It is a most basic and fundamental right in a democratic system that people have this understanding of the legal services and are properly represented. I became rather pessimistic when I read so often throughout the Government's response to the recommendations that it would all be considered with regard to overall budgetary priorities. I hope that the Minister will be able to ensure that the priority given to this area particularly will be very high.

The matter of Aboriginal and police relations was documented very adequately in the report. Of course, there was reference to the documentation of cases of discriminatory treatment of Aboriginal people by police forces throughout Australia. In Mr Grassby's various reports to the Parliament I think that he has documented, probably from every State and territory of Australia, episodes of discriminatory treatment of Aboriginal people by police. The Government has made a positive response to this. At some stage I would like to hear from the Minister how the identification of these sorts of problems will continue now that the Racial Discrimination Act has been amended, in conjunction with the legislation setting up the Human Rights Commission, in such a way as to prevent the Commissioner for Community Relations making separate reports to the Parliament. The value of those separate reports, of course, lay in the fact that particular cases of discrimination could be documented and brought to the attention of the Parliament. Now that there will be no separate report, will the Human Rights Commission continue to draw the attention of the Parliament to these issues and continue identifying complaints of discriminatory treatment of Aboriginal people by the police forces?

I was pleased to see that the report emphasised the inadequacy of statistics concerning Aboriginal people and the legal system in Australia. Again, that is something that has been referred to before. In response, the Government has said that it will establish a means of gaining statistical information, particularly for crime and justice statistics. I strongly endorse that recommendation by the Government and I hope that very little time indeed elapses between the Government's accepting that recommendation and the establishment of a proper system of statistical gathering. Until we have that system, we are, of course, to some extent working in the dark and we have no really sound way of evaluating the success of some of these programs.

With regard to the employment of Aboriginals and specialist staff there was a recommendation that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs employ its own senior lawyer to provide legal expertise within the Department. However, the Government did not accept that recommendation. I think that the Government response to the matter of the promotion and career structure for Aboriginals within the Public Service was too complacent. The Government defended its record and pointed to the fact that the Public Service Board is taking action to increase Aboriginal employment opportunities. That action is insufficient. Too few Aboriginal people are being moved through the bureaucracy getting experience and training. There are still far too few senior Aboriginal public servants not only in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and specialist areas but also throughout the rest of the Public Service. I was disappointed that the Government defended its record in that respect. I would like a more affirmative response. Overall, as honourable senators will see, the Opposition welcomes the report and welcomes the fact that in many cases the Government has acknowledged the problems that have been so well documented and in some cases has made a commitment.

In conclusion, I would like to say that it seems to me now that the teething problems of the Aboriginal legal service have been sorted out. Now that the Aboriginal legal services are seen to be a very effective way of bringing some sort of legal protection to Aboriginal people and of reducing the numbers of Aboriginal people ending up in institutions, what is needed is an injection of funding. The current level of funding is inadequate. Many of the recommendations in the report concerning education and training and so forth that I have examples of will require additional funding as will the sorts of special tasks that are allocated from time to time to the Aboriginal legal services. The important thing now we have the report is that we have an appropriate response from the Government in terms of the next budgetary allocation. I heartily urge the Minister to seek such an allocation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to make provision for the Senators for the State of Queensland to be chosen by the people of that State voting as one electorate.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to require that senators for Queensland shall be directly chosen by the people of Queensland voting as one electorate. It removes from the Parliament of the State of Queensland the right to divide Queensland into divisions for the purpose of electing senators and thus puts Queensland on the same footing as each of the other five States in relation to the election of senators. In Australia, we have become accustomed to electing senators on a State-wide basis. This method of selection is used because of a provision in section 7 of the Constitution which specifies that, until the Federal Parliament provides otherwise, senators shall be chosen by the people of each State voting as one electorate. The Federal Parliament has not provided otherwise, so senators are currently chosen in State-wide ballots. It is clear, however, that should the Federal Parliament determine that there was a more preferable method of electing senators it could legislate to have that method adopted.

The Constitutional requirements in relation to the election of senators for Queensland are more complex. The Constitution allows the Queensland State Parliament to divide the State into senate electoral divisions and to determine the number of senators to be elected in each of those divisions. This provision is embodied in section 7 of the Constitution which, in part, states:

But until the Parliament of the Commonwealth otherwise provides, the Parliament of the State of Queensland, if that State be an Original State, may make laws dividing the State into divisions and determining the number of senators to be chosen for each division, and in the absence of such provision the State shall be one electorate.

In Queensland, senators are still chosen on the basis of a State-wide vote, because of two factors. Firstly, the Parliament of the Commonwealth has not yet provided that there shall be another method of selection. Secondly, the Parliament of Queensland has not made any laws dividing the State into divisions. The Queensland Parliament, however, retains the right to divide Queensland into divisions for the purpose of electing senators and to determine the number of senators to be chosen in each of those divisions. Quick and Garran outline in The Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth that this unique provision was inserted in the Constitution because of the 'special circumstances of Queensland, its vast territory and scattered population, coupled with the fact that its population seemed to be naturally growing and developing in three divisions which may hereafter become separate States'. Lumb and Ryan in The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia Annotated note that the provision 'was designed to assuage the feelings of separateness prevalent in the northern and central areas of the State, feelings which had adversely affected Queensland's participation in the convention activities'.

It could be argued that although this special provision has been in the Constitution since Federation, it is unlikely that it will be used in the future. The fact that successive Queensland parliaments have seen fit not to establish a divisional structure for the election of senators could lend credence to this argument. Recent events, however, suggest that the part of Section 7 dealing with electoral divisions in Queensland could well be used by a Queensland parliament.

Towards the end of 1979, the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, announced that he would give serious consideration to those provisions of Section 7 of the Constitution which specifically relate to Queensland. At that time, it was reported in the media that electoral divisions in Queensland could be drawn in such a way that in a half-Senate election, three National Party senators could be elected, with the Labor Party and the Liberal Party both having one of their candidates elected. When this matter was being discussed in Queensland in 1979, a three-divisional structure was suggested. Division 1, which would elect one senator in a half-Senate election, consisted of the Federal electorates of Leichhardt, Herbert and Kennedy. Division 2, which would also elect one senator, consisted of the electorates of Dawson, Capricornia and Wide Bay. The third division, which would elect three senators, consisted of the remaining 13 Queensland Federal electorates. Those three divisions could loosely be termed the northern, central and southern divisions respectively.

After the results of the 1980 Senate election were available, the detailed voting figures in Queensland permitted calculations to be made to determine the likely results if the five senators for Queensland had been elected on the three-divisional basis which has just been described. It should be acknowledged that if the Senate election had been based on a divisional structure, there may have been different candidates and different emphases in campaigning by the major political parties. Nevertheless, calculations made on the detailed results within those three divisions reveal that, all other things being equal, the National Party would have won the vacancies in Divisions 1 and 2 and one of the three vacancies in Division 3. The Liberal and Labor parties would each have won a vacancy in Division 3, giving an overall Queensland result of three Nationals, one Liberal and one Labor. Considering that the actual result in the 1980 Senate election in Queensland was two Labor, one National, one Liberal and one Democrat, the divisional structure would have been particularly appealing for the National Party.

Quite naturally there was spirited debate in 1979 when Mr Bjelke-Petersen announced that he would give serious consideration to the provisions contained in Section 7 of the Constitution. Mr Bjelke-Petersen would have perceived that public opinion and perhaps his coalition partners would have not been on his side if he decided to press ahead with legislation to have senators elected in Queensland on a divisional basis. It was not surprising that he did not pursue the idea. The point which should be stressed is that the matter was given serious consideration in 1979 and it would be most unwise to presume that no future Queensland Parliament will legislate to set up a divisional structure for the election of senators.

It should also be kept in mind that it would not be difficult to devise a divisional system-even one which embodied a one vote one value concept-which was biased towards any particular party, not necessarily the National Party. Section 7 of the Constitution could be used by any political party with a majority in the Queensland Legislative Assembly to set electoral divisions which would assist its Sente candidates. If appropriate legislation is not enacted by the Federal Parliament, there is little, if any, doubt that some future maverick Queensland government will use this archiac provision of section 7 of the Constitution. It could choose its timing in such a way that the Federal Parliament would be temporarily powerless to frustrate the actions of the Queensland Government. For example, the Governor-General prorogued the Federal Parliament on 19 September 1980. If the State Government had acted on that day to set up Senate electoral divisions and subsequently issued writs for the election of senators in those divisions, the Federal Parliament could have done nothing until the newly elected Parliament met after the election. Indeed, it would have been required to accept the senators who had been elected under the divisional system. It would be much better for the Federal Parliament to act now, rather than be outmanoeuvred by some future Queensland government which is intent on using section 7 to influence the outcome of Senate elections in Queensland.

The passage of this Bill will prevent the Parliament of Queensland from legislating to set up a divisional structure for the election of senators. When this Bill was being drafted, legal advice suggested that the power given to the Commonwealth Parliament to provide otherwise could be interpreted in two ways. One interpretation is that the power allows the Commonwealth Parliament to provide expressly that senators for Queensland shall be chosen by the people of that State voting as one electorate. The other interpretation is that the power simply allows the Commonwealth Parliament to deny the competence of the Queensland Parliament to make laws dividing the State into Senate electoral divisions. This Bill therefore has been drafted to cover both possibilities. Finally, I mention that this Bill would in no way affect the Senate representation of any new State which may be established within the existing boundaries of Queensland. The representation of any new State is provided for in section 121 of the Constitution. That section states:

The Parliament may admit to the Commonwealth or establish new States, and may upon such admission or establishment make or impose such terms and conditions, including the extent of representation in either House of the Parliament, as it thinks fit.
The passage of this Bill would in no way alter section 121. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
