SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate call on the Government to state its attitude towards the recommendation of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee's Report on the Trade Practices Act and on small business, with particular reference to:
(a) the likely impact of the repeal of section 49 on small business; and
(b) the impact of the Report's recommendations on the concentration of market power in the hands of big business.

On 19 December 1978 the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the present Minister for Education (Mr Fife), referred a matter to a committee which had been appointed by him. Its terms of reference were designed to allow it to inquire into the Trade Practices Act and particularly section 49 of that Act which relates to the complaints which governments have, over the last dozen or so years, had referred to them by small business throughout Australia. I remind the Senate that, although great changes have taken place, small business is still very important and a focal point of the Australian economy. I think it is ironic that two and half years later, and more than a year since the presentation of the report, this Government has failed either to accept or reject the recommendations which I will refer to in that report. Of course, the reasons for this lie in the inability of the Fraser Government to determine whether there is substance in the recommendations of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee, or whether it is prepared to act on behalf of the small business sector of this country.

I also find it ironic that yesterday, when I talked about matters relating to deficiencies in the Commonwealth Electoral Act, I was chided by Senator Martin for not doing something about electoral problems and inadequacies during the brief period, 1972 to 1975, when the Whitlam Government was in power. Senator Martin ignored the fact that for that three years the Whitlam Government was besieged and beleagured by the obstructionist attitude of the conservative majority in the Senate. Under the Whitlam Administration, the Parliament had placed before it the largest legislative program in its history. It seems to me to smack of hypocrisy to be chided because we did not do something about the Commonwealth Electoral Act when on this important question of small business, the Government is not able or does not want to take any action as a result of the report of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee because of the differences in philosophy and ideology within the coalition parties.

This Government has often stated that it is the friend of small business. In the treatment of this report it can only put its money where its mouth is. The fact is that a report has not been made to the Parliament. There has been no discussion in the Parliament about the recommendations dealing with section 49 of the Trade Practices Act. I imagine the reason for that is that the Government is not prepared or is not game to act upon the major recommendation of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee, because that report recommended to the government of the day the repeal of section 49. Despite all the evidence that was placed before the Committee which dealt with the problems of the small business sector in Australia, this very strange Committee came to the conclusion that section 49 of the Trade Practices Act should be repealed. What does the Council of Small Business Associations say? Firstly it says that it wants section 49 retained. I am sure that that would be the view of the Parliament, of the Australian community and the view of a vast majority of the Australian consumers, who recognise the importance that small business plays in Australia, not only because it provides a competitive base for the Australian economy but also because it is one of the largest employers of labour in our community. I will quote what the Council of Small Business Associations says. It has consistently stated that whilst it:
. . . strongly supported the retention of section 49 in the Trade Practices Act, it was felt that the working of the section left much to be desired.

Therefore, we suggest that consideration be given to redrafting that section. Firstly, we must state that we are not asking for price maintenance at either the wholesale or retail level. Discounting is here to stay. All we ask is that discounts, allowances, et cetera, are meaningful discounts which make allowance for differences in the cost of manufacturing and distribution. Many of the discounts being given in today's market-place have no bearing or relationship to specific quantities or cost savings. The Association states:

The present Section 49 has two parts which appear to create the most problems in relation to small businesses, the first being the wording which follows 49 (1) (D) commencing 'If the discrimination is of such magnitude, et cetera . . . ' through to the end of the sentence. The discrimination may be of such magnitude in, say, for instance, a country town, that it seriously jeopardises the existence of a small trader.
That is, a small business. It continued:

However, when this discrimination is related to the market place as a whole it becomes quite insignificant. We suggest that so long as discrimination is proved, action should be taken against the corporate concerned.
Similarly, the wording 'recurring and systematic nature' virtually results in a small business having to close down before sufficient proof of the 'recurring nature' has been provided.

It is no wonder that the Council of Small Business Associations in this country is pressing the Government to strengthen section 49 by taking the steps that it has proposed to the Trade Practices Consultative Committee. It proposed an alternative wording to strengthen the section. It suggested the following wording:

If the discrimination is of such a nature it is likely to have the effect of substantially lessening the competitiveness of the business or businesses being discriminated against in a market for goods, being a market in particular or the general marketing area in which the corporation supplies, or those persons supply goods.

I wish to give one or two examples of how that system would work. Complaints have been reported to me and, I am sure, to other members of Parliament who have any connections with small business about major takeovers of manufacturers of goods. I refer particularly to a case referred to me about the manufacture and distribution of building materials. It was about a large company in Sydney which took over two smaller companies manufacturing similar goods and then not only ceased to honour the trading arrangements which had been in existence for a considerable time with a number of small retail outlets but also refused to make available to the retail outlets the goods which were normally ordered and supplied by the companies taken over. When consumers entered a small retail store for the purpose of purchasing a particular product they were not able to buy that product. The larger company, having taken over the smaller company, forced the consumers to go to larger market places, to the major retail centres, to purchase the goods required, to the detriment of the smaller retail outlet. It is interesting to note what the Department of Industry and Commerce had to say about section 49. It said:
A problem with S.49 is that although retained to assist the small business sector, the present provisions do not really protect individual small firms.
Here we have a Government department acknowledging that the section is somewhat deficient. It continued:
As indicated earlier small firms can be individually damaged by price discrimination but cannot obtain relief if there is no substantial lessening of competition.

One way of making it more effective from the point of view of protecting the small firm would be to add an additional concept to the basic test of 'substantially lessening competition', i.e. prevent price discrimination where . . . it has or is likely to have, the effect of substantially lessening competition . . . or of substantially damaging the business of a purchaser of goods of like grade and quality in that market.

That is the point I stressed in relation to the instance to which I have referred. The change taking place in the market place not only places the purchaser in the position of not being able to purchase goods from where he would normally purchase them but also results in the retail supplier not being able to have the goods supplied to it. That is leaving aside the experience which I am sure every honourable senator would recognise about what happens in the price area itself.
The Council of Small Business Associations stated:

In conclusion although S49 in our view is of little value to an individual small business suffering from price discrimination, it appears to have some deterrent effect on this practice, particularly as businessmen realise there is a difference between genuine discounting and blatant price discrimination.

Yet, in the face of these views, the Committee appointed by Mr Fife two and a half years ago still recommended the repeal of section 49. I can appreciate the dilemma of this Government when the Australian economy is such that every day we see in the financial columns of our newspapers reports of drastic takeovers and changes in the market place, of bigger firms swallowing the smaller firms in manufacturing, retailing, distribution and so on. Surely what we are seeing is not acceptable to the Australian community or to this Government. Certainly, it is not acceptable to the Australian Labor Party. Even the conservative governments in South Australia and Queensland are forced from time to time to stop raids of other conglomerates in Australia from gobbling up some of the companies that have long been part of their tradition and are indigenous to those States. Over the last few days we have seen reports of the raid of the West Australian entrepreneur, Mr Holmes a' Court, of the Bell group of companies, upon Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd in Adelaide. They show how an individual can make $15m or $16m from a concentration of economic and political clout, to the detriment of small or even large businesses, such as Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort. What we are seeing is a modern bucaneering approach by the new tycoons of Australian industry, marauding the business sectors of our country, acting as though they are twentieth century pirates in the same way as pirates stole and plundered goods in other parts of the world two and three centuries ago. All of this is not only having a very marked effect upon the capital market and upon the viability of major companies but also rendering it impossible for smaller companies to survive.

Section 49 is one of the mechanisms that have provided at least some opportunity for small business to survive in the face of this great change that is taking place in the Australian economy. If, according to the Committee, section 49 is not doing anything, why chop it out? Surely a case should be made that it is actually doing harm before it is repealed. That is our submission to the Government. Although few, if any, actions have been brought under this section, there is still enough evidence in the report with which we are dealing to suggest that it has a deterrent effect. Indeed, that was what the Department of Industry and Commerce said in its submission. The companies out in the market place know what benefits them and they want the section strengthened, not just retained. I believe that the Parliament should scrutinise the composition of the Committee that made these recommendations. How, may we ask, could a committee set up to look into the area of small business make recommendations against the submissions by small business itself?

The Sydney law firm of Allen, Allen and Hemsley, which is surely accepted by accountancy practices in Sydney as one of the major firms working in the trade practices area, has a significant influence on the thinking of the Consultative Committee. The six-man Committee was chaired by Mr R. G. Blunt, a partner in that firm, and Mr A. G. Hartnell, who is currently working for that firm, was a member of the Committee. Whilst having two out of the six members in itself gives Allen, Allen and Hemsley considerable weight, this weight is increased by the fact that Mr Hartnell is a deputy secretary in the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs who is on leave of absence so as to take part in a Public Service-private sector work exchange program. In the Department Mr Hartnell was intimately involved in trade practices matters. His past experience thus makes him the most important single member of the Committee. The other members of the Committee are Mr J. G. Wilson, former head of Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd, Sir Samuel Burston, President of the Australian Woolgrowers and Graziers Council, Mr T. Martire, a Sydney small businessman, and academic, Dr N. R. Norman. So of the Committee of six appointed by this Government to look into section 49 of the Trade Practices Act only one small businessman is present.

We can ask why it is that big business did not make submissions. Obviously it found it was not necessary because big business was already represented on the Committee. I note that the report's recommendations on franchising are realistic and worth while and should be implemented. I believe this is an urgent issue and one which the Government should not sweep under the carpet. We are aware of the problems facing small businesses in this country. When we are aware that over the last seven or eight years the number of bankruptcies has increased some 40 per cent in this country, surely it behoves a government that claims to represent the interests of the small business sector in our country to take some action to repeal the section, to strengthen the section or to give the Parliament some opportunity to decide what action should be taken in respect of this important report.
The report goes on to make some philosophical comments about competition. It states:

Some proponents of competition laws see competition as desirable mainly because it limits the accumulation and use of power by individual (large) firms. Although the use of this power might be limited by direct governmental control, competition is seen as preferable because it replaces the direct influence of big business or government with the impersonal dispassionate control of the market. A broader aspect of this claim is the limiting of the 'social' power of large firms. The justification for this approach would be the conviction that fragmented economic power with many independent proprietors, rather than economic concentration with power wielded by corporate bureaucrats, is desirable in itself.
Finally, in the conclusion the report states:

Competition laws should be directed primarily at the behaviour of firms and secondarily at market structure that is inconsistent with the attainment of efficiency and progress. They should be directed at preventing firms persistently behaving in a manner different from that which a competitive market would enforce on them. They should not be directed primarily at achieving the other goals . . .

What is the evidence that was placed before the Committee? The Committee looked at what was happening to the manufacturing sector of our economy. It made the point that import competition may be of considerable significance to our manufacturing sector. In respect of retailing it said that two-thirds of all of the submissions made by the small business sector drew the conclusion that there was unfair price discrimination. Similarly, in respect of the wholesaling sector, the Committee found that evidence given to the Committee by small business, which in its desire to maintain its viability as part of the Australian economy made similar representations to the Committee on the basis that there was unfair price discrimination.

Of course, we are all aware, are we not, that the big companies in the area of discounting are able to provide goods at such a price to the large retail outlets in such a way as to make it impossible for the small businessman to compete at all in the area of prices? So we have the problems of the delivery of goods, of unfair price discrimination and of the big getting bigger all at the expense of the small business sector in Australia. We have seen so much of this develop in the last couple of years that I think it behoves any government that claims to represent the economic interests of small business in Australia to act upon the recommendations of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee or reject them and take on board the submissions which were so properly placed before the Committee by the Council of Small Business Associations of Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carrick) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate deplores the continued persecution of religious minorities in Iran, particularly the large community of Baha'is, and urges that this total abuse of the right to religious tolerance be brought to the attention of the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations.

This debate gives us the opportunity to explore some of the incidents that have occurred in the strife-torn nation of Iran since its Islamic Revolution which overthrew the regime of the late Shah and established a theocracy. The facts which I wish to put before the Senate this evening indicate the extent to which religious minorities in Iran, some of whose positions were allegedly guaranteed by the Iranian Constitution-both the revolutionary Constitution and the earlier Constitution of 1906-have now been set at nought.

I shall bring also before the Australian Senate a matter which has been considered on a number of occasions by the Australian Government and which relates to the position of the very large Baha'i religious minority community in that country. I will confine my remarks this evening to discussing purely the persecution of religious minorities, although perhaps it is worth noting in passing that other minorities, including, for example, the ethnic minority of the Iranian Kurds also have been subjected to extreme persecution by the current regime. Lest it be thought that I refer purely to one group of religious minority adherents in Iran, I think, before going on to the exact position of the Baha'is, I should indicate the fate that has befallen the Anglican, Catholic and Jewish religious minorities in that country.

I turn first to the position of the reasonably well-organised and reasonably well-developed Anglican community in Iran. Shortly after the Ayatollah Khomeini and his regime came to power in Iran, a systematic persecution of the Anglican Church commenced. Within a few weeks of the Ayatollah coming to power-in fact in February 1980-the Anglican Vicar of Shiraz, Aristo Sayeh, was brutally murdered by the revolutionary guards. In October 1979, gunmen, again identified as revolutionary guards, burst into the Isfahan bedroom of the Anglican Bishop of Iran, Hassan Barnaba Dehqani-Tafti. He and his British-born wife, Margaret, were subjected to assault and, indeed, were sprayed with automatic pistol fire. Fortunately they survived that attack. However the Bishop's son, Bahram, a few weeks later in fact was murdered. The Bishop's secretary, Miss Jean Waddell, an elderly lady, was arrested by religious guards, being strangled almost to death, she was thrown into prison and brutally treated by the revolutionary guards. She and Dr John Coleman and his wife, Audrey, who were Anglican missionaries in the city of Yazd, were subjected to imprisonment, torture and various other forms of persecution.

Indeed, as honourable senators will recall, it was only through the intervention of His Grace, the Anglican Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr Runcie, and his special representative to Iran that these Anglican hostages were fairly recently released from custody. The persecution of Christian groups in Iran continues. In August 1980 Iran ordered that all Catholic priests, monks and nuns had to leave the country within a period of one month. Mr Mohammad Ali Rajai, the Prime Minister of Iran, one of the most extreme of the Islamic fundamentalists, was instrumental in seeking to close down all Catholic religious establishments in Iran. The message which His Holiness, Pope John Paul II, sent to the Ayatollah Khomeini in fact was rejected, and the replies which the Iranian Revolutionary Government sent to His Holiness were offensive in the extreme. The position of the Catholic church in Iran since the revolution has become one of considerable persecution.

Perhaps not surprisingly the Jewish community in Iran has suffered, and suffered very considerably. The Jewish people in Iran have by and large sought to leave the country, and almost half of the entire Jewish community in Iran has since quit the country in fear of renewed persecution. The Age newspaper of 19 August 1980 reported that Iran's parliament had expelled its only Jewish member, Mr Eshagh Farahmandpur after a two-hour debate which in fact took the form of a trial conducted within the Iranian parliament. Mr Farahmandpur was accused of being an adherent of and a collaborator with international zionist conspiracies. Despite the fact that he had been properly elected to the Iranian parliament, he was expelled from that parliament on no other basis than his membership of the Jewish faith. Lest it be thought that the attack is simply one of a series of indiscriminate attacks upon particular religious minorities, I note that on 4 March this year the Majlis, the Iranian parliament, passed legislation which required that the activities of all parties, societies and groups, including religious minorities, would be regulated by a series of government controls. For instance, clause 17 of that legislation prohibits religious groups from having contact with embassies, political parties and foreign governments without the written permission of the Iranian Government. Such contacts which exist are to be reported in detail to the Iranian Government within a period of 48 hours.

I mention those things to put into context the fact that when I specifically single out the persecution that the Baha'i minority has suffered in Iran, I do not mean it to be the exclusive illustration of religious persecution by a fanatical regime. The Iranian constitution adopted, as far back as 1906, at a time when Raza Shah was coming to power-indeed the current Iranian constitution recognises this-there is an apparently legitimate place for four religious groups within Iran; for Islam the religion of the overwhelming majority of Iranians, for Christians, for Jews and for those who are adherents of the Zoroastrian faith. I have already indicated the extent to which the Christian and Jewish groups are persecuted by the behaviour of the current regime. It has not been brought to my attention that any persecution of the Zoroastrian community in Iran has yet occurred, but I must say from my knowledge and research of that country and its circumstances, I would not be surprised if that were the case. The Zoroastrian religion is a very old one, established many years ago in Iran. Zoroastra, who is also known as Zarthushtra, was active as a religious reformer in Persia 258 years before its conquest by Alexander the Great. It is a religion based on the position of the chief deity, Ahura Mazda and what I suppose might be called his dialectic opposite, Ahrimar, is a significant religion. Its adherents are a significant group of people in the Iranian community and I have no doubt that they as a religious minority are likely to suffer the same persecution as the Baha'is, the Christians and the Jews. I should now therefore say a few words about the Baha'i faith in particular and draw attention to the specific instances of religious persecution which have been directed against the Baha'i community. Despite the chiding of Senator Evans, I am sure that he would not want to be deprived of the opportunity to expand his knowledge of a particular interesting religious faith which has many adherents in Australia.

In fact, those of us who live in Sydney are aware of its significant Baha'i temple. Senator Sibraa would be aware of the establishment of the Baha'i community and its centre of religious worship at Ingleside in the same Federal electorate, I think, in which Senator Sibraa resides. There are many people of the Baha'i religious persuasion in Australia. They constitute a small dedicated group in Australia. Among the things that undoubtedly are significant to them is the total freedom in which they practice their religious beliefs here and the fact that they are a persecuted minority on whose behalf, as I will demonstrate shortly, the Australian Government has intervened both with the Iranian authorities and indeed with the United Nations. The basic principles of the Baha'i faith are that they believe in the oneness of mankind, as they describe it, in the independent investigation of truth, in the common foundation of all religions, in the essential harmony of science and religion, in the complete equality of men and women, in the elimination of prejudice of all kinds, in universal compulsory education, in spiritual solutions to political, economic and social problems, in a universal auxiliary language, and in the concept of universal peace.

It is for precisely those views which they hold that they are now subject to persecution in Iran. The fact that the major figures of the Baha'i faith, The Bab-that is his title-Siyyid Ali Muhammed, its first significant figure, Bahaullah its principal exponent-his son and his grandson who were the principal figures in the establishment and development of the Baha'i religion which goes back now about 130 years, were originally members of the Islamic faith, has caused Islamic revolutionary regimes in countries such as Iran to regard them as heretics, as deviants from the true religion and as apostates, and as such to subject them to a high degree of persecution. Under the regime of the late Shah of Iran Baha'is were certainly not encouraged as a religious group, but many of their members, because of their education and because of their inherent skills, rose to occupy positions of significance in the administration of the Shah and as such have been identified on a number of occasions with a regime whose very memory the current revolutionary regime in Iran is seeking to stamp out.

It should perhaps be indicated that persecution is not new to the Baha'i religion in Iran. Back in 1896 Nasiri'd-Din Shah was assassinated and the Baha'is were unjustly blamed for that. There were a considerable number of persecutions as a result. In 1903 the new regime ordered the massacre of more than 100 members of the Baha'i religion in the city of Yazd. In 1906, during the time of the great revolution in Iran, the members of the Baha'i faith were again persecuted. There was systematic persecution of them in the 1930s. There was persecution of them during the time of the late Shah's rule in Iran in 1955. The current wave of persecution, however, has been vicious. I would like to give a few instances of the extent to which that can be shown to be true. When the former Premier of Iran, Mr Hoveida, was executed and indeed, when the former chief of Savak, General Nassiri, was executed, one of the charges against them was that they were members of the Baha'i religion. Regardless of the role they might have played in supporting the Shah's regime, one of the formal charges against them was that they were associated with the Baha'i religion.

In May 1980, five members of the Baha'i religion, including Mrs Parsa, a former Minister of Education under the Shah, were executed. In July 1980 two other significant religious leaders of the Baha'i group were executed in East Azerbaijan. In November 1980 Yousef Sobhani and Reza Firuzi, again significant Baha'is, were executed. In January 1980 Professor Hakim, a member of the Baha'i National Council and an internationally recognised medical scientist, was murdered and his property was confiscated by the revolutionary regime. In March 1981 Mr Nafti and Mr Dehgani, again members of the Baha'i National Council, all nine of the members of which are in prison at the moment, were executed. In May 1980 the Sunday Examiner newspaper reported that Amnesty International had expressed its disquiet about the execution of ex-government Ministers in Iran and seven members of the Baha'i faith. The Canberra Times of 24 September 1980, under the heading 'Crusade to purify nation of non-Islamic influence' drew attention to the number of executions of Baha'i members in Iran. It indicated that the purge of non-Islamic groups that was going on had caused 30,000 of the country's estimated 70,000 to 80,000 Jews to flee the country. It estimated that some 70 leading members of the Baha'i faith in Iran had been imprisoned. It identified the fundamentalist Mr Rajai, the Prime Minister of Iran, as a prime moving spirit in this persecution of religious minorities. The Weekend Australian of 13-14 September 1980 again reported the murder of some seven members of the Baha'i faith on the orders of a revolutionary tribunal.

I have already referred to the murder of Professor Hakim. A number of other executions could be adverted to. It is not just that members of the Baha'i faith are being murdered and executed; it is also a fact that they are being persecuted within the framework of the Iranian Government. Mr Rajai, when he was Education Minister in Iran, commenced this persecution of members of the Baha'i faith. Ayatollah Sadoughi, one of the senior members of the Iranian revolutionary establishment, preached what I suppose might be regarded as a sermon in which he asserted that all members of the Baha'i religion were plotting in every city in Iran and were conspiring with the Zionists and with the United States. He urged the faithful, in his words, 'to evict the Baha'is whom you know from all administrative posts and turn them over to the revolutionary prosecutor'. Etelaat, one of the significant revolutionary newspapers, has been pursuing a campaign calling for the dismissal of all employees, the ending of all Baha'i concessions and forbidding members of the Baha'i religion from engaging in any form of paid employment. In the French newspaper Le Monde of 24 June 1980 there is a very significant description of the way in which the persecution of Baha'i members in the Iranian civil service is taking place. I have here a copy of a directive from the Ministry of Education in Iran signed by Mr Rajai, who, as I said, is now the Prime Minister, in his capacity then as Guardian of the Ministry of Education of the Islamic Republic of Iran, in which he said:

The Ministry of Education which has come into being through the justice of the Islamic Republic of Iran, and the blood and martyrdom of thousands of Muslims, men and women, cannot tolerate, like the previous regime, the existence of followers of the Baha'i sect in its Educational unit . . . In conclusion I would like to remind you that the employment of Iranians, who are not followers of recognised religions such as, Muslims, Jews, Christians and Zoroastrians, in Government Offices is against the law. Therefore, your dismissal--
This is addressed to a particular Baha'i individual-
according to the existing law is a minimum punishment.

The Australian Baha'is have drawn to my attention the fact that some 50 members of the Ministry of Education were dismissed summarily in the middle of 1980 for their adherence to the Baha'i faith. One of the members of the Islamic revolutionary court, in response to a petition from certain Baha'i women, wrote:
In accordance with the instructions of the Attorney General of the country, the Baha'is are not entitled to receive anything; therefore, we are not replying to your petition.
That was a simple petition asking for the protection of their religious and civil rights under Iranian laws. The Governor of Sistan and Baluchistan wrote in a circular letter:

Since transactions with the false Baha'i organisation is against the laws of Islam, the Department of Finance is instructed to refuse accepting any vouchers for such transactions . . . Anyone who does not observe this ruling will be severely punished.

The London Times on 2 July 1980 indicated the extent to which Army officers, for instance, were being told that they were to be dismissed or deprived of their commissions unless they gave up their Baha'i faith. It has been indicated that certain changes of status-for instance, the right to get a passport or the right to get married-may be denied to members of the Baha'i faith unless they are prepared to forego their faith and to make a renunciation of it.

A number of resolutions have been passed internationally and there have been numerous responses to and protests at the persecution of the Baha'is. The Canadian House of Commons Hansard dated 16 July 1980 records that the House of Commons in Canada passed a motion moved by Mr Geoff Scott in the following terms:

That this House of Commons deplores the continued persecution of religious minorities in Iran, especially the 200,000 Baha'is, and urges that this total abuse of religious tolerance be brought to the attention of the Human Rights Committee of the United Nations.
That motion was similar in wording to the motion that I have moved this evening. The United Nations Economic and Social Council on 8 September 1980 expressed:

. . . its profound concern for the safety of the recently arrested members of the elected National Administrative Council of the Baha'is in Iran, and that of all members of this community, both as individuals and collectively;
The Official Journal of the European Communities in September 1980 recorded a resolution which, inter alia:

Condemns the violation of the human rights of all religious minorities in Iran, more particularly the members of the Baha'i faith whose rights as a religious minority are not recognised by the Iranian constitution;

I am glad to say that the Australian Government has been active and forthright in its condemnation of persecution of the Baha'i faith in Iran. As far back as 12 November 1974 there appeared in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette a proclamation issued by His Excellency the Governor-General recognising denominations for the purpose of the Marriage Act 1961-1973. The Baha'i faith is listed there. On 13 September 1979 the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Peacock, writing to the Acting Secretary of the Baha'i National Spiritual Assembly in Australia, said:

The Australian Government is deeply concerned about the situation in Iran in relation to aspects of human rights and the position of ethnic and religious minority groups. The Government shares your concern about the position of the Baha'i communities and reports of confiscation of and damage to their communal property.

I should indicate that at that stage the chief religious shrines and sanctuaries of the Baha'is in Iran especially the House of Bab in Shiraz had been systematically desecrated by the Iranian revolutionaries and that the free practice and free occupation of the religious shrines in Iran by the Baha'is had been systematically denied to them. Mr Peacock, in a letter of 15 August to the Acting Secretary of the National Spiritual Assembly, indicated that his Department 'shares your view that the situation of the Baha'is in Iran has deteriorated markedly, particularly in the past few months'.

Mr Street, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, indicated on 12 December 1980 in a letter to Mr Bailey, the Chairman of the Spiritual Assembly, that his Department had called in the Iranian charge-d'affaires in Canberra and had made representations to him regarding the persecution of members of the Baha'i faith. In fact, the Iranian charge-d'affaires was called to the Department of Foreign Affairs on 7 August 1980 and has since been called on at least one other occasion for the Australian Government to express its opposition to the treatment of the Baha'is in Iran. On 9 March the Australian delegation to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights meeting in Geneva spoke strongly against the persecution of religious minorities in Iran. We have therefore been on the public record as it were in indicating, at least at a governmental level, our opposition to the persecution of this religious minority.

The purpose of moving the motion this evening is to invite the Australian Senate, which is part of the Commonwealth Parliament, to associate itself formally with this expression of concern about religious persecution in Iran and with statements that have been made by the Australian Government through its Department of Foreign Affairs. The Baha'is, as a group, do not participate in political activity. It is part of the tenet of the Baha'is faith that Baha'is do not participate in political activity in any country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet they vote.

—No, they do not vote, even in Iran. When the Revolutionary Government proposed a national referendum on the question of the establishment of an Islamic republic the religious leaders of the Baha'i community in Iran wrote to Prime Minister Bazargan indicating that the religious convictions of the Baha'i religion would not allow any Baha'i to vote in national referendums. As I understand it, members of the Baha'i faith in Australia as well do not participate in overt political activity even to the extent of voting. It is a tenet of the Baha'is faith not to involve oneself in anything that is communally divisive, including participation even in democratic political undertakings. I think it is in fact significant that this group is very insistent on having no activity which could be described as entering into partisan considerations, whether in Iran or Australia. As I say, the congregation in Australia is significant. Outside Israel, where at Haifa the principal religious shrine of the Baha'i faith is to be found, and Iran, Australia is one of the half dozen or so places around the world where a Baha'i temple is established and where the members of that faith practice their faith without any degree of discrimination or imposition being made upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that it is perhaps unfair to take this matter totally in isolation. I believe that it would be unfair for any implication to be drawn from what I have said that the Islamic faith as such is hostile to the Baha'is or that that faith does not believe in allowing the Baha'is to exercise their own religious practices and beliefs. I think the situation we have in Iran at the moment is an aberration, that it should not be regarded as being either typical or representative of the overall approach of the Islamic people. Time magazine of 28 April 1980 carried an interesting theological discussion under the heading 'Is the Ayatollah a Heretic?' in which a number of Islamic scholars discussed the question of the extent to which the Ayatollah's regime has launched persecutions, his lack of charity towards strangers and his lack of hospitality in the sense that it is understood within the Islamic faith, in fact, marked him out as deviating significantly from the fundamental teachings of Islam.

My purpose in moving the motion this evening is to seek the concurrence of the Senate in condemning a particular instance of religious persecution. My purpose is to align the Senate with the stand that has already been taken by the Australian Government at Executive level with the Canadian House of Commons, with the Council of Europe and with some of the organisations associated with the United Nations and to indicate that in Australia is a community of people freely practising their religious faith. They are unable to do so in Iran. They are being systemically and vigorously persecuted in Iran. Passage of this motion this evening may not do anything specifically to alleviate the situation as it appertains in Iran at the moment, but at least it is a confirmation and understanding that Australian members of parliament and the Australian Senate understand and unreservedly condemn the persecution that the Baha'is are currently suffering. It seeks to draw to the attention of the wider world community the fact that this persecution is unjustified and that it goes some way in reaffirming one of the absolutely fundamental strengths of Australian democracy and that is the free practice of religion, the free expression of religious views and the tolerance of different religious practices in Australia. I hope that the Senate will find it within its ambit to pass this motion this evening and formally put it on the books of the Australian Parliament, thereby conveying to the Australian Government and the United Nations its expression of concern for and outrage at the situation existing in Iran at present. The Baha'is quest for brotherhood and world peace deserves better; it deserves our support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although it cannot be said on this occasion, any more than any other, that Senator Puplick has worn his learning lightly, he has certainly made out a careful, well documented and persuasive case for his motion, just as the honourable member for Diamond Valley, Mr N. A. Brown, did in speaking on a similar subject in his contribution to the Human Rights Commission Bill debate in the House of Representatives last night. I simply say that the matter raised by Senator Puplick is undoubtedly important. He has certainly persuaded me to support the motion. I do so and I hope the Senate will do likewise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Puplick for the motion he has moved. I gave notice of a motion in similar terms a few months ago but was unable to proceed with it. I hope the motion will meet with the support of all sides of the Senate. I hope that the question will be put forthwith.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: 'DOCUMENTS ON AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE AND FOREIGN POLICY 1968-1975'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate views with grave concern the attempts by the Government to suppress the publication of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75 and extracts therefrom, noting in particular-

(a) the far-reaching implications for the future of democratic and open government in Australia if the Government should receive High Court endorsement in this case for its arguments based on breach of confidence, breach of Crown copyright or alleged breaches of the Crimes Act;

(b) the intimidatory and dishonest behaviour allegedly engaged in by Government officials in advising book-sellers and others against whom no injunction had been granted that distribution of the material by them would be illegal; and

(c) the absurd and self-defeating nature of the Government's actions to date in this matter both in Australia and overseas which-by virtue of their belated and ineffectual character-have apparently served only to give greater circulation and notoriety to the material in question than would otherwise have been the case.

Notice of motion in this matter was given four months ago, on 25 November 1980. Subsequent events may appear to have made some of it now inapplicable. In particular, of course, there has been a decision of a single judge of the High Court, not the Full High Court Bench but only Mr Justice Mason, in a splendidly sensitive judgment to the effect that the Government's pretensions with respect to breach of confidentiality and that part of the action which is based on alleged breaches of the Crimes Act are not in fact appropriate to demand the suppression of this book. The other part of the judgment, however, was that the law on Crown copyright would justify, pending a trial on the facts and further consideration of the legal issues involved, a continuation of the injunction in question. But certainly, insofar as Mr Justice Mason's decision did knock out the claims made by the Government with respect to breach of confidence and the alleged breaches of the Crimes Act, the condition of political democracy in this country might be thought to be now a little safer than it appeared to be at the time this motion was originally moved.

However, as I hope I can indicate in a moment, a great many questions remain unanswered, unresolved or insufficiently answered in relation to this matter. It is my submission that these matters are such that the Senate would now be justified in expressing its concern in the terms of this original motion. However, because the general issues surrounding this topic were, I think, well canvassed at the time-certainly they were set out at some length by me in moving a motion to refer certain matters to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee on 3 December-and because there will undoubtedly soon be another opportunity in this Parliament in the context of freedom of information legislation to canvass the general issues governing defence, security and international affairs matters at appropriately detailed length, I do not propose to go over these general issues of principle again tonight. I simply take the opportunity now in what I will say to remind the Senate of what some of the unanswered questions and unresolved issues are and hope that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), in reply, will be able to supply some information and set at rest some of the fears which I still have arising out of this action.

The first question I want to ask is: What precisely is the status now of the Goverment's litigation against Walsh and Munster, the editors of the book and against the Age and Sydney Morning Herald newspapers? Mr Justice Mason, as I said, upheld the continuation of the injunction with respect to the book itself and also with respect to the newspaper publication of the remaining proposed articles in the series on copyright grounds if not on the more substantial and more far-reaching grounds of a particular breach of confidence. Mr Justice Mason directed that the trial of the action proper in this matter to determine whether the injunction should in fact become permanent be held appropriately soon in the New South Wales Supreme Court. The question I have is: What exactly is happening now with respect to that trial? Is the action proceeding at all or is there some prospect of settlement and if so, on what terms? Is it proceeding-and this is the really important question-just on the copyright issue? Is that all that the Commonwealth is proposing to continue to pursue or are all the issues which Mr Justice Mason adjudicated in a preliminary way now to be up for grabs again so that the arguments will be run again in the New South Wales court with the prospect of an appeal going from that court on the questions of law involved to the Full Bench of the High Court? These possibilities are certainly technically open at this stage. What I think ought to be told to this Parliament is what precisely the Commonwealth's intentions are. Is the Commonwealth prepared to rest content with a statement of law by Mr Justice Mason on the crucial issues of confidentiality and the implications of an alleged breach of the Crimes Act as justifying suppression or does it want to pursue unto the democratic death the particular arguments that it was trying to run before Mr Justice Mason? They are important questions and they are ones that if the Commonwealth does answer in the affirmative, if it is trying to do all those things and the Attorney-General confirms that in his reply which I understand he will make to my speech tonight, in my submission the Commonwealth will be justified in being censured in the terms of this motion.

The second question I have is: What is the status of the action in the United Kingdom against the New Statesman magazine which was, of course, set on foot at the same time-late November or early December last year-in order to suppress the intended publication by the New Statesman of major extracts from the book? Is that injunction which was then obtained on a temporary basis still standing? What is the status of that litigation in the United Kingdom? Is the Commonwealth proposing to pursue the matter to make the injunction permanent? Has the Commonwealth made up its mind in that respect? What is happening? If the Commonwealth is still pursuing this matter against all principle, as I certainly would say and I believe the Opposition would say and indeed a number of individual senators on the other side of the chamber would say, again I believe it is appropriate for the Commonwealth to be censured in the rather polite terms of this motion.
The third question I have which is relevant to part (c) of the motion before the chamber is: When can I expect an answer to question 151 which I put on notice on 26 November 1981?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pressing your luck now.

—Yes, 1981 is overdoing it. I meant 1980. Thank you, Senator, for that very timely intervention. You can always be relied upon to bring accuracy to these occasions. If I may remind the Attorney, the terms of that question are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) How many copies of the book Documents on Australian Defence and Foreign Policy 1968-75 were put into circulation before an injunction was granted against the publishers, Messrs Walsh and Munster.

(2) How many copies of the early editions of The Age and The Sydney Morning Herald containing extracts from the book were put into circulation before injunctions were granted against those newspapers.
(3) How many and which other Australian newspapers and magazines have published extracts from the book.
(4) How many and which radio broadcasts in various parts of Australia have transmitted material from the book.
(5) How many and which overseas publications have published and circulated material from the book.

(6) Is it the case that copies of the book are in the possession of (a) the Indonesian Government; (b) the United States Government; and (c) other governments whose relations with Australia are dealt with in the book.

The obvious point of that question is to elicit data in support of paragraph (c) of the motion now before us which refers to the absurd and self-defeating character of this litigation which has served only to draw attention and to give notoriety to the documents in question, documents which, it seems, already in fact have been given very wide circulation. Not only do I seek from the Attorney an answer as to when my question will be answered but also I seek from him tonight, if he is minded and able to give them, some answers to those very specific questions that have now been before him to ponder for the last four months. I make the point that surely the Attorney cannot claim that the substance of those questions is sub judice in any respect. I hope that the kind of material sought by way of answers to those questions is the kind of evidence which, to the extent that it is relevant to the trial of this action, the Commonwealth would be able and willing to make available to the court and to provide generally to the best of its knowledge. I cannot see in any way that it could prejudice the Commonwealth's claim for that information to be out and about.

The fourth matter I raise for the attention of the Attorney and indeed the Parliament is relevant to paragraph (b) of the motion before us tonight. I ask: When can I expect an answer to question on notice 152 asked on 26 November 1980? This question sought detailed answers as to whether the Commonwealth engaged in intimidatory behaviour against particular booksellers. I will not read the terms of the question because they are quite long. I simply remind the Attorney that the terms of that question in fact repeated the terms of the question without notice I asked on the same day and which the Attorney in reply decided to take further advice on. The double trouble that I have endeavoured to give the Attorney by putting the question on notice as well as asking a Question without Notice does not, unfortunately, appear to have accelerated the response that I received to it. I hope that I can get a response tonight from the Attorney as to the specific questions of detail there raised. I make the point again, even more strongly in this case, that surely material of this kind cannot possibly be regarded as sub judice in the context of the continuing litigation, if indeed it is continuing, and I hope the Attorney will not be tempted to make any such claim.

The final matter I raise and on which I seek answers is in respect of the very serious question of intimidation or big brother operations, this time in another guise, by the Australian Government in the context of the allegations made of telephone tapping as part and parcel of the Commonwealth's rather ham-fisted endeavours to suppress the publication. The Attorney will recall that on 2 December 1980 I asked a Question without Notice as to whether there had been tapping of the telephones of Mr Tom Kelly and Mr Jack Graham, senior office bearers of the New South Wales Society of Labor Lawyers, in their conversations, in particular, with the radio station 2SER-FM because it would appear that it was only by such tapping that the information in question could have been obtained. The Attorney gave me a reply on that occasion which indicated that, whilst he was not going to answer the question as to whether there had been an interception, he would answer part of the question as to where the information as to the likelihood of a radio broadcast taking place had come from. On that occasion I asked the Attorney-General a supplementary question, as reported at page 215 of Hansard, of which the Attorney said he would take notice. I ask him tonight for a response to that supplementary question.

I asked the Attorney-General whether he would make further inquiries as to the source of what he described as the anonymous telephone call to establish, at least to his own satisfaction, whether the anonymous call did or did not emanate from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or from some other like body-and would he give further consideration to advising the Senate accordingly. In reply to the supplementary question the Attorney said that 'I will take note of the further question from Senator Evans'. As he has had four months in which to take notice of the question, I ask the Attorney, in all good faith, whether he would be prepared to contemplate tonight giving us an answer and putting at rest the fears, legitimately held I believe by myself and certainly those persons more closely involved in this series of actions, as to where the tip-off in fact came from? I do not propose, as I said, to take advantage of the opportunity this motion gives me to beat the drum any further on the whole issue. There will be later opportunities in other contexts to do that. I simply make the point that the questions raised by this motion are manifestly questions of high seriousness raising fundamental questions of democratic principle. I hope that the Attorney will, in the reply that I understand he is now about to make, respond accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans gave notice of a motion to the Senate in November. He moved that motion this evening and supported it with a speech of somewhat longer duration than we anticipated. I am not complaining about that. The motion raises very fundamental questions about freedom of information, protection of Government documents and the legal means by which the Government can protect such documents. It also raises very fundamental questions about the sub judice rule and the relationship between proceedings in Parliament and statements made, particularly by myself as Attorney-General, in relation to proceedings in which I, in my office, am deeply involved. However, Senator Evans has really sought to use the motion as a vehicle to obtain a good deal of information. It is a sort of extended new form of Question Time. I do not mind really on that basis responding as much as I can to the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I am bound to say that the Government will oppose the motion and will do so for reasons that I think I must mention although the matter is not to be debated at any length. The motion seems to suggest that the Government should not be taking proceedings of the kind it took in the High Court at the end of last year and that the Government should not be seeking to use the forms of legal redress which are mentioned there, including breaches of confidence, breaches of copyright or breaches of the Crimes Act, to protect documents which it believes should not be in the public arena. That pertains to parts (a) and (c) of the motion. I do not propose to debate the question before the court on the facts in this case. It would be quite wrong of me to discuss the facts because that clearly would be a breach of the sub judice rule. The courts will decide whether the documents are of a character which amount to a breach of confidence or a breach of copyright. The court will decide also whether the law of copyright is an appropriate vehicle in these cases. I think that is a subject that may well be debated on another occasion.

Why I say that the Government will oppose the motion is that we believe that there are certain documents in the possession of government which we believe must remain confidential for the workings of government. I think that those on all sides of the freedom of information debate, including those honourable senators on the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, would support that view. I know Senator Evans not only is a member of that committee but from comments I have heard him make recognises that there are such documents in the possession of government which must be protected for various good reasons. They are documents which affect the inner workings of government, certainly for periods when they are highly relevant. There are also documents which would be prejudicial to international relations, to defence and to security and so forth. Mr Justice Mason recognised that fact in the judgment he gave on the interim injunction. I will read from the judgment that Mr Justice Mason gave in the High Court. He said:
. . . the court will determine the government's claim to confidentiality by reference to the public interest. Unless disclosure is likely to injure the public interest, it will not be protected.

The court will not prevent the publication of information which merely throws light on the past workings of government, even if it be not public property, so long as it does not prejudice the community in other respects. Then disclosure will itself serve the public interest in keeping the community informed and in promoting discussion of public affairs. If, however, it appears that disclosure will be inimical to the public interest because national security, relations with foreign countries or the ordinary business of government will be prejudiced, disclosure will be restrained. There will be cases in which the conflicting considerations will be finally balanced, where it is difficult to decide whether the public's interest in knowing and in expressing its opinion, outweighs the need to protect confidentiality.

I do not wish to adopt that statement as the absolute correct proposition of law in this matter because obviously the question of law itself is one which ultimately may well be decided in these proceedings. I quote it because in the interim proceedings a very distinguished Australian lawyer and a judge of the High Court has stated a principle which clearly justifies the action which the Government took and which it may be required to take if similar circumstances should arise again.

These proceedings commenced in great haste, one Friday evening early in November when late in the afternoon of that day information was received in the Department of Foreign Affairs that a book was about to be published. According to the material received the book contained documents of a very sensitive character in relation to the sorts of matters which Mr Justice Mason mentioned in that part of his judgment which I have quoted. Proceedings were taken and an interim injunction was obtained at a late hour of that day from Mr Justice Mason. The proceedings that have taken place in the High Court have been in relation to that interim injunction which Mr Justice Mason continued on the ground of breach of copyright and referred all the issues in the action to the Supreme Court of New South Wales because obviously a great deal of evidence is still required.

Those are the reasons the Government took the action. Whether or not in relation to the particular documents in this book the Government was justified in taking that action will be, as I said, ultimately determined in those proceedings. The motion that has been moved by Senator Evans really seeks to deny the right of a government to take protective action of that kind in relation to the documents. I understand that he and all those intending to participate in the freedom of information legislation debate would recognise that if documents did fall into that description then the Government would be justified in seeking to restrain their publication. Whether the form of the law as it stands is inadequate obviously is a matter for debate. It may well be that the powers open to a government to give protection to this class of documents even under the most liberal freedom of information legislation need further consideration. As I said, it may be that the law relating to copyright is not the most appropriate vehicle. It may be that the law relating to documents in confidence is not going to prove to be adequate. But there may well be debate about these things and there may well need to be law reform in relation to these matters at some future date. But that is not the issue that is raised in this motion tonight. It will not be the issue that will arise even in the debate on the freedom of information legislation itself. For those reasons the Government will oppose this motion because on the face of it it does appear to deny the Government any right to take that sort of action.

As to the proceedings themselves, I can provide the Senate with certain further information. In relation to the proceedings against the newspapers, a summons for directions has been taken out in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. An order has been given that all interlocutory steps are to be completed by July this year. The present position is that the Commonwealth has delivered answers to a request for further and better particulars on 18 March and the defendants are required to deliver their defence by 1 April. At the time the Commonwealth delivered its particulars it informed the defendants that the Commonwealth does not intend to pursue the claim based on the Crimes Act.

In the proceedings against the publishers and the distributors, a summons for directions has been heard and again all interlocutory steps are to be completed by July 1981. The Commonwealth has until 1 April to deliver answers to the defendants' request for further and better particulars. As to the proceedings in the United Kingdom against the New Statesman I point out that the action was commenced in London on 14 November. Interim injunctions were granted and further proceedings were adjourned by consent. That is where those proceedings stand at the present time.

In relation to all of these proceedings, discussions are taking place between the Commonwealth and the several defendants in these actions as to the future course of proceedings apart from the steps that I have mentioned. But as those discussions have been taking place without prejudice I do not propose to say anything further about them here.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are pursuing the breach of confidence issue at the moment?
—Breach of confidence, certainly will be strongly pursued in the proceedings.
—You don't accept Mr Justice Mason's decision on that issue?

—No, because we are very concerned to ensure that there is some adequate form of legal protection which I have already mentioned. Whether or not this course of action is adequate, we want to have that established because if it is not adequate there will have to be some other form of legal protection. I think that is all I need say in relation to the matters that Senator Evans has raised about the proceedings, or at least all I can say.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans also referred to some questions that he asked me. In relation to one of a series of questions-I think it is No. 151 on the Notice Paper-I have given consideration to a draft answer to that question but I have been concerned that it does raise facts which may well be in evidence in the proceedings in the Supreme Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it would be uncontested evidence.

—I have not satisfied myself as to whether those questions can be answered. I will have another look at the matter. I have not yet had sufficient satisfaction that that is so. As Senator Evans is so anxious to have an answer I will have a look at it again. As to the other questions that he asked me in relation to actions by Commonwealth officers, I answered then in principle. Senator Evans had asked me in a question without notice-in fact it is in paragraph (b), as the second limb of this motion-about the actions of government officials advising booksellers in relation to the injunction that had been obtained and endeavouring to obtain their co-operation in not selling the book and avoiding the necessity of having to take proceedings against some large numbers of booksellers. I have already indicated, in answer to a question, why those proceedings were taken. The question on notice calls for a great deal of information. When that is collected, the question will be answered.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the other question that the honourable senator asked me, it does not appear to me that there is any way of finding out who an anonymous telephone caller is. Of course I do not propose to say anything about whether any action has been taken under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. That is as much information as I can provide in reply to the questions asked by Senator Evans. As I have said it is a rather strange use of a motion to try to obtain further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to winkle it out of you in some way.

—The honourable senator has not succeeded, has he? It has not proved to be a successful tactic. However, when the Senate seeks endorsement of the principles in the motion, for reasons that I have given, the motion will be strongly opposed by the Government. I trust that the Senate will defeat the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim not only to be disappointed by the answer of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) but also in one respect to have been misrepresented in it. I do not want to seek a right of reply but I will make a corrective statement because there is one aspect of Senator Durack's reply which surprises me. He said that I had gone on record as acknowledging the right of the Government to protect from scrutiny its internal working documents, documents relating to defence security in international affairs and other sensitive documents of that kind. I make the point that nowhere have I made any statement in as sweeping terms as that. Indeed, the whole argument about freedom of information is as to whether there are unqualified rights in government to suppress documents of that kind or rather, as I contend and have contended on numerous occasions, whether there are overriding questions of public interest in respect of all those classes of documents which ought to be resolved, where there is a dispute by some independent tribunal and not simply by unilateral government action. I wish to make the record absolutely clear in that respect-if it has not already sunk into Senator Durack-because there is a very serious dispute between us on that question of principle. I would not wish him to engage in any further misrepresentation of that kind, cavalierly or otherwise.
