SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) is of the opinion that Australian families, particularly one-income families, have been financially disadvantaged by the failure of the Government to either increase or index family allowance payments;

(b) notes the Prime Minister's election night statement that certain things undertaken in the last five years had 'not pleased all people', that his Government had 'heard that message' and that 'we will use all our energies and all our efforts to advance the cause of all Australians and all Australian families'; and accordingly
(c) impresses on the Prime Minister and the Government the urgent need to take long overdue action to assist Australian families, particularly one-income families and families with young children.

I shall deal with the paragraphs of the motion as they occur. It is my intention to prove to the Senate that it should be of the opinion that Australian families, particularly one-income families, have been financially disadvantaged by the failure of the Government either to increase or to index family allowance payments. Honourable senators will recall that the family allowance system was established in 1976 when child endowment payments and rebates for children were abolished. Whilst at that time I applauded the Government's move, I warned that unless these new family allowance payments were indexed they would cause considerable concern and serious financial disadvantage to families in the long term. That is precisely what has occurred.

As the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) stated recently in an address to, I think, the Institute of Public Affairs in Sydney, in 1976 the cost of the new family allowance program was approximately $700m and the savings to the Government through the abolition of the child endowment scheme and the child rebate scheme amounted to about $650m. In effect, it was a straight swap. In effect, the Government took the money out of the wallet and put it in the purse. I did not object to that and I do not think many other people objected to it. I think it had been noted that the rebate often went to the male taxpayer and was not necessarily spent for and on behalf of the children. However, the fact that these family allowances have not been in- dexed has caused serious disadvantage to Australian families-all families, not just single income families. As the Senate would know, since that time prices have risen, according to the consumer price index, by in excess of 60 per cent. So, as a corollary, the value of those family allowance payments has been eroded by in excess of 60 per cent. Even if we applied to the family allowance the system which is applied for the indexation of pensions we would see that since 1976 family allowance payments have been eroded to the extent of 56 per cent.

A table has been prepared for me showing on a weekly basis the current position of family allowances and what they ought to be. I remind the Senate that an outdated method is used to calculate the increases in pensions. The allowance is paid monthly, but I will use weekly figures as they are the figures that were supplied to me. Currently, an amount of $3.50 a week is paid for the first child. That payment ought to be $5.45 a week. An amount of $5 is paid for the second child. That ought to be $7.80. An amount of $6 is paid for the third child. That ought to be $9.35. An amount of $6 is paid for the fourth child. That ought to be $9.35. For the fifth and later children an amount of $7 is paid. That ought to be $10.95. In other words, a mother with five children has had her family allowance eroded by an amount of $15.40 a week. She is $15.40 a week worse off. I mention and remind the Senate that these figures would have been for November 1980. A further adjustment to pensions will occur in May 1981 and, of course, these figures will then have to be adjusted. So, honourable senators can see that all families have been seriously, financially disadvantaged by the failure of the Government either to increase or to index family allowance payments.

I turn to a statement made by Mr David Scott of the Brotherhood of St Laurence in Melbourne. It appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 January 1981. The article was headed: 'Level of family allowance linked to poverty'. In the article, Mr Scott made a number of points about the effect that this matter is having on families whose breadwinner is unemployed. The article, speaking of Mr Scott, states:
He said the present level of family allowances also affected working people with more than two children.
'A person with a low income and more than two children is in difficulty,' he said.
Poverty levels set by the Institute of Applied Social and Economic Research at Melbourne University are based on a formula devised in 1966.

In the example of a working man with a wife and four children, the poverty level for that family according to the Institute is $195 a week. So, quite obviously, families are in dire straits if the breadwinner is on a weighted average weekly award wage and the family is a single income family. I will deal with the one income family in the third point I will make.

I now turn to my second point. I request the Senate to note the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made on the eve of the election. What did the Prime Minister say on the eve of the election? Two days before the election, on Thursday 16 October 1980, the Prime Minister made a speech in Launceston, Tasmania, in which he pledged to give back petrol rises as rebates or family allowances. The Prime Minister knows why he gave that undertaking and I know why he gave that undertaking. That undertaking was given and it received widespread publicity in the media throughout the length and breadth of Australia. The undertaking was given against the background of adverse polls which were running at that time against the Government.

An article appearing in the Australian of 16 October 1980 was headed: 'Fraser pledges to give back petrol price rises as rebates or family allowances: OPEC increases will fund tax cuts: Prime Minister says priority to return money to the people'. The article reads:

In a dramatic bid to counter the vote-winning Labor pledge of cheap petrol, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, last night promised to return revenue from increased petrol prices next year to the public in the shape of tax cuts or higher family allowances.

In the short term although a great many furphies and kites have been flown about tax cuts, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has said that the tax cuts are not on at this time. In fact, the Prime Minister's statement exists. The revenue from the petrol price increases which occurred from 1 January this year as a result of the Government's oil parity prices must now be returned to Australian families in the form of family allowances as promised by the Prime Minister.

I had thought that the Prime Minister was about to take some urgent action on this matter when I read the Governor-General's Speech made when Parliament assembled for the opening of the Thirty-second Parliament on 25 November 1980 after the 1980 elections. On page 4 of the Governor-General's Speech, under the heading 'Caring for People', the Speech stated:

In what I have said about unemployment, youth and the economy, I have stressed my Government's concern with the human dimensions of the issues involved. It believes that the only legitimate yardstick for assessing any policy is not conformity to an ideology, not the strengthening of the state, but the effectiveness of that policy in enhancing the lives of people. This is the fundamental concern of my Government.
And this is the nub of the matter. The Speech went on:
This concerns expresses itself in a diverse range of measures to which my Government is committed:

It is evident in the commitment of my Government to a range of social security and welfare measures which will strengthen the family and through it the basic social fabric of this country. My Government has already introduced a number of measures designed to assist families. It will be looking closely at its policies with the objective of further enhancing the position of Australian families.

That Speech, read in conjunction with the promise given two days before the election, meant one thing-the Government was preparing to take action before the next Budget to honour its promise. Indeed, shortly before the recent by-elections were held, when the Cabinet was meeting in Adelaide, South Australia, a leak came from the Government concerning its intention to honour its election promise. Headlines such as '$5 Child Boost Plan' were spread across the front pages of newspapers. For example, the Herald of 10 February 1981 carried that heading creating an expectation amongst Australian families that at last the Government would honour its promise.

I remind the Senate again of the promise which, as I have said, was given against a background of adverse polls running against the Government and of the Labor Party's policy in respect of oil and petrol prices. I shall quote from the Australian article which states:

In a dramatic bid to counter the vote-winning Labor pledge of cheap petrol, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, last night promised to return revenue from increased petrol prices next year to the public in the shape of tax cuts or higher family allowances.

When one reads the fine print a little further down one will see that it refers, of course, only to increases from 1 January this year. The Prime Minister referred to returning to Australian families increased revenue from its oil levies from 1 January of this year. Let us have a look at what has happened in regard to the oil levies from 1 January this year. What has happened is this: On the Treasurer's own figures, the Government expects that the January increase in petrol prices at the pump will return to the Government an extra $170m in this half year. That money is flowing in the back door when it should be flowing out the front door in the form of increased family allowances, according to the promise of the Prime Minister, but it is not doing so. In answer to a question in the Senate on 5 March, Senator Carrick made a response which in fact concerned me very greatly. In reply to the question Senator Carrick said that he was aware of the Prime Minister's policy statement and that he had no doubt at all that it would be implemented, but he then added:
Of course, it would be a matter for budgetary implementation and therefore, no doubt, will be considered in the present process of putting the Budget together.

Senator Carrick also referred to the Bass Strait oil strike in November of last year. If the Government uses that as an excuse then it is acting irresponsibly and contrary to the expressed promise made by the Prime Minister two days before the Federal election. I say this because although the shortfall in production due to that strike was $171m, the oil is still in the ground, and the Government will, at a particular stage, receive the increased oil levy when that oil comes up from the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —I question the logic of that, Senator Harradine. The money is not in the hands of the Government if the oil is still in the ground.

—It is still in the ground. The Government will get the money. The Prime Minister made the promise that any increases arising from increased petrol prices from 1 January would be passed on to Australian families. He did not say that all of the oil levy which is received from Australian crude oil would go to families. Therefore, the comment by the Leader of the Government in the Senate about the loss to the Government on oil levies because of the strike in Bass Strait is in fact irrelevant and does not relate in any way to the promise of the Prime Minister to return the increases to Australian families from January of this year. I repeat: That increase, according to the Treasurer's own figures, this half year will be $170m. What would that mean so far as family allowances are concerned? I have the statistics provided for me by the Parliamentary Library, but they are in monthly amounts. This would result in approximate increases as follows: For the first child, an increase of $5.80; for the second child, an increase of $8.30; for the third child, an increase of $10; for the fourth child an increase of $10; and for the fifth child and later children, an increase of $11.65. That is what it means and that is not yet occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: Families, and particularly mothers, are expecting increases in family allowances, and these are long overdue. I am indebted, frankly, to a number of women who have provided information in respect of the family. This group of women who are organised on a nation-wide basis are members of the Women's Action Alliance. These people, together with all Australian families, are concerned that the money is flowing in the back door and not going out the front door. The Government is hoarding it. I do not know the reason.

Senator Chaney, in that same address to the IPA, stressed the importance of the family and also its importance in respect of the care and nurture of young children and the care of the elderly and the care of the sick. He implied that these functions are carried out more efficiently and effectively and less expensively by families than by the state. If families are the cheapest and the best providers of these services then it is in the nation's interest for families to function with economic security and equal opportunity. Today we had in the Senate a review of Australia's demographic trends. That review showed the increased participation by married women in the paid work force and the effect that this and other factors are having on the birth rate. This increase in the work force participation, lower family sizes and the increase in the proportion of single parent families have focused attention on the relevance of the concept of a family with a breadwinner, a dependent spouse and dependent children.

Mr Howard, in a very interesting paper which was presented in the House of Representatives on 12 March 1981, made reference to this question of single income families. He gave a number of statistics. However, any statistics about the family really provide a snapshot of the situation at a particular time. Every family has a life cycle which starts at marriage and proceeds through child rearing to the stage when the children reach adulthood and leave the parental home. Most families will pass through the dependent wife-dependent children stage at some period in their life cycle. So the fact that at any given time the snapshot discloses that a certain percentage of families are of this type or of the other type obscures the more meaningful concept. If we look at the life cycle of families, as a movie film, we will see that most of them will move through this stage at some time or other. Having said that, what does the snapshot reveal at this time? Mr Howard, in his paper presented on 12 March, said that it is worth noting that of the total number of 3,750,000 married taxpayers, some 1,250,000 have dependent spouses. Bearing in mind that I said this is a snapshot, most families will go through that stage if we look at the cycle as a marriage movie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do the figures you give show that one-third of married taxpayers have a dependent spouse?

—I am reading from Mr Howard's document in which he said that it is worth noting that of the total number of married taxpayers of 3,750,000, some 1,250,000 have a dependent spouse. That is what he said. Of course, many of the 3,750,000 married taxpayers could be men married to wives who are also taxpayers. That is the situation. I mentioned to the Senate that this is the snapshot at this point in time. Married couple families, with wives not in the work force, and with dependent children represent 30.9 per cent of all married couple families and 27 per cent of all families, including single parent families. Quite obviously, not all married couples are taxpayers. For example, there would be a large number of persons receiving social security benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: When considering paragraph (c) of the motion that I have moved, the question arises as to the incomes of Australian families. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics document 'Income Distribution, Australia 1978-79: Families', which is the preliminary document, in 1978-79 average annual incomes ranged from $13,280 for families with two members to $20,510 for families with six or more members. The estimated number of families and their average annual incomes, according to the Bureau, were as follows: There were 572,000 families with no income earners, and they received an income of $6,130. There were 1,174,600 families with one income earner and their average annual income was $13,460.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you say 'family', you mean a married couple and children, not just a married couple, do you?

—'Family' is defined in the Bureau's document as having one income, two incomes or three or more incomes. The situation raised by the honourable senator does not arise at this stage until I get to the other figures regarding children. There were 1,583,100 two-income families and their average annual income at that time was $19,280. There were 406,600 families with three or more income earners and their average income was $28,410. The total number of families, according to the figures, was 3,736,900 with an average income of $16,430. What does that tell us about the two-income families? In the period of the Bureau's sample, 1978-79, average earnings per employed male unit were $11,736 per annum. One income families had an average income of $13,460, but two-income families had an average income of $19,280. The net result of that is clearly that single income families-I suppose that is prima facie self-evident-are substantially worse off than dual income families. One of the reasons for the higher participation rate of married women in the work force at present is that the single income family cannot survive. Therefore, the mother or the wife is forced, through economic circumstances, into the paid work force. I referred to that in a previous debate today. But again, it is self-evident.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just refer again to the Bureau's figures which were released just before the election-I think I used them during the election-on 30 September 1980. A survey was done by the Bureau in Queensland and its report was entitled 'Employed Married Women in the Labour Force, Queensland, November 1979'. The ABS surveyed 184,000 married women in Queensland. Of the sample, 93,300 were responsible for one or more children under the age of 15 years. Of that group, 49 per cent give financial reasons as their main reason for working. It was interesting to note that many of them gave as their reason for working the need to pay off the mortgages on their homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate, but I must bring up a matter for the attention of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the Senate. It is an illustration of the problems that some groups in the community which have been trying to develop child care centres and which have had Government approval to do so are facing because of the action of the Government in going back on agreements concerning these centres. Tonight I will bring a specific case to the attention of the Senate and the Government. I refer to an undertaking given by the previous Minister for Social Security that the Government would fund a child care centre adjacent to the Australian Government Clothing Factory in Coburg, Victoria, for parents working in the factory and in nearby work places.

SPEECH.PARA: The plans for this centre began about three years ago when a group of Italian women based in Coburg, recognising the importance of child care, particularly for women in manufacturing industry, organised lunch time factory meetings and received overwhelming support for their proposal. They found the need of the area to be urgent and of considerable proportions. The initial survey showed that mothers in the five factories visited could make use of a child care centre for 194 children. The working party formed was later broadened to include several unions to which the women belonged, the Centre for Urban Research and Action, the Working Women's Centre and the Coburg City Council. The then Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Sir Robert Cotton, claimed that the Government as the employer could not provide the centre in the clothing factory but offered adjacent land if the Coburg City Council would sponsor the project, a proposal to which the Council agreed. A submission was placed with the Victorian Office of Child Care in July 1978, almost three years ago. On 9 March 1979, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, as Minister for Social Security, approved in principle the submission for the building of a 60-place child care centre to cost some $250,000 on the agreed site by the clothing factory. Discussions were held with Vicrail regarding access and with Mr Edmonds of the Department of Housing and Construction, who was to be the architect for the project. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle wrote on 27 August last year to Mr G. Harman, the Town Clerk of Coburg, assuring the Council that there was no proposal to withdraw the Commonwealth commitment, though she said that if problems could not be resolved she may have to look at an alternative proposal. She said:
The extent of unmet need for day care in the area is clearly evident, particularly in relation to work related child care for migrant women and the 'Galbally Report'.

On 16 January this year the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Philip Lynch, agreed to the lease of the Gaffney Street Community Child Care Centre, and there appeared to be no barrier to its going ahead. However, a month ago, Mr Harman, the Town Clerk, indicated that the Department of Social Security was planning a retreat from the Commonwealth's commitment.

The Minister for Social Security claimed then and I have no doubt will claim later that the reason was that the cost has gone up considerably since Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle approved the project. He was therefore seeking the Coburg group's assistance in developing an alternative proposal. The Coburg group does not want an alternative proposal. It has worked for three years in good faith to get a work-based centre close to the factories. The scheme was developed carefully after consultations with members of the community in general, with workers and with unions. It was a project to which a Minister for Social Security gave approval.

In child care matters organisations which enter agreements with the Government are always held to the letter of any funded proposal. Any attempt by organisations to modify their proposals to any extent frequently put these projects at risk. We should ask why the Minister should not expect the agreed proposal to be the one that the community wants, not a different model presented by the Government on the eve of the work-based centre's construction. Why should there be one rule for those who seek funding and gain funding and another for the Minister and the Government? I suggest that there is ample evidence, admitted by the Government, of the need for these centres in general and this case in particular. I remind the Senate and the Minister of the findings of the research report for International Women's Year entitled: 'But I wouldn't want my wife to work here'. It was a tragic report on migrant women in the work force. It reads:
They-
That is, the women interviewed at the time-

stated that because of economic and survival pressures they had to work; because of poor education and lack of English they had to work in factories and this meant they had to leave their children. They knew little about child-minding services which may or may not have existed near their homes. Many had few friends or relatives and told us they could not understand why factories did not have child-care services as they did in Europe or South America. They were forced to make unsatisfactory child care arrangements which caused enormous psychological worries and often physical accidents.

The Jackson report on manufacturing industry looked at both industry and the workers in industry. It stated that child care facilities were one of the factors that impinged on the effectiveness and quality of work life and noted that so far few efforts had been made to allow people and industry to reap potential benefits from new approaches in such areas. I suggest very strongly that we should support the right of the working party of the Gaffney Street Child Care Centre not to have its new approach-a work-based centre in the environment of the clothing factory-scuttled by the Government's change of mind. The Government accepted the recommendations of the Galbally report on migrant services and programs. That report made specific recommendations in this area. It stated:

We recommend that the current child-care policy be reviewed and that the Government give priority to funding child-care facilities at places of work, jointly managed by the employers and the employees or unions. The employer should meet part or all of the capital cost with the Commonwealth providing assistance for equipment and recurrent costs.

The Gaffney Street project falls within these guidelines. It is exactly the sort of community and worker enterprise which should be encouraged. Governments cannot encourage projects like this by changing their mind right at the death knell after projects have been approved and people have worked hard and vigorously and have sacrificed much in many cases to get something off the ground. I do not believe that the Government should at this late stage cancel its support for the project. I do not believe that it should be offering alternative proposals which the organisation believes are second best. I think it should be held to the guarantee that it gave to the people who have worked so hard. The Opposition opposes this sort of backdown, endorses the proposal of the working party and hopes that the Government will again change its mind and support these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has raised a matter which was drawn to my attention by my Department in about mid-February, as I recall it. I wrote to Mr Harman on 26 February in the sorts of terms which have been outlined by Senator Grimes. In order to shorten my response, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my letter to Mr Harman of 26 February.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
P Stanfield/MV
Office of Child Care
26 February 1981 Dear Mr Harman,

On 27 August 1980, Senator the Hon. Dame Margaret Guilfoyle OBE, wrote to you in relation to the proposed Gaffney Street Child Care Centre. At that time, Senator Guilfoyle suggested that because of problems associated with the development of this project in the grounds of the Commonwealth Clothing Factory, consideration should be given to the development of an alternative proposal. I am now seeking your assistance in developing an alternative proposal.

The overriding problem with the proposal as it now stands and one that renders its completion unachievable, is that of cost. On current estimates, the capital grant of $250,000 approved in principle by Senator Guilfoyle in February 1979 would now be inadequate for the construction of a new 60 place child care centre (estimated cost for the completion of this centre could be as high as $350,000 to $400,000). In addition, I have been informed that the centre would be required to pay market rental for the land on which the building would be constructed, and this would place an intolerable financial burden on the operation of the centre.

Discussions with union groups whose members would benefit from the service indicate that they would be prepared to contribute only $15,000 towards outdoor equipment and landscaping costs. Accordingly, it would appear that at this stage an additional $100,000 to $150,000 might be required to construct the centre, plus additional recurrent assistance over and above that normally required for operational expenses to cover the cost of land rental. Additional funds would also be required to meet the cost of security fencing that will be required by the clothing factory.

An alternative proposal and one I understand has been raised with you by staff of the Melbourne office of the Department of Social Security, would involve the purchase of two houses near the clothing factory and their renovation to make them suitable for child care. This is the normal procedure associated with the development of centres now that the cost of constructing new centres has increased so substantially. Additional information relating to the purchase/renovation method for the development of child care centres can be obtained from the Melbourne office of the Department of Social Security. The contact officer is Mr P. Harris, Assistant Director Child Care, telephone (03) 669 6302.

I assure you that the decision to vary the earlier proposal in no way represents a departure from the commitment entered into by Senator Guilfoyle, but appears to be the only method by which a viable child care service can still be developed in the area within the limit of funds available. Accordingly I am seeking your full support in developing an alternative proposal.
Yours sincerely (F. M. CHANEY) Mr. G. W. Harman
Town Clerk
City of Coburg
P.O. Box 179
Coburg, Vic. 3058

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice-this is referred to in the letter-was that the possibility of an alternative proposal was raised not only by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle when she wrote to Mr Harman on 27 August 1980 but also with him by staff of the Melbourne office of the Department of Social Security. The reason for the alternative proposal being canvassed was, again as was indicated by Senator Grimes, that it would appear that the cost of the proposal had risen from the original level of $250,000, which was the figure of in principle approval by my predecessor, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, to an estimate of from $350,000 to $400,000. In the view of the officers dealing with the matter this warranted its re-examination, a view with which, on the basis of the facts as I know them, I agree.

SPEECH.PARA: I will examine the remarks made by Senator Grimes. I will of course consider a telegram which I received today from workers from the clothing factory who advised me that they had held lunch-time meetings on the matter and were seeking the building of a child care centre under the guidelines of the original proposal. I will advise Senator Grimes in due course of the results of that re-examination. It remains a fact that, if the funds made available for child care are spent in dollops of $400,000 as against $250,000, there will be fewer centres built and there will be fewer children serviced. It would be my general intention in the administration of this and other programs to seek the most economical solution consistent with the interests of the people we are trying to help. I think that Senator Grimes acknowledged that the Government had admitted the need of the children involved in this case. I stress to the Senate that any dispute revolves around the means by which we are going to meet the need and not the meeting of the need itself. I will undertake to have the matter carefully examined, bearing in mind the sort of principle that I have just mentioned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal Sen L.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What are the details of the work of the First International Biomass Experiment (FIBEX).
2. When will FIBEX begin its research program.
3. What nations will be participating in FIBEX.
4. What is the budget allocation for Australia's participation in FIBEX.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. FIBEX (First International BIOMASS Experiment) is the first data collecting effort of the International Program of Biological Investigation of Marine Antarctic Systems and Stocks (BIOMASS).

FIBEX will concentrate on the study of krill which is a key component in the biological food chain of the Southern Oceans. Krill being the lowest animal in the food chain, forms the diet of larger animals feeding in Antarctic waters. The current series of experiments to be undertaken on FIBEX contain the following elements:
an investigation of the distribution and abundance of krill using hydro acoustic echo sounding equipment and associated trawling;
determination of the distribution and abundance of phytoplankton (krill food);
oceanographic studies to monitor those chemical, physical and biological variables which may influence krill distribution, behaviour and life history; and
studies on krill swarms, where possible, to investigate their structure, behaviour and interaction with abiotic and biotic environment.

2. FIBEX commenced in February 1981 and will operate continuously for one month. The principal regions concerned are the Scotia Sea adjacent to the Antarctic Peninsula and off-shore from the Australian Antarctic Territory.
3. Argentina, Australia, Chile, France, Federal Republic of Germany, Japan, South Africa, United Kingdom, United States of America and the Soviet Union are participating in FIBEX.

4. Provision of $1.2m was made in the 1980-81 Budget for modifications to the M.V. Nella Dan, chartered by the Australian Government, and for the purchase and installation of sophisticated scientific equipment, to enable Australia to participate in FIBEX. Operational and ancillary costs will bring Australia's total expenditure on FIBEX to around $2m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government assist impoverished Australians who are overseas and who have an urgent need to return to Australia; if so, what are the details of the scheme, including the cost to the Government and any costs recouped for each of the past five years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In general, the policy is to assist, after due investigation, Australian citizens who are in distressed circumstances abroad. The assistance takes the form of the cost of passage to Australia at the cheapest rate available, together with a minimum of funds for incidental costs en route, provided that satisfactory guarantees are furnished by the repatriate and relatives or friends residing in Australia that the full cost to the Government will subsequently be refunded. Wherever possible a deposit against the expenses of repatriation is first obtained from the repatriate and/or the guarantor. Each approach is dealt with on its merits and there is no automatic entitlement to this assistance. Under current guidelines, the grant of assistance is considered more favourably if it is sought on behalf of a person who is:
(a) in difficulties through unavoidable misfortune (applications from persons proceeding overseas without making provision for their return journey are not usually given favourable consideration);

(b) a person who left Australia at a comparatively recent date with the intention of returning within a reasonable period (applications from persons who left Australia with the intention of settling abroad or who have been overseas for a considerable number of years are not usually considered favourably);

(c) separated from family or relatives in Australia, provided that relatives or friends residing in Australia who can assist financially, contribute to the cost of repatriation and given satisfactory written guarantees of repayment in full of the balance of all costs to the Government.
Disbursements and costs recouped for each of the last five years are as follows:

It is the policy of the Government to recover expenditure to the extent practicable. In many cases Australians with limited means repay loans by instalments over an extended period. Amounts shown in the 'repayments' column above often do not therefore relate to the expenditure shown for the same year, and recoveries of expenditure shown in the table may be expected to continue for some time into the future.

Under Section 7C of the Passports Act, a new passport can be issued only at the express direction of the Minister or in an emergency to a person who owes money to the Commonwealth in connection with his or her return to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During my visit to Indonesia in November 1980 I raised with the Indonesian Foreign Minister the allegations concerning the fate of Roger East which had emerged in October 1980. The Indonesian Foreign Minister promised that a reply would be given in the near future.

The question of Mr East's fate has been raised by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs with his Indonesian counterpart on several occasions since 1975.

Australian officials have repeatedly pursued the question of what happened to Mr East with Indonesian authorities in Jakarta, with the Indonesian Red Cross and, during visits to East Timor on a number of occasions, with the local authorities and with individuals there.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Central Intelligence Agency Activities in Australia

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1981 (Hansard, page 80) Senator Mason asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning alleged activities of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:

Honourable senators should be aware that some sixteen or seventeen enterprises include the words 'Nugan Hand' in their name. Not all are Australian registered and not all appear to have operated within Australia. For instance the Nugan Hand Bank, to which the Leader of the Opposition referred in a question to me on 5 March (House of Representatives, Hansard, page 452), was registered in the Cayman Islands. Nugan Hand Limited, to which Mr Justice Woodward-the NSW Royal Commissioner into Drug Trafficking-referred in his Second Report, was incorporated in Australia. Nugan Hand operated through an intricate web of corporations in Australia and overseas.

Setting aside sensationalist reports and speculation, the Commonwealth Government is most concerned about evidence of apparently illegal activities by the Nugan Hand group. The Commonwealth Government acted speedily after Mr Justice Woodward recommended that an appropriate law enforcement group should investigate the Nugan Hand group, arising from evidence of its involvement with criminals known to be themselves involved in drug trafficking.

I took the initiative of approaching the Premier of New South Wales on 26 August 1980, seeking the widening of the terms of reference of the New South Wales/Commonwealth Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking to enable it to investigate breaches by Nugan Hand of Commonwealth laws as well as of State laws. This special police group is investigating whether there was any criminal activity particularly drug-related, in or affecting Australia, by any persons connected with Nugan Hand activities, and, if so, identifying such persons so that appropriate action could be initiated.
I also offered the assistance of the Commonwealth to the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission in its separate inquiry into the financial affairs of Nugan Hand.

Turning to allegations of CIA involvement with Nugan Hand, as I informed the Leader of the Opposition on 5 March, any operations of the United States in Australia would be declared to the Australian Government and consequently agreed by the Australian Government. Officers from U.S. agencies working in Australia are declared to the Australian authorities and work with various Australian agencies.

In this connection I draw the attention of honourable senators to my statement made on 24 May 1977 (House of Representatives Hansard, pages 1695 and 1696) in which I reassured the Parliament that on review the activities of the United States Government in Australia had been found to be fully consistent with the interests and policies of the Australian Government and people. The Government is satisfied with the assurances received from elements of its own administration and from the United States Government, that neither the United States Government nor its representatives were involved in improper or inappropriate activities here. Beyond these general assurances, satisfactory specific assurances on this matter were obtained last year from Australian authorities and the United States Government.
The Government has no evidence that the Nugan Hand group was co-operating with the security services of any foreign power to interfere in Australia's domestic affairs.
If the honourable senator has any evidence relating to the affairs of the Nugan Hand group I invite him to provide it to the appropriate authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to refer the matter to the Treasurer who has furnished the following answer:

The decision to establish the inquiry was announced on 19 August 1980, in the Budget Speech, when I also indicated that the Government expected the inquiry to report before the 1981-82 Budget. The Inquiry's terms of reference and composition were announced on 18 September 1980. At that time I also indicated that the inquiry would be making and announ- cing its own arrangements for the receipt of evidence. These preliminary statements would have alerted interested parties to the need to consider the submissions they might wish to make to the inquiry.

The inquiry called for submissions through widespread advertisements in national and country newspapers around the middle of December 1980 and stated 6 February 1981 as the closing date for the receipt of submissions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What trachoma or eye-health programs exist for Aboriginal adults in the Northern Territory.
(2) What trachoma or eye-health programs exist for Aboriginal children in the Northern Territory.
(3) What success have any such programs had in reducing: (a) the incidence; and (b) the severity of trachoma in Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The provision of health services in the Northern Territory is the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government. In response to inquiries on this matter, the Northern Territory Department of Health has advised that trachoma is recognised as a serious eye health problem in many Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. It is generally accepted that infection in childhood results in eye changes which lead to a susceptibility to recurrent infection and, in some instances, to serious eye damage in adult life. Accordingly, the trachoma control program is being concentrated on children in Aboriginal communities. The program is based on the mass prophylactic use of oily tetracycline eyedrops and is being implemented through the extensive network of community health centres operated by the Northern Territory Department of Health in cooperation with local schools. Eye problems in adults are dealt with in the community health centres and, where necessary, consultations with specialist ophthalmologists are arranged.

(3) (a) and (b) In the areas where trachoma is hyperendemic, it is too early to determine if there has been a reduction in incidence. However, recent surveys have indicated that there has been a definite decrease in the severity of infections. In this regard, it must be recognised that inadequate community water supplies plays a significant part in the incidence and prevalence of trachoma and the Northern Territory Government has been actively promoting a five-year plan to upgrade water supplies and other basic services in Aboriginal communities. The importance of environmental factors was also stressed in the report of the National Trachoma and Eye Health Program, the recommendations of which included the need for improvement of such factors as housing, water, sewerage and garbage disposal facilities, in addition to improved treatment programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February 1981 (Hansard, page 12) Senator Evans asked me the following questions without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is it the case that character assessments are presently taking place in the Attorney-General's Department whereby all employees, including those who have no access to classified government documents, are being checked for such apparently irrelevant or ill-defined characteristics as 'undeclared homosexuality' or a 'loose tongue'? By what authority, legislative or administrative, are these checks being carried out? Are they being carried out or will they be carried out by any other department? If such action is not directly connected with the protection of highly sensitive classified material, what is the policy underlying such checks?

(2) Having agreed to further investigations, will the Attorney do two things: Firstly, undertake to table in Parliament forms that persons are being required to fill in and also any supporting documentation governing the procedures now applicable and, secondly, will he tell us what the fate of any member of his Department who refused to give consent to this procedure would be in practice?
The answers to the honourable senator's questions are:
(1) For the purpose of this answer officers in my Department and throughout the rest of the Public Service may be put into two categories.

The first category consists of officers who have or may have access to classified material. In respect of these officers, my Department obtains a security assessment from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. This clearance is obtained in accordance with the new security procedures adopted following the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979. In addition, after receiving the consent of the officer, my Department obtains from the Australian Federal Police details of any criminal charges involving the officer pending before a Court together with details of any conviction or finding of guilt which has been recorded against him. Alternatively, the officer is permitted to obtain a certificate as to those matters from the Police Force of each State or Territory in which he resided in the past five years. These procedures are, I understand, followed by all Departments.

The second category consists of officers who do not generally have access to classified information. The Department does not obtain a security assessment in respect of these officers. However, before a person is appointed to the Public Service, my Department, with the consent of the person concerned, obtains details of any criminal charges pending before a Court together with details of any conviction or finding of guilt recorded against him. Alternatively, the person may obtain a certificate in relation to those matters from the appropriate Police Force. I understand this is the practice followed in all Departments for officers in this category.

For a short period recently, my Department commenced to apply the procedure used on appointment of the second category of officers to all serving officers. The purpose of this was to provide maximum flexibility in the future deployment of staff.

The Permanent Head has now concluded that this procedure will not be generally applied to serving officers who are in the second category but may be applied in the case of promotion or transfer of officers to positions of special trust within the Department.
(2) Copies of the forms that persons have been asked to fill in are set out below.

In the case of an officer in the first category, a person declining to fill in the necessary forms may be regarded as ineligible for promotion or appointment to the position. If the person is already occupying the position, consideration would need to be given to whether he should be transferred to a position not involving such access.

In the second category, a person refusing to consent to the AFP providing the statement or to provide the certificate from the relevant Police Force mentioned above might be regarded as ineligible for appointment. As explained above, in relation to serving officers, the question will arise in the future only in relation to positions of special trust. A refusal to follow the procedure mentioned may result in ineligibility for promotion or transfer to such a position.
